PETITION.TITLE: Jarosite Dumping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to (a) reverse the decision to extend the time allowed Pasminco EZ to dump jarosite at sea, and (b) endorse and comply with the December 1995 deadline established by the London Dumping Convention.

PETITION.TITLE: Homeless Rate Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.
2.We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless rate benefits is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3.With the number of young people receiving youth homeless rate benefits increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programs to help keep families together.

PARA.TAB: Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Call on the Government to:
(a) review the guidelines for young homeless rate benefits; and
(b) show a greater commitment to programs which prevent family breakdown.

Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:

PROCTEXT.PARA: 1.(1)That, within 14 sitting days after the adoption of this resolution by the Senate and 28 days of making and subscribing an oath or affirmation of allegiance as a Senator, each Senator shall provide to the Registrar of Senators' Interests a statement of:

PARA.TAB: (a)the Senator's registrable interests; and

PROCTEXT.PARA: (b)the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware:
(i)of the Senator's spouse, and
(ii)of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support;

PARA.TAB: in accordance with this resolution and in a form determined by the Committee of Senators' Interests from time to time, and shall also notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar within 28 days of that alteration occurring.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2)That any Senator who:
(a)knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests by the due date;
(b)knowingly fails to notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar of Senators' Interests within 28 days of the change occurring; or
(c)knowingly provides false or misleading information to the Registrar of Senators' Interests;

PARA.TAB: shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly.

PROCTEXT.PARA: 2.That statements of the registrable interests of a Senator's spouse or of any dependent children submitted in accordance with paragraph (1) shall be maintained in a separate part of the Register and shall remain confidential to the Committee of Senators' Interests except where the Committee considers that a conflict of interest arises, at which time the Committee may table the declaration.

3.That the statement of a Senator's registrable interests to be provided by a Senator shall include the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware, of the Senator's spouse and of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, and shall cover the following matters:
(a)shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies;
(b)family and business trusts and nominee companies:

PARA.TAB: (i)in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust and the nature of its operation and beneficial interest, and

(ii)in which the Senator, the Senator's spouse, or a child who is wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, is a trustee (but not including a trustee of an estate where no beneficial interest is held by the Senator, the Senator's spouse or dependent children), indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust;
(c)real estate, including the location (suburb or area only) and the purpose for which it is owned;
(d)registered directorships of companies;
(e)partnerships, indicating the nature of the interests and the activities of the partnership;
(f)liabilities, indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned;
(g)the nature of any bonds, debentures and like investments;
(h)saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned;
(i)the nature of any other assets (excluding household and personal effects) each valued at more than $5 000;
(j)the nature of any other substantial sources of income;

(k)gifts valued at more than $500 received from official sources (such sources being an Australian or foreign national, State, provincial or local Government or a person holding an office in such a Government) or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources, provided that a gift received by a Senator, the Senator's spouse or dependent children from family members or personal friends in a purely personal capacity need not be registered unless the Senator judges that an appearance of conflict of interest may be seen to exist;
(l)any sponsored travel or hospitality received;
(m)being an officeholder of or financial contributor donating over $100 in any single calendar year to any organisation; and
(n)any other interests where a conflict of interest with a Senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Register and Registrar of Senators' Interests

PROCTEXT.PARA: 4.That:

PARA.TAB: (a)at the commencement of each Parliament, and at other times as necessary, the President shall appoint an officer of the Department of the Senate as the Registrar of Senators' Interests and that officer shall also be Secretary of the Committee of Senators' Interests;

(b)the Registrar of Senators' Interests shall, in accordance with procedures determined by the Committee of Senators' Interests, maintain a Register of Senators' Interests in a form to be determined by that Committee from time to time;

(c)as soon as possible after the commencement of each Parliament, the Chairman of the Committee of Senators' Interests shall table in the Senate a copy of the completed Register of Senators' Interests and shall also table every six months any notification by a Senator of alteration of those interests;
(d)the Register of Senators' Interests shall be available for inspection by any person under conditions to be laid down by the Committee of Senators' Interests from time to time; and
(e)that part of the Register of Senators' Interests relating to spouses and dependent children shall remain confidential to the Committee of Senators' Interests as provided for in paragraph 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator McKiernan, welcome to St Patrick's Day. I also welcome members of the Labor Party to the chamber; it is good to see them here—good of them to come along. It is absolutely no wonder the country is in such a mess when the Labor Party cannot even keep this chamber going. For those who are listening to the broadcast, I say that it is the government's duty to keep this chamber operating. Yesterday, the Labor Party could not muster a quorum for this chamber. I suspect that Labor senators were having a farewell party for Senator Richardson, with his newly found interest in overseas travel, perhaps in an ambassadorial post somewhere. Certainly, they were not in the chamber. They were somewhere else and could not keep the chamber going.
—I heard they were playing golf.

—Maybe they were playing golf. Whatever they were doing, they were not in the chamber where they are paid to be. The Labor Party cannot even keep this chamber going. So it is good to see a couple of Labor senators here today; welcome back.

PARA.TAB: Before the lunch break yesterday, I was speaking on this matter of registration of senators' interests. I indicated that I have no objection to disclosing what little assets I have. In fact, I have already done that in the past. Like Senator Panizza and others on this side who have been members of local authorities, we have already done that. We have disclosed, to anyone who was interested to look, what our assets and interests were in our role in local government. I have no particular concern about that.

The concern I do have with this motion by the Labor Party is that it is not a genuine attempt to disclose senators' interests. Senator Baume has mentioned on many occasions, and again today in a notice of motion, just how the Labor Party flouts these rules. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) cannot even fill in the form correctly. It will be interesting to see whether there is any response to Senator Baume's notice of motion this morning in which he asked whether the Prime Minister complied with the guidelines in disclosing his interests as required.

It is really just a stunt by the Labor Party. Members of the Labor Party are not genuine about disclosure of interests. I say this because I understand there was very little or no consultation with the Liberal Party on the form that the proposed resolution should take. One would think that if there were any genuine interest by the Labor Party in proper disclosure, it would have been done in a bipartisan way. There would have been some input from all parties—particularly the majority party in this chamber, the party that is favoured by a majority of Australians. One would have thought there might have been some consultation, but there was not.

I also say there is a lack of genuineness in the fact that this motion has been around since 1983 and the government, the Labor Party, has chosen not to bring the motion on. I know some of the sycophants in the press who run around after the Labor Party are saying that it is the Liberal Party that has been delaying it. We have never delayed it. It is a very important matter which requires very intense debate and scrutiny. It is something that we have been debating, but the Labor Party keeps refusing to bring it on. It was only because it was forced to do so, on some other little grubby deal it was doing with one of the minor parties, that we are debating the matter now. The Labor Party is interested in the political point scoring of it, but there is no genuine attempt to disclose.

In all instances, if we on this side of parliament, the Liberal and National parties, are discussing or debating a matter in which any of us have an interest, we disclose it at the time, and that is the proper disclosure that there should be. Anyone in the chamber or the press gallery, or any member of the public, can understand what assets we have that might conflict with the legislation or the discussion before the chamber.

During Senator Baume's speech on the motion today, he pointed out that Mr Keating did not disclose that he owed Mr Brown some $4 million, I think it was. I think that figure has since been altered to something else that Senator Baume has ascertained. How can we think that these rules are genuine when the Prime Minister cannot disclose those interests? At the time Mr Keating obtained a loan from the Commonwealth Bank he was either Treasurer or Prime Minister. It would be interesting to know whether the Prime Minister discloses his interests in the Commonwealth Bank or his loan dealings with the Commonwealth Bank when he makes decisions at the cabinet table on the Commonwealth Bank—the Commonwealth Bank being in the past wholly owned by the Commonwealth government, which is now a major shareholder. There is certainly a lack of genuineness in this.

I said yesterday that if the Labor Party were serious about disclosure and conflict of interest, why is it not looking at disclosure for members of the press gallery, proprietors of the news media and journalists who report this parliament? I hate to say it, but on many occasions members of the press gallery and journalists have a greater influence on action the government takes than do members of parliament who are not in government. It would seem fair to ask why the Labor Party is not looking at some disclosure for them. I also asked why the Labor Party and the unions are not required to disclose their assets because decisions this government makes every day affect the very large land-holdings of the unions and the very big shareholdings that I know the ALP has in Queensland and, no doubt, elsewhere. I also question why departmental heads are not required to participate in some form of public disclosure.

I am interested to see what the Democrats' amendment in relation to spouses is. There are fairly different proposals around. The government's proposal is that the assets of de facto spouses have to be disclosed if they are known. I want someone to tell me what a de facto spouse is. It seems to me to be a term which you can interpret as you want. If you are married, in a regular marriage, we know who your spouse is. But these days there are a number of people in the community who have relationships. Are they de facto spousal relationships? I understand that the current politically correct term used by the Labor Party for a husband, wife or the person you are closely associated with is `partner'. They are no longer a spouse but a `partner'. I wonder whether the de facto spouse spoken about in the Labor Party's proposal means partner. Just what does it mean? It might be interesting to hear some debate on that. I could not speak in this debate without referring to the sanctimonious claptrap that Senator Cook spoke on 19 August 1993, when this motion was first debated. Senator Cook said:

SPEECH.PARA: What have we got to hide in opposing this?
As I say, we are not particularly opposing the disclosure; we are opposing the form of it. He then went on to say:
In any case, from the Labor side, we do not want to hide anything;
This was at the time when Mr Keating, the Labor Party's leader, was hiding the extent of his interest. Senator Cook compounded that stupidity by later on the same day saying:
. . . the Prime Minister also declares his interests, members on the other side are aware that the Prime Minister has an interest in a piggery.

We did not know much about that until Senator Baume and others started investigating that matter. Since August 1993 we have known a lot more about the piggery but not, of course, because of anything the Prime Minister has told us; we know simply because Senator Baume, very skilfully and persistently, has gone through and exposed for the Australian public the Prime Minister's huge conflict of interest. For Senator Cook to suggest that the Prime Minister is the fountain of all virtue in disclosure is absolutely ridiculous. I find that quite amazing.

PARA.TAB: I understand the sensitivity of the Democrats to all this. In the press they have been blamed, along with us, for delaying this matter. I do not think they have; they are not in charge of the program of the Senate. It is a matter for the Labor Party, for the government of the day, to bring this motion on as and when required. The Labor Party has been messing around with this since 1983 simply because it did not want proper debate on and scrutiny of it. It knew in debate we would point out just how futile and how shallow these rules are.

I might just have a look at some of the rules to see how some of the Labor Party members have complied with them in the registers of interests they have lodged. Senators are supposed to declare shareholdings in public and private companies, including the name of the company or companies. I see that certain senators apparently trade in shares.

I congratulate Senator Colston on the way he filled in his form. I think he did so very truthfully and honestly. He has indicated that he has some shares in a private company, no doubt his own family company, and he then indicated that that family company has shares in a number of major listed public companies. It was very good of Senator Colston to disclose that. Under the rules he did not have to; all he had to do was say, `Yes, I have some shares in my private family company'. He did not have to disclose all the major companies he has shares in. From looking at this register I suspect that he invests in Australia, and good for Senator Colston. It looks as though he has a number of shares in different public companies. I would say he probably trades in them, and that is good to see.

But when does Senator Colston update that information? If he sold some of those shares and bought some more, as would a share trader, and particularly if he is doing it every day as a share trader would—and I know some parliamentarians who are share traders—apparently he would have to disclose the changes in his shareholdings every day as he bought and sold shares. In itself that suggests how stupid these rules are and how ineffective they will be.

Senator Burns's return is another matter of interest. Senator Bryant Burns has completed his return, as he is required to do, and that is beaut, but it is handwritten and his handwriting can hardly be read. So what is the point of a return that no-one can read? Senator Burns has complied with the rules—good for him—but anyone reading this to discover whether he has a conflict of interest would not be able to understand it because the handwriting makes it very difficult.

I mentioned that Senator Schacht, the small business minister, when filling in his form did not even understand the difference between a proprietary company and a public company. That is particularly interesting.

I point out that former Senator Sibraa disclosed that he had shares in Fendran Pty Ltd. There is no indication as to what Fendran does, as to whether it owns any assets, any land, any piggeries or any shares. There is nothing about that, so this disclosure is absolutely futile and valueless.

Turning to Senator Bolkus's disclosure, I understand that Senator Bolkus had a very high profile and public marriage just recently. Congratulations to him on that, but his form does not seem to disclose that he has a wife. Obviously this was completed before he was married. Again this shows the futility of the form in that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you checked out mine?

—I am talking about Senator Bolkus. I am not particularly interested in Senator West's details—or in Senator Bolkus's; I simply point out that I know Senator Bolkus has a wife, because it was in all the papers, but that fact is not mentioned in the return I have. Senator Bolkus also shows that he is in partnership with his sister in a company.
—That is family.

—Of course it is—that is great, but he is supposed to disclose the nature of the interest of the partnership, and he has not done that. I do not give two hoots about what the partnership does. I am simply saying that these rules are so stupid that not even Senator Bolkus has completed the form correctly. He is supposed to say what the partnership does and what it is about. I quote from the rules indicating he has to disclose any interests in relation to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . partnerships, indicating the nature of the interests and the activities of the partnership . . .

Senator Bolkus, a senior minister in this government, has not complied with this rule. He has not done it. What is being done about his not completing the form properly? Nothing, I suspect. Senator Bolkus has not disclosed anything. He could own the land that this parliament sits on, for all we know—that partnership might, for all we know—but it is not disclosed. That is why I say that this whole business is so futile.

PARA.TAB: I looked at Senator Beahan's return. He has disclosed that he has an overdraft on a trading account. A trading account is used in a business, but his form does not disclose his owning or having any interest in any business. What is happening there? He has a trading account for a business but no business. Again, I do not care too much about that, but it shows just how futile this whole set of rules is. I could go on all day with similar examples. I make it quite clear that I am not accusing any of the members of the Labor Party of deliberately misleading the Senate, but I am pointing out that these rules mean absolutely nothing.

When I fill in my form I will disclose, as best I can, the assets I have. I have—and have had for many years; since long before I ever thought of coming to this place—a family trust, the trustee of which is a private company in which my wife and I own a couple of $1 shares. According to these rules, I only have to disclose that I have a couple of $1 shares in this private family company; I do not have to say that it owns assets here and assets there and has a few shares—but I will. Whenever I speak in this chamber on any matter that in any way affects me, my family trust or anything like that, I tell the Senate about my interests.

In the debate in the Senate on better cities money in Townsville, where this Labor government gave $10 million in a pre-election buy-up, I criticised it—and I was criticised in my home town. I disclosed that I had property in that area. The government's giving money to that area was good for me—and I am glad it did it—but I think it was a wrong expenditure of money. I disclosed my interest at the time. That is the way we should do it; we should disclose these things. The rules before us, put up by the Labor Party, are simply a sham. It is very easy to get out of disclosing interests. People can buy things in the name of their spouse and not have to disclose them. It just makes a mockery of the whole process.

I note that we are also supposed to indicate liabilities, the nature of them and the creditor concerned. In the leading case, Mr Keating's registration of interests, not much about the nature of the liability was shown. We have since heard about the quite unusual arrangement where it is up to the borrower to decide whether to repay the debt to Mr Brown, a former Labor minister and current lobbyist. That detail, of course, was not in Mr Keating's registration of interests. Looking through the register I see that some people have disclosed debts owing. Some have said it is a debt to the bank for the purchase of their house; others have just said it is a debt. So what do we do? These rules do not make any proper disclosure of where conflicts of interest might occur.

I note with interest that there is a requirement to disclose any other interest where a conflict of interest with a senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise. On that basis all members of the Labor Party in this parliament should be disclosing that they are members of a party which has leased a premises that it owns to a Commonwealth government organisation at an outrageously high rent—a rent which will give the Labor Party a slush fund for campaigning at public taxpayers' expense of, I think, $35 million over the next 10 to 20 years. Why has that not been disclosed by members of the Labor Party?

It is the profits from those sorts of rorts by the government, publicly funded by the taxpayer, that will get this lot opposite elected. Those opposite will use the profits from that company to get elected, to get in here with all the trappings of office, yet none of them have disclosed that. I cannot think of a greater conflict of interest than a political party secretly leasing its premises to a government department at an enormously high rent—a rent which is far and away in excess of any comparable rents in this town or around Australia. Where was that disclosed in their register of interests?

The disclosure rules are not being complied with, and that has always been the concern that we in the Liberal and National parties have had. Labor Party members in this place flout the rules. They do not comply with them; they do not do what they are supposed to do. For that reason, this is a fairly futile exercise.

If these rules do come in, if the Senate happens to vote that way, people on this side of the chamber will comply with them. As we do now, as honestly as we are able, we will disclose areas where there might be any conflict. Members of the Labor Party do not do so; they have not done so. Why go through the facade and the farce of bringing these rules forward?

I would like to speak further on this matter but I suspect that some of my colleagues also want to speak on this debate—a debate that has been considerably shortened by the guillotine applied by the government in conjunction with the Democrats—so I will not proceed further. I simply reiterate that, if this were a proper disclosure provision, I am sure that the government would have the full and total support of senators on this side of the chamber. These mickey mouse regulations which mean nothing are just a farce, a sop by Labor Party members to pretend that they are interested in accountability. The regulations really mean absolutely nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues, in particular Senator Ian Macdonald, in speaking on this debate as to whether the Senate should establish a register of senators' interests. For a number of reasons, to support the proposal as it now stands would be an unwise thing to do. Perhaps the most obvious of those reasons are the top two. Firstly, we run a serious risk of creating a false sense of security in the community. It would be a case of, `We don't have to worry about whether people have a conflict of interests because they have had to establish their interests in this register; they have had to disclose them. So we don't have to worry'.

PARA.TAB: We have seen in recent debates, as Senator Macdonald indicated, that the register is not drafted so that that is the case. It is not true that we do not have to worry. Any members of the community who bothered to look at the House of Representatives disclosure forms would have no idea of the extent and involvement of Mr Keating's companies in the piggery to be established, no idea of the values involved in loans and in assets and liabilities—no idea at all. Perhaps the piggery is the classic example of where looking something up in one of these registers is really no good to us at all.

If we wanted to chase it up, we could go to the relevant registers and follow through all the companies and do an enormous amount of digging, which obviously has been done. In that sense, the register gives a clue as to where to go. But why bother to establish a register of interests which, on its face, is clearly useless? We establish a false sense of security in the community that we do not have to worry about people's interests because they are disclosed. That is the first point I make.

The second point I make—I think history from time immemorial shows this to be the case—is that we cannot legislate for honesty. It is just not possible. Those who are minded to be dishonest spend their lives getting around the rules, figuring out how not to do what they ought to do—in this case how to disguise a financial interest, if that is what they wanted to do, such that on the face of this register they would not have to disclose it. One would not need to be much more than a second year law student to figure out how to do it. That just makes a farce of this.

If we accept the proposition that we cannot legislate for honesty, that people who want to get around it will, we come back to the first point that I made that this is pretty useless. When people think they have some interest—I say interest there without adding the adjective `financial' because I want to come to that point—which ought to be disclosed we should rely on them to so disclose it.

Plenty of people have a variety of assets or relationships that are well known and they do not bother every time to get up and say, `I have this and I have that and they are inconsequential'. We rely on people to disclose a consequential interest. By and large, I think that happens. If there is a case recently where that has not happened it would have to be Mr Keating's piggery.

I take these things quite seriously. In 1987-88 I had responsibility in the shadow ministry for the status of women and, among other things, the Australian Capital Territory. Probably not many people know that a question came up as to whether we should agree that a casino be established here. At that time, my husband, not I, had some shares in a company—the name of which escapes me—which owned Federal Hotels, which had an obvious interest in whether or not Canberra should have a casino. At some substantial loss, about which I am constantly reminded by my husband, he sold the shares. The loss was in the thousands of dollars, so he still remembers it from 1988. We sold the shares because I did not want to be in the position of anyone being able to say, `Look, even though you are not in government, in opposition you can make a difference to these things, whether or not you agree, whether or not you create difficulty'. If a casino had gone through with our support and Federal Hotels had had the opportunity to run it, I would have been very uncomfortable. The sad thing was that only a couple of weeks after the shares were sold I was ditched from the shadow ministry and the decision was not mine anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who had the good sense to do that?

—Senator Faulkner interjects, `Who had the good sense to do that?'. I am sure that is on the public record and he can chase that up if he wants. He might question his own judgment in describing it as `good sense', but that is another matter. Basically, I regard that story as nobody's business, but I tell honourable senators that story simply to indicate that I take matters of conflict of interest very seriously. If people have a responsible position, they should make sure that they do not have a conflict. I think people should get out of the conflict rather than simply declaring it. I think declaring it is going halfway.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, there may be occasions when we could not be expected to dispose of a conflict of interest. For example, a family might come from a long line of families in the pastoral industry and they may be holding property which is run by a manager. When dealing with a bill which relates to, for example, disposal of wool, I do not think we could expect someone to dispose of that interest. That would clearly be ridiculous. I presume that no-one here would expect that. A declaration of that interest would be satisfactory.

I just raise the point of these shares in the company, whatever its name, that held Federal Hotels: where it is reasonable to dispose of the interest, it should be disposed of. I say `the interest'. I made the point before that it is not just financial interest. That is another thing which is wrong with these sorts of things: people do not only vote in accordance with their decision as to what is substantively the best way to go simply because of financial interest. Day after day I see people on the other side of the chamber who, because of factional arrangements, have worked out in what particular way they are going to vote. The party on the opposite side of the chamber does not give people the opportunity to vote according to their consciences in a way different from their party view. They all have to sit over there—I do not say like dummies. That is the course they have chosen: collective responsibility for a collective decision. But individually they are not entitled to vote in a different way, and I am.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't see you cross the floor very often!

—I have crossed the floor on a relevant occasion. When my conscience tells me to do so again, and by doing so I will put my endorsement at risk, I will say to the Liberal Party, `I know I wouldn't get here as an Independent, but this time I am not going to support you anyway because I can't; it's the wrong thing to do'. I have done it before and I will do it again quite happily.

PARA.TAB: I have said that those opposite vote for other reasons. There is a rumour—and I think it is widely accepted; no-one has challenged it with me—that some time ago a minister in this government had a relationship, shall we say, with a member of the gallery. Members of the gallery were hot-on annoyed about it; that is what they were telling us. They were putting the view—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't start that sort of stuff, Amanda.
—Perhaps Senator Faulkner could let me finish making the point I want to make before he decides—
—You're just being sleazy now.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, perhaps the Manager of Government Business in the Senate might like to let me make my point before he decides I am being sleazy. I am not mentioning anybody in particular and I have no intention of doing so. I am simply trying to make a point and I intend to continue doing so. I ask you to ask Senator Faulkner to either speak in this debate, if he has not done so yet—
—I have.
—In which case he has had his chance, so why does he not button up?
—I have spoken and I didn't smear anyone. You are smearing.

—I am not smearing anybody. Mr Acting Deputy President, if you think I am smearing someone, under the standing orders it is open to you to tell me to withdraw any remark I make. I am simply raising the point that, in general, there was this view, uncontested by anybody—in fact, I think, substantiated by Senator Faulkner's interjection—that there was a minister involved. I would not be smearing, would I, under his terminology, if there were no truth to it? Perhaps he could let me just continue and get out of this area.
—Go back into the gutter where you belong.
—Silly little boy.
—Go back into the gutter.
—Very silly little boy.
—You are a guttersnipe!

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Faulkner!

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to join the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Why would I go to the gutter and join his Prime Minister?
—You are a guttersnipe.
—Order! Senator Faulkner! Senator Vanstone, you have the call; please continue.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I was only remaining silent because I thought that remark was clearly within your earshot. Given that you are charged with the responsibility of keeping order in this place and given that you are not required to be reminded by a senator when something is unparliamentary, I thought you would take the opportunity to ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw.

—I thank you for pointing that out to me, Senator. Yesterday the matter of unparliamentary words was addressed in the chamber, and very stern rulings were given. An individual senator has asked the President to address that matter. I felt that it would be better at this time to remain silent, pending the President's issuing some instructions or rulings on the use of unparliamentary language in this place. In calling him to order, I have asked Senator Faulkner to restrain himself, and I continue to do so.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, if I have said anything unparliamentary, I withdraw.

—I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I thank the honourable senator for withdrawing. Senator Bolkus was required by ex-President McClelland to withdraw that remark; it clearly is regarded as unparliamentary. I look forward to whatever the President has to say about it. I would just make the point, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that standing order cannot be held in suspension forever and a day while the President decides what he would like to say.

PARA.TAB: Let us get to the point. We have just wasted a bit of time by intervention, and that is fine. I was talking about this well established, and now I think confirmed, rumour that a minister was having a relationship with someone in the press gallery. The members of the press gallery were very annoyed because somehow this person always had better stories about, and better access to, what was happening in that minister's portfolio. We, on this side, thought that minister was getting a better run in the media than the rest of the guys on the frontbench, and we did not think it was fair. All sorts of things can make a difference, including relationships. Because of relationships that do not need to be declared—not relationships between husbands and wives—people might make the same decision that this register suggests they would make if they or their wife had that financial interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I just think it is disgusting.
—Order! There is one speaker on the floor.

—One example about which Senator Faulkner seems to be so touchy is a classic reminder of how futile this register can be. There is no legislating for honesty. I notice that one amendment seeks to have the register include the interests of de facto spouses. I am interested to know whether people will want to amend that to include putative spouses. Why could we not include putative spouses? If any men have fathered children, we would like to know about the interests of the women by whom they have fathered their children. They are putative spouses. At law a woman is entitled to a portion of the assets of the father of her children. For the purposes of a legal distribution of assets, the woman is as entitled as a spouse or a de facto spouse. So what about putative spouses? Why do we not just cast this net forever and a day?

PARA.TAB: I support the view that members of the press gallery should have to declare their financial interests. I just point out that there are other interests, such as personal relationships, allegiances of factions and allegiances of friendships which are of no sexual nature whatsoever. Allegiances of friendships might occasion someone to not bother to cross the floor or to not bother to make the argument and run dead on a particular issue because one of that person's mates is owed a favour and wants this particular issue to go this way or that way. The point I make about people on the other side not being able to cross the floor only exemplifies, in their case, how pointless it is in some instances to disclose an interest. Even if the interest is disclosed, they are not entitled to vote differently on an issue anyway. So what are we worried about?

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you do logic at university?
—Senator Evans wants to know whether I did logic at university. I wonder whether he did.
—Order! It would serve you to ignore the interjections. Senator Vanstone has the call.
—What has this got to do with the subject?
—Senator Evans obviously thought it had something to do with the subject as he is interjecting and babbling away. Is he the one on duty to sit in here like a goose?

—Order! I have called for order. I have asked for interjections to cease. It would help if those interjections did cease. It would also help if Senator Vanstone attempted not to respond to the interjections. I again appeal for order.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am trying.
—I am trying to assist.

—I am grateful for your assistance on this very auspicious day, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will join with you later in a celebration. I am not embarrassed about declaring my interests. Senator Ian Macdonald said in another place that he would be a bit embarrassed about people knowing how little he owns. I am a bit embarrassed about people looking at the degree of liabilities that people might have. That is an interesting point. We have to disclose where the liabilities are but, as I understand it, not exactly how much they are. One has Buckley's of going to a bank and finding out what the degree of someone's indebtedness is. The hope is that, because people disclose that they have some sort of liability, it does not matter how big the liability is because their assets will reflect that. However, a simpleton's mind does not appreciate that their assets may well not reflect the reason for the debt at all and, therefore, not disclose what the genuine interest is.
—The piggery company has debts bigger than its assets.

—As Senator Macdonald reminds me, the piggery company has debts bigger than its assets. If we are going to do these sorts of things, we should attempt to do them properly. In any event, as I said, there is no legislating for honesty. If it is of any interest to people who may want to go ferreting around—and this is not at any shipping magnate level—my husband and I have shares in Fauldings, ANZ, Woolies, once it decided to go public to the extent that we could buy shares here, CRA, MIM and Boral.

PARA.TAB: I have got a very small unit in Parkside in Adelaide. I have a first mortgage over a portion of that unit, which I am reminded of every month when I look at the bank statement. I have got a unit at Kingston. Finally, I am pleased to say that Westpac does not have an interest in that after 10 years; it seemed interminable. My husband and I have interests in two properties in the south-east of South Australia. With one of them, if I were simply to comply with this form, those opposite would understand what the interest was because we have got one undivided fifth share of some land. Anyone who saw where that was—the south-east—would assume it had some rural association. We, as husband and wife, are partners in a pastoral company. The title is `such and such a pastoral company', so it is quite clear on the face of it what that interest is. The pastoral company owns the stock, plant and equipment.

The other property is owned through a different legal structure. A second- or third-year law student would be able to figure out ways to get around this register. That comes back to the original point, and the most important point I made, that one cannot legislate for people to be honest. That other property is owned in this way: shares in a company, which is itself a trustee of a unit trust, and holdings of units in the unit trust. People have got Buckley's of ascertaining what that interest is. I think that highlights just how futile this register is. The crucial point is that someone who wants to get around it will.

I would have to fill in quite a bit under liabilities. Apart from the first mortgage over the small property in Parkside in Adelaide, the other liabilities are all with Westpac. I would be happy to fill that in. I am somewhat concerned as well, especially for the women in parliament, about the nature of the financial relationships they have with their spouses and what impact this might have. It is a social fact of our culture that, by and large, women do not hold the assets. So for the men in parliament to have to declare what they know about the assets of their spouses does not really mean much because, by and large, the women in this country still do not hold the assets; that is just a cultural and social fact. I believe that, pleasantly, it is changing. But, nonetheless, more often than not it is the case in any family unit that where assets are held individually more are held by the husband than by the wife.

So, when we ask the women in parliament to disclose what they know about the interests of their spouses, necessarily they are being asked to disclose more. I would argue that what those opposite are doing is creating a disincentive for the male spouses to continue to enter into joint arrangements with their parliamentarian wives because the consequences necessarily are that that interest might need to be disclosed. It might not be an interest that can in any way be disguised and, for quite good and proper commercial reasons, the spouse might want them to be kept under wraps until a deal is finished, or whatever. One can easily foresee that happening if the assets of one's spouse change by nature of that person's interest and work and where that person is engaged in making a profit by virtue of exchanging large assets and turning them over regularly. This situation does create a difficulty. It does not create a difficulty for male spouses, but I think it potentially could create quite a significant difficulty for female spouses.

I have not heard all of the speeches. If there are any other Labor senators wanting to make a contribution, I would be interested to hear what they say as to how we deal with people who have decided not to be honest. In a sense, that is what the government wants to do here; it wants to make people be honest. I have an apprehension about that, because basically what it is saying is that it thinks there are lots of people here now who are not honest. I do not think that is so—even on the government side, or in the Greens or the Australian Democrats. I do not start from the premise that government people or my people or the Greens or the Democrats are in some way dishonest.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've lost this; why don't you just give it away?

—Senator Faulkner interjects that we have lost this public debate. We may well have, but that does not make the position wrong. It does cause concern for those who at any one time simply want to chase the public debate. But, if Senator Faulkner thinks the issue has been lost in the public arena, I would be upset about that and I would think it was a shame. I think it is a shame if members of the public happen to think—
—This is a very dishonest speech; you don't believe a word you're saying.

—Mr Acting Deputy President Herron, you may not have been listening before, but when the good senator opposite was in the chair Senator Faulkner kept interjecting. He just cannot help himself; he has to keep interjecting. I do not mind taking up all the time available to me if he wants to keep being the lunatic he is and interjecting. I am only trying to assist you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to have a bit more peace in this place.As I was saying, with this proposal the government starts from the premise that people are dishonest. I do not think that is true. I think there is the occasional dishonest person around.
—No-one claims that.

—Senator Evans says that no-one claims that. I wonder why the government wants it then. If all people are honest, if all people declare their interest, where it is relevant they will disclose their interest. This proposal allows them to hide their interest. We have seen that with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). We cannot legislate for honesty. Even if we could, this proposal does not do it. For that reason, I support the remarks of all of my colleagues.

—With the indulgence of the Senate, I will comment on the remarks made earlier today about me and the colour of the tie that I am wearing. This is my 25th St Patrick's Day in Australia, and I figured I did not need any longer to flaunt the colours of the nation of my birth. But I wish all people of Irish extraction and those with a love of Ireland a very merry and happy St Patrick's Day, and I hope tomorrow will be as easy as today.

PARA.TAB: We are debating a very important issue today. It is about the declaration of interests of senators, people who are elected to the parliament of Australia to represent the interests of the people of Australia. It is something that I personally believe is long overdue, although I would agree with some of the earlier speakers that the forms in which the declarations are made do need to have some work done on them. I am heartened to note that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), in moving this motion yesterday, indicated that the committee of senators' interests which is to be set up following the passage of this motion will look at that.

I have taken note of some of the comments made by previous speakers from the other side and I do believe there are areas where the form could be tightened up. I would hope that when the committee is established it will take note on a non-partisan basis of some of the comments that were made by speakers opposite—and, indeed, from this side.

Like my colleagues on this side of the chamber, I too completed the form on a voluntary basis—there was no compulsion to complete the form and to table it in the chamber. But I felt it was a great intrusion into the private affairs—not necessarily of myself because I did not have a problem with completing the form—of others who have no connection with this place.

For example, on the form that I completed and lodged—I have since amended that form, although I am not sure which one is in the possession of the people opposite who have a record of those forms—I had to state that I had an interest in the former family home that I occupied with my former wife. Clearly from that there is no conflict of interest in my part ownership or my former wife's part ownership of that home with anything that will be debated in this chamber. From Jean's point of view, it is an intrusion into her affairs. Certainly, I should be in a position to make declarations of that nature, but I do not see why a former spouse with a financial interest with the other former spouse should be subject to the sort of public scrutiny which we volunteered for on the last occasion.

Senator Vanstone said that it could be carried on even further—she spoke about putative spouses. Again, that is something that a committee on senators' interests ought to look at in the future with a view to tightening it up somewhat.

Much was made during the debate of certain financial interests held by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I do not think there is a need to say very much more; it is on the record—page after page of Hansard. In fact, some of the comments are also of interest to one of our courts in Australia, but I will not say any more about that. The form, though, does need to be tightened up. It does not cover the situation where an honourable senator might seek to present his or her views through the newspapers of this country using an assumed name.

We might say that that would never happen in a place such as this with 76 senators elected to represent the people. But, unfortunately, it has happened in the past. One of our senators made contributions to the newspapers of this country under a pseudonym. That was not entirely honest but it again addresses, and is linked with, some of the matters about which Senator Vanstone spoke.

Senator Vanstone went on at some length about when she was on the front bench in 1989, I think it was. At that time her husband had an interest in a hotel chain that was bidding for the casino licence in Canberra. Her husband lost some money because the shares were disposed of—an honourable thing to do. I do not think the form, in its current form, would compel any individual in a similar circumstance to that of Senator Vanstone to do something similar in the future—to sell shares or interests in a company and make a loss on it. Senator Vanstone is to be commended for doing what she did at the time. I wonder how many of her colleagues on the opposition front bench are following the example.

A few days ago in the other place, the Prime Minister drew attention to the fact that there was one opposition spokesperson with an interest in the financial affairs of this country who had substantial shareholdings in one of our major banks. That is something that ought to be declared on a senator's interests form so that the Australian public could be aware that what the shadow spokesperson was saying may have been in conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —This requirement is not to that effect.

—That is exactly the point that I am addressing. The form as currently structured needs some work. But it is an excellent start. Following the passage of the motion, the committee that is then set up will be able to address those matters, and that is what I am directing my comments to.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister also drew attention to the fact that another opposition spokesperson is involved with a legal company which sells advice to its clients—quite a legitimate occurrence. Unfortunately—and I am certainly not pointing the finger—there might be a conflict of interest in that that particular individual, who was named in the other place but will not be named by me, is the shadow spokesperson for industrial relations. There is a potential conflict of interest there. I think that the form needs some degree of work. The comments made by Senator Vanstone about a supposed affair between a minister a certain member of the press gallery were unfortunate. Certainly, names were not mentioned, but those comments were very unfortunate.

TALK.START.PARA: —No names were mentioned.

—No names were mentioned at all, thankfully. I think certain standards prevail in the parliament of Australia, as distinct from Britain. We would all have recognised the damage done to a number of senior public figures in Britain in very recent times. We would all recognise and applaud the fact that the types of allegations and insinuations that are made in the United States about individuals do not happen here. I certainly hope that arguments such as those used by Senator Vanstone are not repeated in this chamber or in the other place in order to score political points. I do not think anybody will benefit from that type of character assassination—even though names were not mentioned. There are some people—enemies; we all have them—in places right around Australia who would seek to damage an individual's career. In doing that, they forget that all individuals have family members who, in turn, are also damaged.

PARA.TAB: I hope that what we have heard here this morning will not be repeated. I do not, in any way, condemn Senator Vanstone for raising the matter. She is quite at liberty to do so, but I hope that nobody on either side of the chamber, from whatever political party or independent group, will see that as a lead and follow it through in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate relates to a proposal to keep a registration of senators' interests. This proposal, put forward by the government, was first moved by Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in this chamber, but has been amended by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Manager of Government Business here, Senator Faulkner, to allow a committee to be set up to oversee the matter. The motion is opposed by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately and thankfully, Australia is a democracy. We are debating here fundamentally the right of citizens in this country to know the interests, including the financial interests, of members of parliament. The electors in this country know the financial interests of members of the House of Representatives. People know them because a register of interests is kept in which all members of the House of Representatives lodge a return stating what their interests are. That register is open for public inspection. Members of the opposition can inspect the financial interests of members of the government and members of the government have access to the financial interests of members of the opposition.

There is scrutiny. If there is believed to be a conflict in ministers defending their private financial interests rather than taking on their public duty, they are exposed. That exposure can be publicly ventilated and the public can then make a judgment about those individuals. The same is true of the opposition. If the activities of opposition members is such that their actions are seen to serve their private financial interests and not their public duty, they can be exposed by virtue of the existence of this registration. The public can then form a judgment about those people as elected representatives.

This motion comes forward in the Senate because there is no such registration of senators' interests. There is no such registration because it has been resisted consistently by the opposition in this chamber. That raises a question of motive. Why would an opposition, in a democracy, resist the registration of the financial interests of members of this chamber so that they can be open for public inspection and their actions can be judged either against—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The standing orders provide that a senator shall not speak twice in a debate unless he is speaking to an amendment. Senator Cook is clearly not speaking to the amendment moved by Senator Baume; Senator Cook is speaking to the substantive motion. Senator Cook has already spoken to the substantive motion once. I do not think this contribution is adding anything to the fairly lightweight contribution we heard last time. Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that you ask Senator Cook to direct himself to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Baume. If he does that, we are quite happy to sit here and listen to what he has to say.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator O'Chee is showing his ignorance yet again. A new motion is before the chair. It was moved yesterday by Senator Faulkner. Senator Cook is entitled to speak to the motion.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—The motion was debated earlier. We are debating the amendment. I understood that Senator Cook's remarks in the debate related to the amendment. There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I would like some guidance in this matter.
—You can't. You have to raise a new point of order.

—I think I will let the Acting Deputy President answer me on that point. I disagree with Senator McKiernan that it is a new motion. I started in continuation from, roughly, August last year. How can it be a new motion? Otherwise the chamber owes me another 17 minutes.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. If I can help, on Thursday 19 August 1993 Senator Gareth Evans moved the motion, which is recorded on page 275 of the Senate Hansard.
—Thank you, Senator Macdonald. I have already ruled on Senator O'Chee's point of order. There is no point of order in relation to Senator Cook; I believe he is relating his remarks to the amendment.

—It is true that I am relating my remarks to the amendment. I was three minutes into an address in which I have 30 minutes to speak and I was making the threshold points about what this issue concerns. It is only with a knowledge and an understanding of the background of this issue that we can understand the amendment. I am not at all surprised that there should be an attempt to gag me; it is absolutely consistent with the attempt made by opposition senators to defeat the government's motion so they do not have to disclose their financial interests.

PARA.TAB: I return to the theme that I was warming to: the essential issue of public concern about this matter. The essential issue is that electors in this country, as in any democracy, are entitled to know what the financial interests of their elected representatives are so that they can judge whether those elected representatives serve their private financial interests in public office or do their duty by the country and the electors. I was making the point that there is, by dint of a government majority, such as a register in the House of Representatives, which is open for anyone to inspect. Anyone from the press gallery, anyone from the opposition or the government, and anyone from the public—any elector of an electorate—can inspect the financial interests of members. There is not such a register in the Senate, and that is because the opposition has consistently defeated the government's move to establish one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am still confused. I would like you to tell the chamber, if you can, what amendment Senator Cook is speaking to. As you pointed out yourself, as Senator Cook spoke in the first round of debate he can speak only on an amendment. The only amendment I can see is on page 4 of today's Notice Paper, the amendment moved by Senator Baume about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) filing a grossly misleading declaration of interest. That is the only amendment, as far as I am concerned, in front of this chamber. Can you rule on the point of order and get the minister to be relevant in his remarks.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: every time I set out the issues in this debate I have a point of order taken against me. You have ruled, as you did a minute ago, that the point of order does not stand. You gave me leave to continue my remarks. A consistent taking of the same point of order upon which you have ruled amounts not to a point of order but to an attempt to disrupt the speech that I am making. I suggest, Mr Acting Deputy President, you make that point to Senator Panizza and also allow me to address the amendment in my own way and put the issues about this amendment and this motion in their proper context.
—Yes, there is no point of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Ian Macdonald

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take another point of order. I will just read out the amendment so that when Senator Cook speaks you can determine whether he is being relevant to the amendment. The amendment says:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . but the Senate condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for filing a grossly misleading declaration of interests, and calls on him to table in the Parliament a full and proper account of his beneficial ownership of substantial assets and liabilities in order for the public to be able to judge the extent of his potential conflicts of interest.

Senator Cook spoke for half an hour the first time round. He should not be permitted to speak on the same subject for another half hour. If he wants to speak about Mr Keating filing a grossly misleading declaration of interests then that is part of the debate on the amendment. But he should not be permitted to have another half hour—guillotined time, I might add—because it stops us from being allowed to speak, and I guess that is what Senator Cook is all about. He is taking up another half hour of very limited time to rehash the arguments. He must confine himself, as a matter of relevance, to the amendment before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this new point of order: I am not trying to unnecessarily take up the time of the chamber, and I will conclude my remarks expeditiously if I am allowed to make them. They are relevant to the motion. But I make the point that any junior person with a nodding acquaintance of the rules of the debate would make, and that is: the amendment is an amendment to a substantive motion, and the terms of an amendment to a substantive motion cannot be considered without considering how it would change that motion and the effect on the motion. Therefore, it is entirely relevant to talk about both the motion and the amendment because we are being asked to vote on whether we support that amendment or whether we do not support it but support the substantive motion. We cannot just talk about one; we have to talk about both in order to have a proper, sensible and intelligent debate. I admit that proper, sensible and intelligent debate is a stranger to the opposition.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, we have certainly had a very strange contribution from Senator Cook—a very convoluted argument dealing with what he wanted to talk about, not the matter before the chamber at the present time. I have not spoken in the debate on either the principal motion or the amendment, and I wish to speak briefly on it.

PARA.TAB: I was prompted particularly by the remarks of Senator Cook, which I heard just now in my office, that members of the public were entitled to know the financial affairs of their elected members, and that that was part of a good functioning democracy. That happens to be a fairly new approach, or a new addition, to the democratic process, and I do not argue with it. I have no quarrel with disclosing it if in fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid, you are entering into debate and we are discussing a point of order in relation to relevance.
—I thought the minister had finished and sat down.
—No, I was waiting on a ruling.
—I thought, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you had ruled on it.
—I have not. We are still on the point of order. Will you confine your remarks then to the point of order?
—I confine my remarks to the point of order. Senator Cook should be speaking to the amendment before the chair, particularly as he has already spoken to the motion. I reject his reasons.
—It is not my place to pre-empt or to know what Senator Cook is about to say. I believe that he was addressing the amendment—a matter which we have determined. There is no point of order.
—I will now make my third effort to address this amendment.
—The first two have been pathetic.

—The first two have made the point that consistently in this place the opposition has voted down motions by the government to establish a register of senators' interests open for inspection by the electors of the Commonwealth, the press gallery, and other members, in order to ascertain whether people in public office are conducting themselves in the public interest or in the interests of their own financial commitments.

PARA.TAB: The amendment moved by Senator Baume is aimed at the Prime Minister (Mr Keating); it is an amendment which alleges certain things of the Prime Minister, which are not true. On that basis alone the amendment should fail. But it should fail on a wider basis too. It should fail on the basis that the Prime Minister has declared his interests on the public record; they are open for inspection. His interests, as far as his part shareholding in a piggery is concerned, are a matter of public notoriety—they are a matter of public debate. They have been the subject of a smear campaign against the Prime Minister, which is continuing. It is a smear campaign judged not by the government—although we are, of course, annoyed by it—but by the independent commentators in the press gallery who have followed the intricacies of the smear as to have no substance whatsoever.

The smear campaign continues on the well-known principle that if enough dirt is thrown some of it might stick, or on the Goebbels principle that if a big lie is repeated some people might believe it—repetition being the key element in effective propaganda. We have an attempt at repetition as a tool of propaganda by virtue of the motion moved by Senator Baume. It repeats essentially the big lie idea that something here is wrong when it is not. This is an amendment which, as I said, should fail on the grounds that it is not true. It is also an amendment which should fail on the grounds of the principle at issue here. The Prime Minister has declared his interests publicly. Senator Baume has not declared his interests publicly. He hides behind the vote of the opposition, resisting the agreement of this chamber to impose on all its members an open declaration of their pecuniary interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are misleading the Senate. When have we voted on it?
—I am not misleading the Senate. The opposition has voted consistently against it on several occasions.
—Name them!

—If Senator Macdonald wants me to go through them chapter and verse I am quite happy to. I understand that Senator Reid wants me to curtail my remarks so she can speak within the time of the guillotine but, if Senator Macdonald wants me to bat out the time, I will do it.

PARA.TAB: I return to the central point: the opposition has voted down the idea of a register of pecuniary interests, hiding behind the allegation that it does not go far enough and it is not complete enough. If ever there were a logical fallacy, the fallacy would be, `We will not adopt a measure which is in the public interest, which is fundamental to democracy and which is a right of the citizens of this country to know, simply because we are unhappy with the regulations and terms of the register'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I heard Senator Cook say that the opposition voted this down. I would like him to tell us when it was voted down because I cannot find it in the Journals of the Senate.
—There is no point of order.

—The point is that the excuse for not voting for the proposition has always been that it does not go far enough. This is an opportunity for the opposition—if it believed in the principle—to voluntarily declare its interests. It is open to Senator Macdonald to voluntary declare his pecuniary interests if he agrees in the basic principle of the electors' right to know what his pecuniary interests are.

PARA.TAB: I have some right to make that statement because my pecuniary interests are declared. They are on the public record and are open for inspection. I hide behind absolutely nothing—it is all open and able to be seen. That is right and appropriate and I expect no particular kudos because it is the duty of a senator to do that. It is Senator Macdonald's obligation, if he is to have any standing at all in this debate, to declare his pecuniary interests.

Before he starts moving down the road of promulgating the smear against the Prime Minister, he should let us see his pecuniary interests. The Prime Minister's are on open display; Senator Macdonald's are not. Let us see the pecuniary interests of all members of the opposition. Let us conduct this debate from a basis of all of us being equal—not some having their rightful duties properly explained and exposed and others hiding behind an ability to muster a vote to deflect interest. Why Senator Macdonald does not declare his pecuniary interests is the fundamental question hovering over his case.

I now go to the terms of what Senator Baume has said. Senator Baume has made a series of allegations in his amendment which are basically untrue, but he continues to make them. Not only is the opposition engaging in hypocrisy here, for the reasons that I have just stated, but also the motion is offensive and should be turned out because the allegations made in it are not true. It is a continuing attempt to smear the Prime Minister.

I would have thought that since the Fremantle by-election there would have been an understanding in the opposition that the politics of the low blow, the politics of the personal smear, the politics of the denigration of individuals and the destruction of their reputations were not politics the Australian electorate particularly applauds. They see that as the worst feature of politics. They resent it, they reject it and they do not like it. Certainly the people have a right to and do expect that duplicity and hypocrisy be exposed. This continuing smearing of politicians simply reduces the reputation of politicians as a whole and demeans the reputation and standing of the parliament.

Australians expect better of their elected representatives than that. Australians expect that at least when we come to this place we will debate substantial issues like the nature of the economy, the question of unemployment, the future of our foreign relations and the place of Australia in the world. They are the issues they expect to be debated. I would have thought that the opposition would have learnt that when Australians do vote they want to vote for an expectation that things will get better for them.

The opposition has not learnt that. The opposition is still here trying to denigrate, destroy personalities, destroy reputations and engage in bitter infighting. This amendment is simply yet another weary, tired step along that road and the whole thing should be rejected on the basis that it is totally out of court, totally improper, totally untrue and another effort at smearing and reputation destroying.

I conclude by saying what I said at the beginning. The Australian community has a right to know what the pecuniary interests of all elected members of parliament are. In the case of the Senate they do not. That is not because of what the government wants. The government has tried to move this and has not succeeded in getting it carried in this chamber. Members of the opposition have voted down, deferred or deflected our motion to get a register because they obviously do not want to have to put on the public record their pecuniary interests. Mine are on the public record. Those of all members of the House of Representatives are on the public record. We are prepared to put ours on the public record.

Those opposite cannot engage in a smear campaign against those who are on the public record unless they are prepared at least to do the same. Then we will all operate from a position of equality in this debate. Then truth will out, honesty will tell and, if they are engaging in a campaign simply of smear which is dishonest and untrue, they will be revealed for the hypocrites and charlatans that they genuinely and really are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: I think `charlatans' is unparliamentary and the minister should be asked to withdraw it.
—Senator Cook, I think that definition and description was unhelpful. I would be grateful if you would withdraw.

—I used the words `charlatans' and `hypocrites' generically to describe the opposition. That is not outside of standing orders. I appreciate your request, but I think in these circumstances it is an appropriate description. I would prefer the words to stand, with the greatest of respect to you, Mr Deputy President.

—Having asked you, I would be grateful if you would withdraw because in my view it was unhelpful and disorderly. You used the word `hypocrites' and you were referring particularly in this sense to those clearly sitting on the other side. I would be grateful, in the interest of the Senate, if you would withdraw.
—I did so unaware that they were unparliamentary and, because you have requested me, Mr Deputy President, in respect to you and your office, I withdraw.

—We have certainly had an incredible contribution from Senator Cook this morning, ranging over a wide number of topics. When I intervened, thinking he had sat down or perhaps even hoping he had sat down but finding it was part of a point of order, I did hear him say that the electorate was entitled to know the financial circumstances of their elected members and I do not disagree with that. He also alleged—he shouted it—that we had voted down this motion a number of times, giving perhaps some substance to his suggestion that if you shout it long enough and loud enough it will become true; but I do not think that one will become true.

PARA.TAB: What he has done by his contribution this morning is confirm the view we have taken in relation to this matter that it is meaningless in its present form. The figures, facts, papers, documents and things arising from the personal affairs of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have proved that to be the case. There may be others, similarly, that have not been looked at in such great detail.

People can have trusts, private companies, proprietary companies and things of that nature. Even Senator Cook, if he looked at these things, would have to admit that that list does not provide a meaningful description of the assets of a particular person. My assets, when they are given, will show my exact position because I do not have any private companies, any trusts or any of these other devices which enable people to appear to disclose their financial situation but not do so—or not do so meaningfully. That will become very apparent.

For Senator Cook to go on in the way that he did—I would almost say that he was ranting and raving, but I would not be so rude to a minister—polishing his own halo and saying how self-righteous he is for having disclosed his assets, is not in any way a reasonable contribution to what is expected in this debate and what the government thinks it is trying to do. The government is trying to get bits of paper on the public record so that it can say that there is disclosure of members' and senators' interests. But, having looked through them, it is very clear that there is no disclosure of members' and senators' interests for a large number of people; the disclosure is quite meaningless.

Looking through the lists that the government has voluntarily put forward, I defy anyone to know whether people may be insolvent. They easily could be, but there is no information there that would tell us that. I think the amendment put forward by Senator Baume certainly focuses on one particular member of parliament but it highlights the meaninglessness of this whole exercise. It is merely some form of window-dressing.

The thing which I dislike most about this motion, and which I do not believe the government has explained adequately, nor can it explain adequately, is that it expects information to be disclosed about, in my case, my husband, and the government expects others to disclose information about their wives. How can the government expect this in a modern day and age, when it has been promoting affirmative action, equal rights and privacy? Yesterday I think it was Senator Cook who was going through the bill of rights and all these things that the government would like to have.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it was not me.

—One of the chattering parrots on the front bench on the other side was certainly talking about a bill of rights, the rights of people and their privacy. We hear it all the time. The government expects members and senators to disclose information about their wives or husbands or their de facto wives or husbands. I think it is outrageous to be doing this in 1994. I shall not be doing that because I think it is offensive.

PARA.TAB: My husband is entitled to his privacy. People who know him know that he is a retired Commonwealth public servant and they could easily find out what Commonwealth pension he receives as a consequence of that employment. The mere idea of suggesting that a spouse is a chattel whose personal financial situation can be disclosed by another person flies in the face of what I think is reasonable in this day and age of the rights of people to be individuals and have their own arrangements for their own lives and their own financial affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about those people who put their affairs in the hands of their spouse in order to evade disclosure? What do you say about that?

—I know of nobody who is putting assets in the name of a spouse to hide disclosure. If Senator Cook knows that to be the case, then he can disclose it. I am telling him that I have not done that; I am not likely to be doing it. I find it offensive that Senator Cook is telling me that I should disclose to the public whatever affairs—I had better withdraw that word, because he is not inclined to that sort of thing—or financial arrangements my husband may have. I am not sure that I even know all his financial situation, and I certainly would not ask him. I regard it as absolutely outrageous and an invasion of privacy.

PARA.TAB: If we had meaningful disclosure—if the documents were meaningful—it would probably throw up that assets had been transferred from one person to another, and that is a different issue altogether. But that has not been done. This is being pursued by the invasion of privacy of the husband or wife of a member or senator in this place. That is something that ought not to be done. I would not vote to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Baume, and I also take the opportunity to foreshadow amendments which I have circulated and which I do not think I can strictly move until the amendment of Senator Baume is disposed of.
