Senator Baume's amendment goes to the heart of this matter, because it is based on the fact that the disclosure that has been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his statement in the other place is not only misleading but also gives insufficient information upon which any member of the public could make an assessment as to whether there is a conflict of interest, or a potential conflict of interest, between the Prime Minister's personal business interests and his public responsibility.

PARA.TAB: That is why Senator Baume has moved his amendment which is—and I remind the Senate, as it was some time ago that it was moved—to add at the end of the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . "but the Senate condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for filing a grossly misleading declaration of interests, and calls on him to table in the parliament a full and proper account of his beneficial ownership of substantial assets and liabilities in order for the public to be able to judge the extent of his potential conflicts of interest".

It will be interesting to see how the Labor Party and the minority parties in this place vote on that amendment, because, if they do not support it, what it really means is that they endorse a disclosure regime which is ineffective. By doing that they therefore endorse a regime that in effect misleads the public, because it gives the public a false confidence that there is sufficient information on the register for them to be able to make that judgment as to whether there is a conflict of interest. And it is simply not so.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume's amendment states that the statement of the Prime Minister is misleading. What did the Prime Minister say? On 7 June 1991 he wrote to the Clerk of the House of Representatives in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I advise that on 15 May 1991 my family company, Pleuron Pty Ltd and I made an investment by way of acquisition of shares in Euphron Pty Ltd, a company which has interests in a piggery and a refrigeration fabrication business. The interests acquired by both Pleuron Pty Ltd and me in Euphron Pty Ltd do not constitute a controlling interest in that company, nor do I or any member of my family hold a directorship of that company.
His letter therefore stated, as I just quoted, that Euphron has interests in a piggery.

PARA.TAB: That implies, I would suggest, that there are other shareholders. In fact, as I understand it, Euphron was the sole beneficial owner of the piggery.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely right.

—So if that is right, then this statement by the Prime Minister is misleading, and this Senate should recognise that it is misleading. Also, in terms of it being insufficient, it gives no indication of the indebtedness of that company, particularly indebtedness to the Commonwealth Bank which, it has been suggested, at that time was something just under $18 million.

PARA.TAB: So we have a situation where the Treasurer who, at the time of the purchase, was responsible for the Commonwealth Bank, was purchasing a company very significantly indebted to that bank. Was that apparent from the statement that he had tabled in the House of Representatives? No. But without that knowledge the public is not in a position to determine whether or not there is a potential conflict of interest.

He also failed to reveal that the companies were also indebted to Mr John Brown, a former minister, to the tune of millions of dollars. What we have here is Mr Brown who now acts as a lobbyist, and a Prime Minister who has interests in a company indebted to Mr Brown. I would have thought that that presents obvious conflicts of interest, but that information—that indebtedness to Mr Brown—is not included in the statements lodged by Mr Keating in the other place. What one has to do is search through the various company records to ascertain that information. The minister will say that we would get a hint, because once we were given the company name we would be able to conduct those searches. The point is that members of the public are supposed to have confidence that the register is sufficient in itself for them to be able to see whether there is a potential conflict of interest. It is simply not so.

The Prime Minister's further indebtedness through his companies to what we understand is the Commonwealth Bank could be anything up to $30 million. As to issues of personal guarantees, is the Prime Minister personally liable for that debt?

TALK.START.PARA: —Some debts to foreign interests.

—There is also the issue of the interests of foreigners in the company and potential areas of conflict of interest with quarantine matters and so on, but none of that is apparent from the statement lodged by the Prime Minister in the other place. The Prime Minister's example demonstrates the ineffectiveness of the regime that this government is seeking to set up, and the false confidence it raises in the community.

PARA.TAB: That is why Senator Baume has moved this amendment. It will give the Senate the opportunity to criticise the Prime Minister for the misleading aspects of his own statement but, perhaps even more importantly, require of him to disclose sufficient information for the public to make a real assessment as to the extent of actual or potential conflicts of interest. I trust that the Senate will support the motion and send a clear message to the Prime Minister that a disclosure regime which is just a sham is insufficient, and that if he seeks to impose it upon the parliament through his will, then he should be prepared to disclose in a meaningful form which achieves the objective which he is claiming of this scheme but which is clearly not achieved by the scheme as it is presented today to the Senate.

There is some confusion. We actually support disclosure, and that is why one of our foreshadowed amendments specifically requires senators in debate to disclose interests that might amount to a conflict of interest, and to disclose on a vote in this place. They will make that judgement in each and every circumstance, and each and every circumstance will differ, demonstrating the shortcoming of trying to codify this in the way the government has done—taking the lowest common denominator, and, in effect, ending up with a form that provides the public with no real information and basis for confidence in the system. The system as it is, is ineffective, and that is one of the two major reasons why we have expressed objection to what the government is doing.
The other major reason is the one stressed by Senator Reid and that is the intrusion into matters of genuine privacy of spouses and

SPEECH.PARA: families. We still have to be convinced that that intrusion into the privacy of those other than members of parliament is warranted. I concede that there has been some improvement in the wording, but it is only a nominal improvement—the disclosure is now only of interests of which the senator is aware. It still does not address the fundamental question that those who happen to be married to us, or our children, are now going to have their affairs disclosed in circumstances to which they may well object. If the senator does not comply with that under the terms of this regime, the senator, himself or herself, commits a serious contempt of the Senate. We retain those reservations and concerns about this intrusion into the private affairs of spouses and families.

PARA.TAB: I have mentioned one of the amendments that I intend to move after Senator Baume's amendment has been dealt with. The other amendments, which I will run through, have been circulated in the chamber. The first one is that we think it is not appropriate that the committee of senators' interests, which will have the responsibility of overseeing the register, is an appropriate committee to also conduct investigations. We believe that, if investigations of alleged breaches are necessary, they should be conducted by a separate body; we suggest the privileges committee, and I will move an amendment to that effect.

We also seek to increase the figure in relation to a declaration regarding sponsored travel or hospitality to something that is more realistic, and we propose to increase it to $500. Similarly, we say that gifts that are made should be disclosed, if they are going to be disclosed, when they amount to something in excess of $500. We think that the current figure of $100 is ridiculously low.

My fourth amendment is to ensure that the disclosure regime is limited to pecuniary interests. There may well be interests which raise issues of moral conflict, religious beliefs and so forth. As it is at the moment, it is ambiguous. I do not think it was ever intended that that type of interest was to be covered. Therefore, the fourth amendment I propose to move will restrict it to pecuniary interests, which I think is in accordance with the government's objective in any event.

My fifth amendment is the one that I mentioned a little while ago, specifically requiring senators to make declarations at the beginning of a speech and also after a division. I understand, from what the minister told me yesterday, the government will support that, and I am pleased it has come to the party on that and recognises that that is important. My sixth amendment is to define `spouses' to include `de facto spouses'. I will move those amendments after the vote on Senator Baume's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the amendments moved by Senator Hill and Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—You have already spoken to the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I disagree with that. I cannot remember speaking. I spoke in the debate on the general motion moved by Senator Gareth Evans, and I was in continuation from last time. I have not spoken to the amendment.
—You have spoken after Senator Baume moved the amendment.
—On a point of clarification: that would have been the same as when I raised a point of order to sit Senator Cook down.
—You spoke after the amendment was moved, so you have spoken to the amendment.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, can I speak to Senator Hill's amendments? He has only just moved them.
—Senator Hill has not moved them; he foreshadowed his amendments. So you are not entitled to speak.

—Much has been said today and yesterday about the futility of this whole debate. Senator Baume's amendment that the disclosure form should be completed properly if it is going to be completed at all should be taken into account. I have been sitting here for the last 15 minutes or so glancing through these much touted declarations of senators' interests that were put in voluntarily by the Labor Party last year. The President of the Senate, Senator Beahan, put in one last year. While most pages remain blank—other than a few little contributions—the back page, where it requests the membership of any organisation, clearly shows that he is not even a member of the Labor Party.
—Who is that?

—Senator Beahan. Therefore, the President of the Senate is not even a member of the Labor party. But worse than that, the form is unsigned; the whole thing is unsigned. If we are going to get down to the nitty-gritty of this whole exercise, surely someone who professes to be the caretaker of the entire operation of the Senate should be able to fill out a form correctly. It begs the question: how many others have left out critical pieces of information and hope not to be caught? Presumably Senator Beahan is a member of the Labor Party and could well be a member of other organisations. But he did not see fit to fill out the form completely and nor did he see fit to sign it. The Labor Party cannot trumpet this system as being the be-all and end-all in getting everyone to confess everything when they, voluntarily, have not completed these forms properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In winding up this debate, I will not seek to track over all the substantive issues that have been raised on both sides of the debate. I think the issues have been very well canvassed. I simply acknowledge the reality that any system of pecuniary interests registration that we adopt is bound to represent some kind of balance between the public interest in disclosure on the one hand and legitimate claims to privacy on the other. There will always be arguments as to whether the balance has been sufficiently struck one way or the other.

PARA.TAB: Most of the contribution we have heard from the opposition side has not been so much directed against the principle of pecuniary interest disclosure, but rather against the alleged inadequacies of the present scheme. I can understand a number of those points. The answer that I would make to that is that those on the opposition side who think that they can design better forms or an approach to this in terms of the actual presentation of data better than the form now proposed will have an opportunity, through their participation in the committee on senators' interests, to have an ongoing input into this process as it evolves over the years ahead. We have quite an open mind as to how best to advance the cause here when it comes to the actual detail—consistently, of course, with the terms of this motion—and we will be happy to respond to and discuss suggestions of a detailed kind that might be made to make the system work better.

Where we do not have an open mind—where we have a thoroughly closed mind—is on the virtues of this particular system being put in place. It is just unconscionable that we have sat here in the Senate since 1986 while the House of Representatives has had its system in place. It is unconscionable that it has taken us something like 11 or 12 hours of debate spread over seven or eight different occasions in those intervening years to finally get to the point that we will get to in the next few minutes of a vote on this matter. It is quite intolerable in terms of any basic commitment to democratic accountability principles that that should be so. It has nothing to do with the management of this place. It has everything to do with filibustering and squirming by the opposition.

Let me take the remaining few minutes available to me to indicate briefly what the government's position is on the amendments that have either been moved or foreshadowed by the opposition. Senator Baume's general amendment to the principal motion is typical of the sort of offensive, opportunistic, point-scoring stunt that we have come to expect from Senator Baume. I do not propose to say anything further whatsoever on that subject. We will vote accordingly and I would urge the Senate to do so.

When it comes to the substantive amendments that have been foreshadowed by the opposition, our response is as follows: as to the first amendment, going to a reference to the Standing Committee of Privileges to determine whether a contempt has been committed, that amendment is acceptable and we will vote accordingly. As to the second proposed amendment, to set a threshold on declarable sponsored travel or hospitality, we initially preferred to set no limit at all on what was disclosable there. We think the threshold figure of $500 that the opposition is proposing is too high. The Australian Democrats have proposed their own further amendment to make that threshold $200, and we would be prepared to accept the Democrats'—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is eternal compromise.

—This is democracy at work. We would rather accept the Democrats' amendment than the opposition one. As to the third amendment, raising the limit on declarable financial contributions to organisations from $100 to $500, we do not think that that should be accepted and we will vote accordingly. We want to stick to the lower limit.

PARA.TAB: As to the fourth amendment about limiting the requirement to declare any other interest where a senator's public duties could arise to pecuniary interests only, we think that is excessively narrowing and limiting. We would not wish to limit it in that way. There may well be other non-pecuniary interests which could conceivably give rise to conflict of interest and be against the public interest as a result. We believe the system will be better for allowing such interest to be declared.

As to the requirement for honourable senators to declare their interests in the course of debate, this is an amendment which we readily accept. I was always puzzled about why it was taken out of the system as applied in the House of Representatives. I am advised that the House of Representatives removed it from its system in 1988 on the recommendation of its own Committee of Members' Interests with the support of not only the government but also the opposition. It was a bipartisan recommendation that came up to remove that particular requirement.

The committee apparently felt that the requirement was so broad it was probably being honoured more regularly in the breach than in the observance, and that it was largely made redundant by the register. Personally, I do not agree with that. I think it is appropriate that interests that conspicuously involve a potential conflict of interest ought to be disclosed at the time that people get to their feet in the chamber. That is the traditional Westminster practice. If we have not been honouring it in the observance as much as we should have in practice in the past I think we should honour it in the future, and maybe this will draw that to people's attention to accept it in this way.

As to the final amendment on definition of spouse and de facto spouse, what is basically involved here is putting on the register—not only because of the way the definitions are here drawn—not only immediate family but also extending the obligation to declare interests on the register to those people who are recipients of travel privileges under the present scheme whereby people in appropriate circumstances can nominate a mother, sister or some other person, maybe not a relative at all, to be the recipient of the travel privilege. That is a system that has evolved to cope with particular personal circumstances that vary from individual to individual. It has been a good system in that context. There is no problem about it. But to take the further step of requiring people who satisfy that criterion to be on the pecuniary interest register generally seems to us to be a case of overkill. Accordingly, we will vote against that. Rather than having to get to my feet again when it comes to the business of the other remaining debate on the composition of the committee, I will indicate in 30 seconds what our attitude to those amendments will be when they are moved by the opposition. We do not oppose the first amendment that has been circulated about removing from the committee any responsibilities regarding a code of conduct. This responsibility could well be given to another appropriate body when a code of conduct is considered in due course. As to the other two amendments, we do not think that they are appropriate and we will oppose them. (Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! The time for debate on the register of senators' interests has also expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall put separate questions on each amendment. The question is that amendment No. 1 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the standing orders be amended by adopting the following new standing order—

SPEECH.PARA: 22A. (1)A Committee of Senators' Interests shall be appointed at the commencement of each Parliament:

TAB.TAB: (a)to inquire into and report upon the arrangements made for the compilation, maintenance and accessibility of a Register of Senators' Interests;
(b)to consider any proposals made by Senators and others as to the form and content of the Register;
(c)to consider any submissions made in relation to the registering or declaring of interests;
(d)to consider what changes to any Code of Conduct adopted by the Senate are necessary or desirable;
(e)to consider what classes of person, if any, other than Senators ought to be required to register and declare their interests; and
(f)to make recommendations upon these and any other matters which are relevant.

PARA.TAB: (2)(a)The Committee shall consist of 6 Senators, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and one nominated by any minority groups or independent Senators.

TAB.TAB: (b)The nominations of the minority groups or independent Senators shall be determined by agreement between the minority groups and independent Senators, and, in the absence of agreement duly notified to the President, the question of the representation on the Committee shall be determined by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: (3)The Committee shall elect as Chairman one of the Senators nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
(4)The quorum of the Committee shall be 3 members.

(5)The Chairman may from time to time appoint a member of the Committee to be Deputy Chairman, and the member so appointed shall act as Chairman of the Committee when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6)Where votes on a question before the Committee are equally divided, the Chairman, or the Deputy Chairman when acting as Chairman, shall have a casting vote.

(7)The Committee shall have power to send for persons or documents, but shall not exercise that power, nor undertake an investigation of the private interests of any person, except in accordance with a decision agreed to by not less than 3 members of the Committee other than the Chairman.
(8)The Committee shall have power to confer with a similar committee of the House of Representatives.

(9)The Committee shall, as soon as practicable after 31 December in each year, prepare and table in the Senate a report on its operations during that year, and shall also have power to report from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak very briefly to this motion as I do believe that many senators who made a contribution to the previous debate also canvassed their views on the question of the establishment of a committee of senators' interests. This motion formalises the government's proposal to put in place a committee of senators' interests which will mirror the similar committee in the House of Representatives. Its function will be to monitor the operation of the pecuniary interest system and consider any changes to that system which may be proposed.

PARA.TAB: The government would regard the provisions relating to the composition of the committee and election of the chair of the committee as being subject to revision in light of the outcome of the inquiry that is currently being undertaken by the procedure committee into the committee system for the Senate. This matter finally puts to rest the issue of pecuniary interests for honourable senators. I think this is an appropriate committee to be established. It will fulfil and perform a very important function. I commend this motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Proposed standing order 22A, subparagraph (1)(d), omit the proposed subparagraph.
2.Proposed standing order 22A, paragraph (2)(a), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(2) (a)The membership of the Committee shall as closely as possible reflect the composition of the Senate and, until modified by a subsequent resolution, shall consist of 8 Senators, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 4 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 nominated by any minority groups or independent Senators.

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Proposed standing order 22A, paragraph (3), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(3)The Committee shall elect one of its members as Chairman and, in the absence of a majority decision in such an election duly notified to the President, the question of the election of the Chairman shall be determined by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments were foreshadowed a little while ago. The government's motion logically follows the one that the Senate has just carried. Our concerns are not so much in the setting up of the committee but in the composition of the committee. The first amendment, which is on a slightly different matter, omits the reference to a non-existent code of conduct. As I understood Senator Gareth Evans, the government is prepared to support that. So the two amendments in contention are our amendments Nos 2 and 3. They relate to our desire to have this committee reflect the numbers in the chamber rather than the numbers as put in the government's motion and also to the election of the chairman.

PARA.TAB: Not surprisingly, the government has stated in its motion that the chairman shall be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. There is no reason why that should be so. In fact, I suggest that, in the circumstances of this particular committee's responsibilities, it is quite inappropriate. Notwithstanding the incredible vote a few minutes ago by the minority parties, by which they refused to admonish the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for lodging a statement of his interests in the House of Representatives which is misleading and also fails to give sufficient information upon which any member of the public can make a judgment as to a potential conflict of interest between public responsibility and personal business interests—notwithstanding the fact that they voted in effect to sanction the Prime Minister in this way—it seems to us on this side of the chamber that the Prime Minister's personal failure in the application of the disclosure regime is reason in itself for the government not to be permitted to chair this particular committee.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I remind you that in the House of Representatives Register of Members' Interests, volume 3, 1993, under the name of the Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating, item 14 states:

SPEECH.PARA: any other interests, such as membership of organisations, where a conflict of interest with a Member's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise—
The Prime Minister has answered in relation to himself `nil', his spouse `nil' and his dependent children `nil', yet we know that, through his company, he is indebted to a lobbyist.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Senator Evans has acknowledged that in this chamber. Senator Collins might not have caught up with that. Clearly, on evidence that is already before the chamber, there is a potential conflict of interest. Why was that indebtedness not included in the Prime Minister's statement of disclosure? If the Prime Minister himself will not meet the requirements that he sets out and the House of Representatives committee, which through the numbers in the House is under the control of the Labor Party, is not prepared to take action on it, surely that is evidence in itself that this committee being set up by the Senate should not be controlled by the government either in numbers or in its chairmanship.

PARA.TAB: So we have moved amendments, which we trust in this instance will be supported by the minority parties, which will enable the composition of the committee to more accurately reflect the numbers in the Senate and enable the committee to elect its own chair rather than have a chair imposed upon it by the government. I trust that the minority parties will support us in this instance. If they do not, it is just a further demonstration of the sham that has been demonstrated by the Prime Minister in failing to meet the standard that he says he requires of the parliament. Mr Acting Deputy President, if it is of any help to you, I indicate at this stage that we will be dividing on those amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the Senate, the government will be supporting the first of the opposition amendments just moved. We will be opposing the second and third amendments. The matters canvassed in the amendments are currently being considered by the procedure committee in the context of its inquiry into the committee system. Accordingly, we will not be supporting these amendments but propose that the procedure committee include consideration of the composition of this committee in its wider inquiry. On that basis, we will be opposing them.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to extend the debate on this issue, and I will not, but I must respond briefly to the comments just made by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) in respect of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I must say with some strength of feeling that I sit and have sat in this chamber day after day after day listening to criticisms of the Prime Minister's interest in a value added export industry potentially for Australia in primary industries.

I see in front of me, on the opposition side, a sea of faces of active primary producers. I begrudge them not; I applaud them for their efforts. Senator Panizza, for example, is arguably one of the biggest individual wheat growers in Western Australia, and good luck to him. At my last count Senator Panizza had 25,000 acres and a bumper crop.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you're a bit wrong on that.
—Maybe I am wrong, but he had a very good year—and full marks to him.
—So what?

—That is what I am saying—so what! There is a sea of them on the other side. Senator Chapman, Senator Sandy Macdonald and Senator Crane are all in the business of primary production. It is okay if people are conservative, but it is not okay if they are Labor.

PARA.TAB: Who could forget that former Prime Minister, the owner of Nareen, who took a decision that angered and upset most of Australia with respect to the Olympic Games in Russia and was sending shipments of wool from his own wool property, Nareen, with the name stamped on the bales, to Russia while he was Prime Minister? Talk about po-faced, two-faced hypocrisy! There has been nothing like it. This from a sea of people who have consistently opposed this measure completely! I do not want to extend the debate, and I will conclude on that point, but it had to be responded to. It seems that it is okay to be a primary producer and a member of parliament if a person is conservative; the only time it is not okay is if that person is a member of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Collins for that incredible intervention. Senator Collins either does not understand or chooses not to understand that there is one dramatic difference between the primary producers on both sides, who have always been or have recently been involved in primary production, and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is that the viability of the Prime Minister's venture—
—Viability?

—I am just quoting Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The viability of the Prime Minister's piggery venture depends, according to Senator Evans, on a series of governmental approvals to expand his venture.
—Which government?
—Three governments.
—What a hypocrite!

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Collins, that was an unparliamentary remark and I ask you to withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, of course I will withdraw.
—Senator Collins knows perfectly well that approvals are required for this expansion at three levels.
—What about Nareen? Remember Malcolm Fraser?

—Senator Collins says, `What about Nareen?'. I thank Senator Collins for that interjection. It shows how dopey and incredibly stupid his position is. What governmental approvals at federal level, at state level and at local level did Malcolm Fraser need for his project to be viable?

PARA.TAB: In other words, the Prime Minister's financial investment of almost half a million dollars depends for its viability, for its capacity to survive, on getting approvals. From the federal government, FIRB approval is required. From state governments, environmental approval is required. From local governments, planning approval is required. Three sets of approvals are required for the Prime Minister's investment to be viable. In addition, the Prime Minister has a potential for conflict of interest in the fact that he owes $4 1/2 million in a subordinated loan to a lobbyist and in the fact that, when he was Treasurer and when he bought his interest in this company, the Commonwealth Bank was owed more money than the assets of this venture were worth.

There is a potential conflict of interest which cannot be contradicted. To try to pretend that existing primary producers, whose viability does not depend on any governmental approvals at any level, have the same sort of potential for conflict as the Prime Minister has, is absolute, arrant, self-evident nonsense. As Senator Evans said, for the Prime Minister's investment to be viable, it needs this project to proceed. For this project to proceed, there needs to be approvals from the federal government, the state government and local government. Yet, what does the Prime Minister say in his declaration of interests—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume, I have allowed a degree of latitude in the debate. I would ask you now to bring yourself back to the question that is before the Senate, that is, the amendments moved by Senator Hill.

—With pleasure, Mr Acting Deputy President. As you have noted, I was responding to some incredible remarks made by Senator Collins. I am overjoyed to relate this to the matter because this committee is going to preside over a statement which is exactly the same statement as exists in the House of Representatives. To have a Labor dominated committee determining action to be taken under statements lodged would be a farce. The statement that this committee will administer says: `Any other interest'—every senator will be required to answer this—`where a conflict of interest with a senator's public duty could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise'. In the House of Representatives that same condition requires members to state where a conflict of interest with their public duty could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.

PARA.TAB: This committee is going to determine the acceptability of answers to that question. The Prime Minister, knowing he has a Labor dominated committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume, the matter is related to senators' interests. The Prime Minister is not a senator.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, this is exactly the same clause as exists in the House of Representatives. It is directly related to this matter. If there is a Labor dominated committee determining answers to this question, it will be a farce. It is demonstrated by the fact that, in the House of Representatives, it is a farce. We should not follow that farcical precedent—

—Order! Senator Baume, you are running very close to reflecting on another place. I would ask you to use caution in your remarks. I refer in particular to your reference to the other place as `a farce'. I would ask you to be careful in the words you use.

—I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I assure you I will not be diverted from the job and duty I have to demonstrate that it would be ridiculous and farcical if the Senate were to follow a procedure which has allowed the Prime Minister to say, `Nil, nil, nil', in answer to the question: `Do you have any other interests where a conflict of interest with a member's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise?'. We do not want to have a situation where a Labor dominated committee can allow the same sort of situation to exist in the Senate which now exists in the House of Representatives where the Prime Minister was able to say `no' to those questions when the evidence clearly demonstrated that a conflict with a member's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.
—Tell us how he has misused his position.

—Obviously Senator Collins does not think that a debt of $4 1/2 million by the Prime Minister's half-owned piggery company to a lobbyist—and a very successful lobbyist—is germane and does not represent the potential for a conflict. That demonstrates why we must not have a Labor dominated committee. If Senator Collins reflects the thinking—to use the word very loosely—of the Labor Party about what is a potential for conflict of interest, then it would be disastrous to have a committee made up of people like Senator Collins determining for the Senate what is a proper answer to those questions.

PARA.TAB: If ever we needed a solid case to demonstrate why the Labor Party must not be allowed to dominate this committee—it is demonstrated quite clearly—it is the interjections of Senator Collins right now. Even if the 14th point did not exist, on the grounds already demonstrated by my leader, Senator Hill, it would be wrong and foolish to allow the minority party in this chamber—that is, the Labor Party—to dominate this committee. But when this one specific point has been rorted elsewhere—

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg your pardon?
—I said, `rorted elsewhere'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: any other interests where a conflict of interest with a Senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.
We do not want that sort of nonsense to happen here. That is why I believe Senator Kemp's amendment, which was moved by Senator Hill, is appropriate—and I believe the Senate should carry it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is imperative that this amendment be carried to make sure that the composition of the committee does reflect the numbers in this chamber. If we are to have a committee that is able to enforce something in a sane, sensible fashion then this amendment is absolutely paramount to that happening.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, much has been said about the righteousness of people on the Labor Party side filling out these forms without any compulsion. A further illustration as to why this committee must be formed in the way that is proposed by the opposition's amendment is that the minister at the table, the President of the Senate and Senator Childs are unable to complete this form properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Me?
—Am I right or wrong in suggesting to Senator Collins that he may well be a member of the Australian Labor Party?
—I am. It is on the form.
—It is not. It is not on the form that he signed.
—Big deal!

—It says, `membership of any organisation—nil'. So it is a big deal that Senator Collins forgot. Senator Collins has just dropped himself clean in it again because he says it is a big deal that he forgot to put something down on his form. His words are, `Such a big deal'. Therefore it begs the question: what else has the galah forgotten? I do not know what he has forgotten but I do know that two other Labor Party senators cannot sign their names—or they forgot to sign their names. That is why this particular amendment is vital to enable this matter to run properly; if it is going to be run at all. If we are not going to make sure that it is effective then it makes a further mockery of this whole situation.

PARA.TAB: This Australian Labor Party—this government—with the aid of the Independents and the Australian Democrats say that this must be filled out. If that is a decision of the Senate, I can certainly live with that; I have no problems with that. But let us not be totally making a farce of this whole situation by ministers, by the President of the Senate and by other people in this place not being able to fill it out correctly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—It is not rubbish. It says on the form, `membership of any organisation'. Senator Collins is unable to fill out a form.
—I have been hiding it for 20 years. I am a member of the Labor Party!
—Why did you say `Nil' if that is the case?
—You can do a bit better than that.

—Quite frankly, Mr Acting Deputy President, the minister's defence is nothing short of appalling. It is absolutely appalling to suggest that that is not a big deal and that we should not be worried about it. We should be worried about it because it puts into question each and every single solitary one of these things that has been put down in such grand style: `We don't care if we tell what we've got'. But the fact of the matter is, not only are they not signed but they are incomplete. So what is the big deal? What else has been forgotten? I challenge the minister: what else has he forgotten? Does he have a mortgage that he has not put down?
—If it's not on the form, I haven't.
—You have not put it down?
—If it's not on the form I don't have one.

—The Labor Party membership is not on the form either! What is the point of this? That is why the amendment moved by the opposition is absolutely integral to making this thing work and making sure that people fill the thing out honestly because, quite frankly, we have had demonstration after demonstration that that has not been so.

PARA.TAB: It just makes a whole farce of the situation to have people in the other place saying that they do not know and, as Senator Baume has demonstrated for months and months, they have not included material on their declarations. So I encourage the Senate to vote for this amendment to make sure that there is some integrity in this whole thing, instead of making it the farce that this is.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're supporting the proposition now.
—Coco, for heaven's sake, wake up! A vote has been taken in this place, Coco.
—You're supporting it now, empty head.
—It is a great shame that Senator Burns donated his brain to research before he died.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Recently, I was asked to withdraw certain remarks as being unparliamentary, which they were not, and the press got hold of it and made a great play of it. I have just been denigrated by Senator Knowles who has used an unparliamentary remark and I ask that it be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—I do not believe that the remarks that were made were unparliamentary. I do believe that the remarks were very childish. I also agree that there have been equally childish remarks coming from both sides of the chamber. I rule that there is no point of order. I ask honourable senators on both sides of the chamber to contain themselves and behave like the responsible individuals we know each and every one of them to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that Senator Knowles has finished her remarks. I support the amendment moved by Senator Hill. Most of the reasons have already been given for his amendment. But before I sit down I would like to address the remarks by Senator Collins. He said that it was no big deal omitting to state that he is a member of the Australian Labor Party. We all know that he is a member of the Labor Party.
—I would not be sitting here if I wasn't.
—I ask the minister to address this seriously for a minute.
—I thought it meant organisations other than the Labor Party.

—Okay. It is not only us who will pick up these declarations of interests; it is all Australians. Not all Australians know that Senator Collins belongs to the Labor Party. The same could be said of me or anyone else in this chamber.
—What? How do you get to be a cabinet minister in a Labor government without being a member of the Labor Party?
—Yes, but some people do not know the difference between a cabinet minister and an ordinary senator.
—But they are all in the opposition.
—Senator Collins can say what he likes; it is inexcusable. He should not employ that red herring. Not everyone in Australia knows who Senator Collins is and not everyone knows that he is a minister.
—Aren't they lucky?

—They are lucky. These returns can be picked up by anyone and they should be able to be understood by anyone. The other matter concerns people who do not sign their returns. An unsigned return is worthless. If a person has a bill to pay and is a bit short for the month, in order to buy a bit of time, it is an old trick to say, `A cheque is in the mail', then send the cheque but forget to sign it.
—I heard that about you, Senator Panizza.

—It is an old trick, but I have never done it. The cheque is sent back because it has not been signed. Then the person really gets into action, signing the cheque and sending it, having bought a bit of time. The declarations of Senator Beahan and Senator Childs are worthless because they forgot to sign them. I put on record the fact that Senator Cook said twice in his speech that the opposition voted down the last motion of this kind. My information from the clerks is that until about 10 minutes ago there has never been a vote on this matter.
—Look at the debates.
—No. He said that we voted it down.
—You are really nitpicking.

—Senator Collins should read Hansard; he will find it in there—if he can read, that is. Senator Cook said twice that the opposition voted this down. The clerks have informed me—and I always believe what the clerks tell me—that there has never been a vote on this matter in the Senate. I put on record that Senator Cook misled the Senate. He should come back and apologise to the Senate, and I invite him to do so.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! The question before the chamber is that the amendments circulated by Senator Kemp and moved by Senator Hill be agreed to. I will put the amendments individually in the order in which they have been moved. The question is that amendment No. 1 be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I open this debate on the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1994 by saying that the bill clearly demonstrates the mess which this Labor government is making of industrial relations in Australia. Although the Liberal and National parties will not oppose this amending bill, we do believe it is unnecessary. Because of the way in which the government is mishandling industrial relations, we will be moving a second reading amendment, which I will move at the end of my remarks. It will add at the end of the motion for the second reading of this bill that the Senate, first, deplores the government's incompetent management of the industrial relations portfolio—incompetence which has again forced it to bring in hasty amendments to the Industrial Relations Act—and, second, condemns the submissive attitude the government continues to demonstrate towards the ACTU, which is reflected in the commission's unduly expanded responsibility and in the disproportionately large number of senior commission personnel who have been drawn from the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, this legislation is unnecessary. It is unnecessary in the first instance because the Industrial Relations Court itself is unnecessary. When the Industrial Relations Court was established in the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, which became an act at the end of last year, it was strongly opposed by the Liberal and National parties. We opposed it for very good reason. The government made absolutely no case at all as to why there was a need to establish a specialist industrial relations court when industrial relations matters could be handled quite adequately by the existing industrial relations division of the Federal Court. No justification or rationale was provided for the establishment of that court.

In addition, the establishment and continuing operation of this new court means an unjustified extra cost to taxpayers. There is also grave concern in the community, which has been expressed by the Law Council and others, of the potential lack of independence of this new Industrial Relations Court. The Federal Court, with its industrial relations division, has the absolute independence that any court ought to have. But with the potential for the Industrial Relations Court not to be at arms length from the Industrial Relations Commission, there is the capacity for that very necessary independence that ought to apply to any court to be lost.

We also were concerned about the relationship of this court to the government's specific industrial relations program and policies. Again, a body with the status of a court ought not relate to a particular program of a government. Because of the nature of courts, as I have just said, they should have independence, they should be above and beyond any particular policy or program of a government. But that is not the case with the Industrial Relations Court.

There was also the problem of who in fact would constitute this new Industrial Relations Court. Of course, this legislation that we are debating today is the very consequence of the fact that the government itself was uncertain as to who was going to constitute that court when it put the legislation through last year. The Law Council of Australia was opposed to the establishment of this court, and we in fact mirrored the concerns of the Law Council in that debate last year because those concerns were quite legitimate and quite important.

Finally, a court which is established in this way, and which relates to a particular segment of a government's policy or program, is obviously vulnerable to a change of government. A government which comes in with a different program in that field, a different set of policies, can abolish such a court. Indeed, the coalition at the time of the debate last year indicated that when in government it would abolish the Industrial Relations Court, which simply highlights the fact that the court is vulnerable to the programs of a particular government. So that court ought not to have been established and therefore this legislation relating to that court is, as I said, unnecessary.

It is unnecessary in the second instance because, if the government really knew what it was doing as far as industrial relations is concerned, it would have included the provisions of this amending bill in that original legislation. After all, we had a very lengthy debate on that legislation in December last year, and the committee stage itself went for three or four days. Winston Crane, my Liberal Senate colleague from Western Australia, and I debated the issues of the legislation, the clauses of that legislation, quite extensively. Indeed, the government introduced and had passed, with the support of the Democrats, 170 amendments to its own bill. So the bill it introduced was not good enough; it had to put through 170 amendments. Yet now it is coming back with further amendments to that legislation. As I said, surely if the government had really known what it was doing it could have included among those 170-odd amendments the amendments that it is proposing today.

The amendments are clear evidence that the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993, debated and passed at the end of last year, was ill conceived. It is clear that the government had completely failed to properly consider and plan for the operation of that legislation. Of course, we know what that legislation was really about: it was nothing more than a pay-off to the trade union movement for the unbridled support which it gave to the Labor government in the 1993 federal election.

I remind honourable senators that that legislation which was passed last year had the grand title of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. It was the government's major overhaul of industrial relations in this country. According to the government there would be no more changes necessary to industrial relations legislation in the near future. Yet here we are today, just a few sitting weeks later, debating this amending bill. Do we need any clearer demonstration that the government did not have a clue what it was doing in establishing the Industrial Relations Court?

This bill is not only unnecessary, it is also being introduced into and passed through this parliament with undue haste. The Liberal and National parties have not had adequate opportunity to scrutinise this legislation. It has been given to us for debate this week—a week in which the House of Representatives is not sitting. There has been no opportunity for the opposition shadow cabinet to meet and consider this legislation. There has been no opportunity for a full meeting of the Liberal and National parliamentary parties—both the House of Representatives and the Senate—to meet and consider this legislation. We simply have not had adequate opportunity to consider all the ramifications of the legislation. It is unnecessary haste on the part of this government, again demonstrating its incompetent administration.

The reason for this haste is that the government has been casting around trying to find someone willing to be president of its unwanted Industrial Relations Court. Eventually, it found Justice Deirdre O'Connor, who is already a judge of the Federal Court of Australia. To move Justice O'Connor from the Federal Court to the new Industrial Relations Court required her agreement to a special deal to take the job. The government now wants to set this deal in cement through this legislation before the new Industrial Relations Act commences operation in a couple of weeks.

As I said, this legislation is a special deal for Justice Deirdre O'Connor. The amendments in this legislation allow her to remain a judge of the Federal Court of Australia during her presidency of the Industrial Relations Court and allow her also to be a president for a fixed term. As I said, the first amendment allows her to remain a judge of the Federal Court; the second amendment ensures that her tenure as a judge is not affected by her taking on this presidential role; the third amendment allows her to be appointed for a fixed term; the fourth amendment allows her to receive a presidential allowance on top of the judge's salary. More specifically, clause 3 of the amending legislation amends section 10(1)(a) of the existing act to add the words `is or'. That will therefore allow a person who either is currently a judge or was a judge of a court created by the parliament to become President of the Industrial Relations Court. The current act, as it was drafted and passed at the end of last year, allows only a past judge of the Federal Court to become president.

It is interesting to note that, while this government is changing the act to allow a person who is currently a judge of a court created by this federal parliament to take up the presidency, it has not made the same change for a judge of a state or territory court. It is not giving the same rights to judges of states or territories that it is giving to judges of the Federal Court or other courts created by the federal parliament. This is another example of the centralist attitude of this government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The original bill in many respects rode roughshod over state jurisdiction on industrial relations and this amending bill simply reinforces the way in which this government gives no consideration to states rights at all.

Clause 4 of the bill ensures that someone taking up the position of President of the Industrial Relations Court retains full tenure rights, titles and so on of his or her position as a judge of the Federal Court. Clause 5 provides for the appointment of the president for a fixed term of tenure and, as I understand it, it has been agreed that Deirdre O'Connor's tenure will be for five years.
It is worth looking at two aspects of clause 5. Firstly, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The first President of the Commission appointed after the commencement of this subsection may be appointed for a fixed term . . .

In other words, this is handmade for Justice Deirdre O'Connor. No-one else will be allowed a fixed term tenure, only the first appointed—Deirdre O'Connor. Secondly, up until now, presidents have been appointed virtually until they die. Again, to suit one individual, the government is going to change this act.

PARA.TAB: We should consider whether acts of parliament ought to be changed at the whim of one person. While we would agree that there ought to be flexibility on agreements—even agreements for the appointment of the judiciary, which is consistent with the approach the Liberal and National parties adopt—legislation relating to flexibility in industrial relations and flexibility in employment relations ought to have general application; it ought to apply to everyone. It should not be drafted simply to suit the whim of an individual. That is contrary to natural justice and contrary to the rule of law.

Clause 6 ensures that Deirdre O'Connor will retain the salary of a judge. If the president's salary is higher than that, the difference will be made up by the payment of an allowance. It will be interesting to note in that context whether that allowance is to be taxed at the same rate as the equivalent salary or whether it is to be taxed differently because, of course, some allowances are taxed at lower rates and some allowances are not taxed at all. They are particular issues that are raised by the specific amendments that are incorporated in this legislation.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I was just wondering whether the Senate could give indulgence to Senator Chapman for a few more minutes to enable him to finish his speech.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its indulgence to allow this part of the debate to be concluded.

PARA.TAB: One of the particular issues addressed in the amendment which I will move at the end of my remarks is the unduly expanded responsibility of the Industrial Relations Commission. It relates specifically to what we regard as the nonsense of the commission being given the task of reviewing all awards and enterprise agreements, as it is directed in the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993, and the increased role and authority of the commission, albeit with the unions having a de facto veto power.

We believe that, very clearly, individual employees and employers ought to be given the right to establish their own enterprise and workplace agreements without the interference of the commission or unions, or anyone else for that matter, unless either the employee or the employer requests such an intervention. So, despite all the trumpeting we had from the government about this legislation at the end of last year, this does not make enterprise agreements any easier to achieve and in fact heads us away from that ideal and back to a system of industrial relations which is much more centralised and much more controlled.

In the last couple of days we have had examples of the way in which it is much more difficult to obtain enterprise agreements. A coalmining operation in central Queensland is becoming the focus of a major national row with regard to the move to 12-hour shifts in the black coal industry. This is despite the fact that the employees at this coalmine and two of the unions involved—the Automotive, Food and Engineering Union and the Electronic and Plumbing Union—have supported this move to 12-hour shifts, which would involve workers at the mine working 12-hour shifts on a seven-day on, seven-day off arrangement.

The reason they have come to that agreement is that it will give them more time with their families. A seven-day on, seven-day off roster is acceptable to employees because it will give them more time with their families. A number of them live on the coast and a roster of seven days on and seven days off means that they can work their seven days and then go back to their homes on the coast, some distance away from the mine, and spend time with their families. Yet we find the United Mine Workers Union taking action to prevent this agreement from being put in place.

In the International Year of the Family, an industrial relations agreement for family welfare freely entered into by employees and employers with the support of two unions will be opposed by the United Mine Workers Union. In this International Year of the Family, when we ought to be introducing initiatives that will benefit family life, here we find a union taking action to prevent this agreement, which action, if successful, will be detrimental to family life. That is one example of where enterprise agreements are not being developed.

Another example is of CRA, through an enterprise agreement, moving award workers into salaried staff positions. About 80 per cent of its 600-strong work force at Weipa and about 1,300 out of the work force of 1,500 at Hamersley have agreed to this enterprise agreement. It will be opposed by not only the union directly involved but also the ACTU in a campaign to prevent that enterprise agreement coming to fruition. This makes nonsense of this government's claims that the Industrial Relations Act is allowing for a more flexible industrial relations system and better establishment of enterprise agreements.

The final point I wish to make relates again to our amendment—the disproportionately large number of senior commission personnel who have been drawn from the trade union movement. With those who have been announced as appointees to the Industrial Relations Court we find, apart from Justice Dierdre O'Connor, to whom this legislation relates, two vice-presidents but then nine senior deputy presidents: Elizabeth Evatt, who is currently on leave but is on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission payroll; Mr Keogh, who is a government employee; Alan Boulton, an ACTU legal officer; Joe Riordan, a union official and a minister in the Whitlam Labor government and the New South Wales Labor government; Paul Munro, Federal Secretary of the ACOA, a public service union; Keith Hancock, a Labor-linked academic who is very supportive of the Labor Party's industrial relations policies; Jan Marsh, formerly the ACTU research officer; John McBean from the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council; and one from the employer side of industrial relations, Colin Polites, a solicitor who has acted for employers.

In the six or seven deputy presidents to be appointed, we find Ian Watson, ACTU research officer; Simon Williams, a solicitor who has acted for unions; Jenny Acton, an ACTU industrial officer; Lea Drake, a solicitor who has acted for unions; John Maher, a government servant; and, again one solicitor who has acted for employers, Ann Harrison. Do we need any more evidence than that of the way in which the trade unions are dominating industrial relations in this country and the way in particular in which this new Industrial Relations Court and its associated Industrial Relations Commission are going to operate?

There is an absolute dominance of former union officials and union representatives on those bodies. That is entirely unsatisfactory if we are to have a fair and balanced conduct of industrial relations in this country. As I have said, it simply indicates the mess into which industrial relations is sinking under this government's administration. Again, it indicates and reinforces the shortcomings and faults that were inherent in the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993. It indicates why this legislation today ought to be unnecessary. With those remarks, I move:
At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)deplores the Government's incompetent management of the industrial relations portfolio, incompetence which has again forced it to bring in hasty amendments to the Industrial Relations Act; and
(b)condemns the submissive attitude the Government continues to demonstrate toward the ACTU, reflected in:

TAB.TAB: (ii)the disproportionately large number of senior Commission personnel who have been drawn from the trade union movement.
