TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Military Compensation Bill. On the surface it is an innovation, but in reality it is the current Commonwealth Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, badge-engineered in the vernacular of the times, for the Defence Force. The bill amends the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 and the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. In doing so, it creates the necessary framework for the new military compensation scheme.

PARA.TAB: Part 2, clauses 3 to 10 of the bill, establishes the military compensation scheme within the framework of SRCA. This ensures that the military compensation scheme will apply to all members of the Defence Force, including members on future operational service, thus ensuring members on operational service as well as those on hazardous and peacekeeping duties will have the choice of SRCA or the VEA.

Ordinary peacetime members who, on the commencement of the MCS, have an existing entitlement under part IV of the VEA will continue to have the option of SRCA or VEA coverage for that period. Subsequent service will be covered by SRCA only. Peacetime members who do not have an existing entitlement under part IV of the VEA on commencement of the MCS or who enter the ADF after commencement will have only SRCA as modified by the MCS.

Through section 5(6A), the minister will be able to extend the operation of SRCA beyond members of the ADF by declaring that the act will apply to those who hold honorary rank when they are engaging in activities stemming from that rank, members of philanthropic organisations like the Salvation Army who are serving with the ADF and ex-members of the ADF on discharged resettlement training.

Members of the defence force, cadet corps and persons declared under section 5 (6A) will be covered for any injury which arises out of medical treatment provided by the Commonwealth where the injury is an unintended consequence of the treatment. Injured members of the ADF will be able to receive full pay or supplementation up to full pay for the first 45 weeks of compensation, regardless of whether they stay in the ADF or separate.

Part 3 of this bill amends the Veterans' Entitlement Act to take account of the establishment of the military compensation scheme. These clauses put in place transitional provisions to ensure members on operational service do not have dual coverage under the VEA and SRCA, and a termination date to remove VEA coverage for ordinary peacetime service, except for the period of entitlement already existing at that date.

These clauses also ensure that members on hazardous service continue to have the choice of VEA coverage. Those peacetime members who have an existing period of entitlement under part 4 of the VEA will have choice of VEA coverage for that period following the commencement of MCS, and ordinary peacetime members who do not have existing entitlement under the VEA will have coverage only under the modified military compensation scheme.

The military compensation scheme has been discussed for a long while. In 1985, when the VEA was first being debated, the government told the parliament that a military compensation scheme was to be introduced the next year. It has taken almost a decade for the government to deliver. In essence, the amendments ensure that the military compensation scheme will provide the basic level of compensation cover for all types of service: peacetime, peacekeeping, hazardous and operational.

Those injured in operational, hazardous or peacekeeping service have a choice between the military compensation scheme and the Veterans' Entitlement Act. Secondly, the military compensation scheme includes all the benefits provided under the SRCA plus cover for the unintended consequences of medical treatment paid for by the Commonwealth, and cover as employees those who are declared to hold honorary rank in the ADF and members of philanthropic organisations who provide service for the ADF.

Currently the SRCA provides compensation to persons who are injured in the course of their employment by the Commonwealth, while the Veterans' Entitlement Act provides pension entitlements to persons who have suffered a war or defence caused injury or incapacity. Currently, members of the ADF on hazardous, peacekeeping and ordinary peacetime service are covered by both the SRCA and the VEA. Members of the ADF on operational service are covered only by the VEA.

The Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act covers death or injury at work or during an ordinary recess, illness or disease which was caused or materially contributed to by ADF service, loss or damage to an aid or appliance as a result of work-related accident, and injury sustained during a journey between home and work, and some authorised activities outside of normal work, such as approved sport. The bill lists the actual benefits that will be paid, and I do not propose to repeat them in this speech.

The opposition will not be opposing this bill, but in no sense does that mean that the bill has our wholehearted support. We are certainly not advocates of this bill, and had we been in government we would have taken a very different path. We were not in government, and the changes we would wish to make to the bill would not, at this stage, receive majority support in the chamber, let alone in the other place. So outright opposition to the bill is quite futile.

I therefore propose to make some remarks about this bill. I will start with three points. The first is that we do not need a bill like this—a separate bill which deals with compensation and rehabilitation and administered by the Department of Defence. The second point I make is that, apart from widening the net and covering more people, this bill brings few, if any, benefits to members of the peacetime ADF beyond what members of the Public Service enjoy.

Finally, by so doing, it builds further on the government's aim to make the ADF just another branch of the Public Service, and denies its unique status. It takes away benefits that members of the ADF have enjoyed for over 20 years, and is unambiguously a reduction and lessening of their conditions of service.

Let me now expand on those statements. I have thought about this bill a lot, and the more I think about it, the more the force of the argument drives me inexorably to the conclusion that it should be part of the Veterans' Entitlement Act. It logically belongs nowhere else. The DVA has a very long history of caring for the needs of ex-service men and women. Everything is in place for them. While this bill will primarily relate to serving members of the ADF, not veterans, the services that they require could be delivered by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Department of Defence, the authority which will administer these services under this bill, does not have the full resources to deliver the services to the level that veterans and defence force personnel are used to and they will have to be expanded and developed at considerable cost.

There is no reason why this bill could not have been presented as an amendment to the Veterans' Entitlement Act. After all, we have had two separate amendments in the last three months and three amendments in the last 12 months, and I presume we will have more in the next year.

There is a very good argument to be made to revise and rewrite the Veterans' Entitlement Act, even though it only passed through the parliament in 1986. Its origin and philosophy go back through the various repatriation acts to the First World War. It is far too long and complex, containing many hundreds of pages. Even the plain English version of the bill is complex in itself, and needs to be clarified and reduced. While a new VEA should retain all the benefits in it at present, it should also include compensation for injury, rehabilitation and re-education that the MC bill provides.

The Veterans' Entitlement Act was born as a consequence of the two greatest military conflicts in history: World War I and World War II. The new bill should be expanded to better accommodate the fact that most members of the ADF today, thankfully, will have seen only peacetime service. Increasingly, a number of those will have only served for a period of five to eight years, not the 20 or more years that will qualify them for a DFRDB or MSBS pension.

My next point is that while people such as cadets, service, welfare and philanthropic personnel and honorary members are covered—and that is a good thing—there are few benefits beyond what public servants acquire. The only argument that the government can resort to to defend this position is that, for example, the loss of an arm or a leg is the same for a soldier as it is for a clerk in an office. In one sense that is perfectly true, but it will almost certainly mean the end of a career for a soldier, and at an early age, with low rank and commensurate low pay. It would deny him or her a chosen career in life, while the clerk may well progress to higher things. On that basis, there is a case for a different scale of benefits from those awarded to the Public Service.

The larger issue here, of course, is the age-old problem of a Labor government being unable to see the difference between the ADF and the Public Service. The Australian Defence Force is trained for wartime operations. Its members do not have unions, awards or overtime and are subject to continuous and strict discipline. They can be required to work 24 hours a day with little or no notice and be sent anywhere. They have to train as realistically as possible to do the violent and dangerous tasks required of them in war.

The combination of that training and the introduction of this new scheme must lead to a rethink in defence, particularly in two areas—namely, training standards and the need for preventative actions, and the development of a high standard of incident reporting. The ADF needs to look very closely at the standard of fitness of its personnel. Training injuries are bound to occur during exercises and in any vigorous training session if personnel are not at peak fitness.

This leads to my next point concerning incident reporting. If the new scheme is to work, and to work in favour of the members of the ADF, there will need to be substantial education of the troops to encourage the reporting of incidents. There will need to be a change from the collective view that only major injuries are reported and recorded. A change which recognises that a small, apparently insignificant injury and its cause needs to be recorded, will mean that, down the track, such records will be available when a compensation claim is made.

I have said in this chamber many times before that the Australian Defence Force is not a part of the Public Service, and I deplore very much the tendency of this government to make it so. If one accepts that, it therefore follows that members of the Australian Defence Force are entitled to some special considerations from the community which they serve.

The final point I would like to make in this area is that for the first time members of the ADF will actually lose some of their benefits. This will happen because the great majority of members will only ever have peacetime service. Therefore, the benefits of the Veterans' Entitlements Act which they at present have will be withdrawn and they will be left only with the military compensation scheme.

Originally, repatriation benefits were only awarded to those who had been on active service in wartime. In 1972, to counter the massive resignation rate under the Whitlam Labor government, coverage was extended under the Repatriation Act to those on peacetime service. In 1986, when the Veterans' Entitlements Act came in, the opposition moved that coverage be maintained until the new Military Compensation Bill was enacted. So, for a variety of reasons, for the last 20 years members of the ADF on peacetime service have been covered by the VEA.

If it is accepted that the nature of peacetime training required in the ADF is far removed from the civilian norm, it must also be accepted that it is reasonable to provide a different compensation scheme from that available for civilians. There is, however, a world of difference between peacetime training, even at its most realistic, and being on a battlefield where an enemy is trying to kill you. It is important that distinction is maintained with respect to compensatory benefits for those two cases. The answer to that problem, from a compensation point of view, may be to maintain the difference which exists under the VEA in terms of the standard of evidence required between the two cases, and not restrict the VEA only to those who have had operational, hazardous or peacekeeping service.

The bill directly affects current and future serving members of the ADF. In the fullness of time, all current members will become veterans, so veterans are indirectly involved. I do not get the feeling, having talked to a number of members of the ADF, that there is much understanding of the significance of this bill for serving members of the uniformed services. As such, there is no criticism from members of the ADF about it.

The veteran community, however, is quite different. Almost universally, veterans dislike the bill, and they dislike the direction it is taking. They have a range of reasons why they are opposed to the bill and some of those reasons, in my judgment, are very well founded. I propose to test the government on particular applications of the bill and how it interprets it at the committee stage. In light of those answers, it may or may not be necessary to move some amendments.

The opposition does not oppose this legislation. We have a number of serious reservations, some of which I have mentioned. The bill does confer benefits which, as I said in the introduction to my speech, legally confer the same status on the ADF as the Public Service. The concept of providing re-training with a view to establishing a new career where a person will be self-supporting is laudable and to be supported. The inclusion of those who have been part of the Defence Force from time immemorial but were not actually service personnel is also worth while.

Finally, the coverage of the reservists by the military compensation scheme is very necessary and long overdue. While reservists have been covered in some ways in the past, I have had numerous complaints over the years from reservists regarding the great difficulties in getting compensation for injuries received in training. This bill should provide a clearer picture for reservists.

Those men and women who wear the uniform of the Australian Defence Force undertake great obligations on behalf of the Australian community. The parliament must ensure that, in return for the sacrifice members of the ADF make in peace and in war, the compensation awarded to them is commensurate with the effort that they make. The opposition will be watching very closely the implementation of this legislation to see that those objectives are attained.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Military Compensation Bill 1994 is obvious from the title. It is to establish a compensation scheme covering injuries and disabilities suffered in the course of the full range of military activities. At the same time, Australian Defence Force personnel injured during operational, peacekeeping or hazardous service will retain the option of coverage under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. Personnel who began full-time continuous service before 1986 will retain that choice for all forms of service.

PARA.TAB: The military compensation scheme will operate, in effect, as a specialised extension of the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act of 1988, otherwise known as the SRC Act. It will be administered by staff dedicated to the new scheme—the same arrangement as now applies with the SRC Act—and will feature a number of additional benefits which recognise the unique demands and hazards of military service. That is, the unintended consequences of Commonwealth supplied medical treatment will again be covered. This restores a benefit which applied, as I understand it, prior to 1988.

The minister will be able to declare certain classes of non-military personnel eligible for benefits—for example, members of philanthropic bodies who are authorised to provide services to the Australian defence forces. I certainly would support that. Also, incapacitated ADF members who are discharged within 45 weeks of their injury will, nevertheless, receive 100 per cent of their pre-injury weekly earnings for the full 45 weeks.

Judging from the letters and faxes which have come in during the last few days, this bill has aroused disquiet and concern in both the service and ex-service communities. The most general concern seems to be that ADF personnel have vastly different conditions to the public servants for whom the SRC Act was designed. This should be recognised by maintaining all compensation benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

The Democrats have some sympathy for the proposal that all benefits should be put under the one legislative roof. The government maintains that this option was looked at but was found to be impractical. The argument put to us was that because the SRC Act is about income support during rehabilitation, while the Veterans' Entitlements Act is concerned with pensions and ongoing medical treatment, it would be a major headache to put them together. In our view, what matters at the end of the day is whether the benefits provided by the military compensation scheme and the Veterans' Entitlements Act together are fair, comprehensive and tailored to the unique demands of defence service.

I have already mentioned the benefits to be provided under the military compensation scheme on top of those already in the SRC Act. The question is whether there are any gaps in coverage which need to be filled. During our briefing by the department on this bill—and I must compliment those who came because it was, perhaps, one of the best briefings I have received; very comprehensive and certainly backed up with very helpful notes—we asked why coverage for the unintended consequences of Commonwealth funded medical treatment had not been backdated to 1988 when it was struck down. The government has indicated that it is looking at whether this hole can be plugged administratively. Surely it would be more straightforward to move an amendment which puts the issue beyond doubt. The extra burden on the Commonwealth is hardly likely to be large.

It has been suggested to us that the cessation of incapacity benefits under the SRC Act after age 65 could leave some beneficiaries in a parlous financial state, particularly if their military superannuation entitlements are small or non-existent. The Democrats recognise that people over 65 would be entitled to other forms of income support, which is why the threshold is there. It may be that there is no problem, but we would urge further dialogue between the government, the service and the ex-service communities. To clear up the matter, this would seem to be in order.

There is also a suggestion that the travel provisions of the SRC Act may not adequately cover the travel obligations of defence personnel, for example, to and from exercise areas. On our reading, section 6 of the SRC Act is quite general and casts a wide net. However, we ask the government whether it has considered introducing a form of words which would unambiguously cover the military situation and allay the fears of the defence community. I urge the minister to look again at that. The need for an independent appeal mechanism has also been raised with us. However, the Democrats are satisfied with the provisions in the SRC Act for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Overall, the Democrats see the military compensation scheme as a positive initiative. It extends compensation which emphasises rehabilitation to all forms of defence service, including operational service. At the same time, it recognises the need for continuity by keeping open the option of the Veterans' Entitlements Act for the more risky forms of military service. The Democrats will be supporting the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank Senator MacGibbon and Senator Woodley for their contributions to this very important debate on the Military Compensation Bill. Until 1949, defence personnel rendering peacetime service were not covered under any specific compensation legislation. Since that time, peacetime service in the Defence Force has been covered by Commonwealth compensation legislation.

PARA.TAB: In 1973, as we have heard from Senator MacGibbon, the Labor government amended the Repatriation Act 1920 to allow defence members rendering full-time service during peacetime access to compensation cover through some of the provisions of the Repatriation Act. After a three-year qualifying period, those on full-time peacetime service were given access to the disability provisions of the Repatriation Act. Those provisions were applied with the normal `civilian' proofs of the Commonwealth compensation scheme.

The government has long held the view that the Repatriation Act is not an appropriate vehicle for peacetime compensation coverage of the Australian Defence Force. This view was demonstrated in 1986 when the Veterans' Entitlements Act, which replaced the Repatriation Act, specifically recognised the need for a peacetime military compensation scheme and provided access to limited veterans' benefits only until such time as the military compensation scheme was put in place.

The need for action on Defence Force compensation has become obvious during recent operational deployments by the ADF in Cambodia and Somalia which have highlighted an anomaly under the current arrangements for compensation. Service men and women on operational service have fewer options for compensation benefits than do those on less risky types of service. This is because the current Commonwealth compensation legislation, the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, cannot be applied to those on operational service. The realisation of the inequity of the current arrangements for those on operational service has caused the government to act to provide a more balanced system.

The government agreed in June 1992 to introduce a military compensation scheme for ADF members on peacetime service. The MCS will replace current arrangements under which members with peacetime service are eligible for compensation under the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and some of the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. MCS comprises cover under the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act with additional benefits to be provided as follows: firstly, cover for the unintended consequences of any medical treatment provided at Commonwealth expense; and, secondly, members discharged less than 45 weeks after being injured or becoming ill will receive 45 weeks compensation at the rate of their normal weekly earnings.

Upon commencement the MCS will provide the sole cover for most members in peacetime service. This includes cadets, instructors of cadets, officers with honorary rank, philanthropic representatives and ex-members on discharge training. All members who join the ADF after the introduction of the MCS will have the MCS as their only compensation cover for peacetime service. To ensure that there is no detriment to those who have an entitlement to VEA cover, there is provision in the VEA for those who enlisted before that act commenced in 1986 and who continue to render full-time service after the MCS is implemented to retain cover under the VEA in addition to the cover provided by the MCS.

Service men and women who enlisted after the introduction of the VEA and have completed a three-year period of service to qualify for VEA coverage will retain that coverage for the period from their enlistment until the introduction of the MCS. Service women and men who enlisted after the introduction of the VEA in 1986 but fail to achieve the three-year qualifying service for coverage under the VEA will be covered for peacetime service under the SRCA and then, after its enactment, the MCS only. Claims may be made under the VEA after the commencement of the MCS for an injury or disease arising out of a period of service when an individual was covered under the VEA.

Although the MCS has been designed primarily for ADF members rendering peacetime service, it is recognised that the scheme may also be attractive for those undertaking operational, hazardous or peacekeeping duties. As an example, the MCS provides for lump sum payments and significant rehabilitation benefits that are not available under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. For this reason, the legislation includes the provision for those rendering peacekeeping, hazardous or operational service to be given the choice of electing benefits under either the MCS or the VEA for injuries or diseases arising out of that service. This arrangement acknowledges the greater risks and difficulties associated with non-peacetime service.

The continuation of VEA coverage for peacekeeping, hazardous and operational service provides a progressive scale of benefits with the greatest range of benefits open to those who do provide operational service. Those on peacetime service receive cover under the MCS. Those on peacekeeping or hazardous service have the choice of cover under either the MCS or the disability provisions of the VEA, while members on operational service have the option of cover under the MCS or the full provisions of the VEA.

During the development of the MCS, consideration was given to the option of providing the scheme as an amendment under the VEA. However, for a number of very sound reasons, this option was not adopted. At the heart of the matter, Defence was already administering the SRCA. As the MCS was to be based on the SRCA, it was logical to retain that administration with Defence. It was also important that Defence be retained as the administrator of the scheme to ensure that it fulfilled its responsibilities as an employer. It is no longer acceptable for an employer to take no interest in the rehabilitation of those individuals who are injured through work. A separate MCS, administered by Defence, brings this employer responsibility into sharp focus.

The responsibilities for occupational health and safety, compensation and rehabilitation are closely aligned. An MCS administered by Defence will allow the ADF to integrate these important areas. This arrangement will help to ensure that an injured service man or woman is provided with continuous support through a process of treatment and rehabilitation, both within and outside the service.

Much has been said during consultations, as part of the preparation of this bill, about the role currently filled by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Although the Department of Veterans' Affairs has a long and excellent history of administering veterans' benefits over 70 years, it has little experience in managing the type of rehabilitation and vocational retraining that is the hallmark of modern compensation legislation such as the MCS.

Effective rehabilitation is at the core of modern compensation legislation. It is Defence, not Veterans' Affairs, that currently fulfils this rehabilitation and vocational training responsibility under the SRCA. The MCS will allow Defence to continue to fulfil this responsibility and to develop and improve it into the future.

Much rehabilitation work is carried out now by the defence forces' medical services and through a highly effective system of schools and training courses. The MCS allows the coordination of medical, occupational health and safety, compensation, rehabilitation and defence administration in an efficient and effective manner. The government is committed to keeping the MCS separate from the VEA. Although both schemes provide excellent benefits, they are different schemes and they do have a different focus.

The benefits available under the MCS are those of a modern compensation scheme. The package has been specifically designed for the serving member of the Defence Force. It is based on a well tested, high quality package which is widely recognised as one of the best schemes in Australia. Administration of the MCS has been deleted from the Defence commercial support program. This means that the MCS will not be commercialised and administration of the scheme will remain with Defence.

The Defence infrastructure for administration of the scheme is already in place and will not require major enhancement to deal with an expected gradual increase in workload. Defence is currently examining options to improve computer support for its occupational health and safety, compensation and rehabilitation functions. An outcome of this will be improved efficiency in compensation claims management.

Members of my staff, officers of the ADF and the departments of defence and veterans' affairs have undertaken an extensive round of briefings and consultations with interest groups as part of the development of this legislation. I do appreciate that Senator Woodley indicated that the briefings he had received on this piece of legislation were as good as, if not better than, any other he had received since he became a senator. I think that is true of the nature of the briefings on this legislation that have been given more broadly to other interest groups.

But these consultations did raise a number of areas of concern amongst interest groups. The government has been able to address a number of these issues through changes in legislation or by administrative action. For example, as a result of consultations with the RSL, the bill has been amended to provide for a Defence Force representative on the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission. This inclusion will ensure that the Defence point of view on these important matters will be clearly represented in advice to government. The ADF will undertake a program to educate its members to ensure that the full benefits of compensation are available to all of its members.

As indicated by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, Mr Punch, during the second reading debate in the House of Representatives, the government is working to improve the cover for the unintended consequences of medical treatment to include those injured from 1 December 1988. Members who have suffered an injury or disease as an unintended consequence of medical treatment for a non-compensable condition are provided with cover under the MCS. This cover was also available before the introduction of the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act in 1988. The government has recognised that some individuals might be unintentionally disadvantaged by the five-year gap in cover between the introduction of the SRCA and the introduction of the MCS. The government has directed that this matter be addressed as quickly as possible.

Advice from the Attorney-General's Department is that the new provision for coverage of the unintended consequences of medical treatment does not apply to events which occur before its commencement; that is, it does not give retrospective cover. The government will bring forward an amendment in the winter sittings to provide any coverage that is necessary in this respect. This, and a range of other lesser matters that are under development, demonstrates very clearly that the government is committed to effective consultation, to meaningful action and a cooperative approach to ensure that the service men and women of this country receive the best possible support from the wider community.

Finally, compensation is one of the most complex areas of legislation. The package presented today has been carefully crafted, carefully considered and adjusted to ensure that it will function well within the constraints of other legislation, Australian Defence Force and defence structures, financial limitations, the expectations of the community and the culture of the ADF. The MCS is a practical and workable response to this situation. It will serve the ADF very well for years into the future. I commend this bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I advise the chamber that, in the absence of Senator Hill, I will be acting as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.

—Mr President, I might say that the view from here is much better—although some of those opposite do not look any better! My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I refer to the Prime Minister's pre-election promise `not to put up tax'. Will the minister again deny that, after the Bonython by-election, the Medicare tax will increase to 1.6 per cent, costing the average family on $50,000 a year an additional $2 a week in tax and having the most severe impact on low income earners?

—May I say that, while Senator Alston is delighted to have a closer view of us, we are not all that thrilled about a closer view of him. Having listened to him, we are not all that thrilled about what he has to say, either. I must have answered this question, addressed in one form or another, 20 times in the last couple of weeks. I have nothing to add to the million other answers that I have already given.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it that, once again, the minister is not prepared to rule out any increase of any sort. In those circumstances, would the minister please explain how any increase in the Medicare levy will do anything to arrest the ever increasing decline in the number of private health insurance contributors?

—The only people who are claiming that the Medicare levy is about to go up are those opposite. We are actually here working on those opposite. Some people in the press gallery—God bless them—have made this comment. Well, good luck to them! But, as far as I am concerned, I have no further comment to make on this issue whatsoever.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence and relates to defence materiel cooperation with Sweden. Can the minister advise the Senate what steps are being taken to further develop cooperative activities between the defence industries of Australia and Sweden?

—I am delighted to receive this question from Senator McKiernan on St Patrick's Day. In honour of that particular event, this morning I signed a new memorandum of understanding on defence materiel cooperation between Australia and Sweden. The new memorandum of understanding is aimed at enhancing the capability of both countries' defence industries and builds upon the existing relationship developed through the Collins class submarine project. It encourages the industries of both countries to identify new cooperative activities and work together in pursuing opportunities for joint marketing and sales of defence materiel in selected third countries. To achieve these aims, the MOU specifically addresses technology transfer; the exchange of information concerning third country markets; intellectual property rights; transparency in export control arrangements; and the removal of barriers to bilateral defence trade, subject to each country's laws.

PARA.TAB: The new memorandum of understanding will, in due course, replace an earlier cooperative memorandum of understanding with Sweden, under which there has been a number of successful activities, including airborne early warning radar system studies, collaboration on electro-optics technology and exchange of information on army command and control systems. The MOU represents something of a first. I understand that this is the first time Sweden has entered into any cooperative arrangement with any other country for the marketing of defence equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I refer to the willingness of the Australian Private Hospitals Association to work with the government to try to find solutions to the problems facing the private health system. Will the minister inform the Senate what direction he will now take, given that the private hospitals have now said that his proposals are `discriminatory, unworkable, self-defeating and would cost the industry at least $420 million in the first year'?

—The first thing one would do is not get very worried about it. If one listens to the Private Hospitals Association too much, one could get oneself into awful strife. Private hospital executives and board members have to look at with whom they are dealing. When they look across and see people like Senator Herron they say, `Oh, my God, what is this? How can we handle people like this?'. I sympathise with them. I worry about them. I look at all those people out there like Senator Herron, these proceduralists, who really are very difficult to deal with.

PARA.TAB: However, if nothing else, I am an optimist. I have faith. I believe that even people like Senator Herron will one day see the light. I told Senator Herron yesterday about the number of surgeons in Western Australia who have already seen lights that he cannot see. I believe that just by putting this on the agenda I have already taken the profession further in six months than it has gone in a decade, and we will take it further still. We have optimism on this side. We believe in the goodness of human nature. We believe that, if we stay optimistic, if we hang in there and if we try to change things, we will succeed. Fortunately, we have an 11-year record of success in doing just that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister for Health may not be worried about the private hospitals, but obviously he has to be a bit concerned about his own party, the ACTU and all the other people who have made submissions against his proposals. Is it not true to say that the minister's utter failure to gain support for his private health proposals, together with a serious decline in private health insurance membership, is the real reason why he is now desperate and has decided to break his commitment to the Australian people and raise the Medicare levy?

—The private insurance industry has supported it all the way through. We even sat there at dinner when it supported it. But I cannot call those opposite names. I agreed not to do so yesterday and I must keep the blood pressure down; so I will not. Prior to going to cabinet last year, when Senator Newman and Senator Herron were saying that I would fail to get the members to endorse the direction in which I saw health care going, I said to them, `Take three deep breaths, don't worry, I'll get there' and I did. The record over the years suggests that I do not get rolled too often. If I were those opposite, I would not hang by the neck waiting for it to happen now either.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to a recent report in the Adelaide Advertiser highlighting a jump in the number of apprentices in South Australia. Can the minister provide information on the increases and in which industry sectors the increases have occurred?

—I am pleased to hear that some members opposite may be interested in what is happening in South Australia. An important by-election is coming up on Saturday, which I suspect may well be the final nail in the coffin of Senator Vanstone's favourite leader, Dr Hewson. I want to point out that those apprenticeship numbers are very good news in South Australia, reflecting the very good economic news in the rest of Australia.

PARA.TAB: In the past eight months there has been a 32 per cent increase in apprenticeship numbers in South Australia. If traineeships are added to the new apprenticeships, there has been a staggering 55 per cent increase in the number of places registered to February this year compared with February of last year as the improvement in the economy in South Australia and the rest of Australia has taken place in recent months. Training numbers have grown steadily in the past two years in South Australia with 2,792 commencements in the eight months to February of this year. This contrasts with only 1,746 for the same period in 1992.

Also very pleasing is the fact that the increase has been across all trade groups. In the sales and personnel area the numbers have jumped by 60 per cent; in the clerical area there was a 46 per cent increase; in the electrical area, apprenticeships and traineeships increased by 83 per cent; the food industry showed a 36 per cent increase; the building industry showed a 31 per cent increase in apprenticeships and traineeships; and the vehicle industry, probably the most important industry in my state of South Australia, showed a 27 per cent increase in traineeships.

These are very good figures and reflect the fact that South Australia, being a manufacturing-based state, is reliant on a strong economy in the rest of Australia which buys the manufactures from South Australia. Of course, it also relies upon good export markets. In both those areas the macro-economic policies of this government have created the environment for confidence and growth—growth that those opposite despair of because every upward notch as a percentage point means that their chance of winning the next election goes down several percentage points, irrespective of who happens to be the leader of the Liberal Party. This is good news for South Australia and Australia, and I hear those opposite baying in disappointment at such good news.
Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Senator Kemp and his brother have split over whom they should be supporting for the leadership of the Liberal Party. It just shows how atomised the Liberal Party is when two brothers cannot agree on who should be its next leader.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I draw the minister's attention to the page one article in today's Canberra Times, reporting that the definition of the long-term unemployed is set to be changed from 12 months to 18 months. I also draw the minister's attention to comments by the Prime Minister on Melbourne radio 3LO yesterday. In talking with Doug Aiton, Mr Keating talked about the long-term unemployment problem as being:

QUESTION.PARA: how you deal with the problem of three hundred-odd thousand people who have been unemployed 18 months or more.

When I asked the minister about this possible change back on 23 February, he said that he had `no information that there is any specific plan before the government at the moment. . . to change the definition'. I ask the minister: is the definition being changed? This will redefine hundreds of thousands of Australians out of the government's employment response—or was it a slip of the prime ministerial tongue?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that Senator Kernot asked me that question quite a few weeks ago. The position as I stated it then is unchanged. Senator Kernot would be aware, as is everybody else, that there are major policy initiatives being discussed by the government at the moment including an industry policy, a regional policy and an employment policy; and the government will respond accordingly. I have no further information to give Senator Kernot on whether the definition will be changed or not. She will have to wait until the statement is made.

PARA.TAB: I indicate that the way she has interpreted the remarks of the Prime Minister does not mean automatically that there will be a change in the definition of the term `long-term unemployment'. I think she is drawing a long bow to get that outcome from the question she has just asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister think that the Prime Minister would know the long-standing definition of long-term unemployed? I wonder why he would have suddenly used the words `18 months or more'. Does the minister think the Prime Minister would know the difference?

—The Prime Minister has been in public life since the late 1960s as a member of this parliament. He has held a number of important portfolios. This clearly indicates that he is across these major issues. For 25 years or more he has represented a major working class electorate in metropolitan Sydney. The members of that working class electorate have returned him election after election.

PARA.TAB: Of course the Prime Minister understands the definition of long-term unemployment; of course the Prime Minister understands the definition of unemployment; and of course the Prime Minister understands the issue of employment. That is why last year he commissioned the green paper to address the major subject of employment issues. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. My question relates to an answer given by the minister yesterday in which he gave a brief overview of the December quarter national accounts. Could the minister advise the Senate what the response of leading commentators has been to the latest figures? Noting that the Treasurer indicated that the figures showed the economy was `on track for sustained recovery with low inflation and low interest rates', is there any reason, in view of media commentary, why the government should change its description of the national accounts figures? Finally, could the minister advise how Australia's growth, as reported in the national accounts, compares with that of other OECD countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the last point, I think the OECD table shows Turkey at five per cent and Australia next in the list. What has to be said is that Turkey is coming off a very low base. So among the economies in the OECD that are comparable to Australia, we are in fact in the lead, and that means we are in the lead over the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain and the other European economies. That is a good performance from Australia. They are all comparable Western economies.

PARA.TAB: I was asked: would the government wish to change its characterisation of the quarterly national accounts? Nothing in the media commentary that has come out today would cause us to want to do that. Nothing has come forward to criticise how we have, in a sober and considered way, characterised the outcome of the national accounts figures yesterday. In fact, all of the commentary has supported that.

We ought not overvalue the outcome. There are of course still challenges and the government is committed to continuing the serious job of managing the recovery properly. Nor should we undervalue the outcome of the national accounts figures yesterday. It was unmitigated good news. Importantly, as an important trading nation in the world, Australia has performed better than its major trading partners which is, as anyone would know, a hard thing to do.

I am asked what the commentators have said about that. I turn to a run down of the headlines in the newspapers today. Most of it is reported front page news with the economic columnists expressing their views about the national account figures, too. The Australian Financial Review led with the headline:

ANSWER.PARA: Economy runs hot, inflation falls flat
Its economic writer, Steve Burrell, said:
The good news: growth without inflation
The Australian newspaper had the headline:
Growth surge to 4pc leads the Western world.
Its economic commentator, Alan Wood, said:
Markets can forget runaway inflation fears
The Melbourne Age, had a small headline:
Business snatch the spoils of a burgeoning economy
Its economic writer, Tim Colebatch, in a box on the front page, said:
"These are good figures. They confirm that the recovery has accelerated to cruising speed. They squash any fears that inflation is about to rebound."
Its economic writer, Ross Gittins, in his feature opinion piece, said:

The Canberra Times, the Adelaide Advertiser, the Courier-Mail—even the West Australian, which hit it on page 12—the Herald-Sun and the Sydney Telegraph all have very positive, upbeat reports of the quarterly national account figures.

PARA.TAB: However, I am asked in this question to comment on what the commentators have said. I am sad to report that one commentator, who is frequently reported, has panned the outcome, describing it as `threatening a boom-bust cycle in Australia'. That commentator is the shadow Treasurer, Alexander Downer. It seems that his commentary is the only one that is out of step with the huge body of opinion that welcomes these figures and recognises the importance of them. Mr Downer, in one of his speeches, said:

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed over the last two weeks there is serious concern in the markets about Labor's economic management—
in the face of these figures, one wonders where he gets that from—
. . . and the danger of rising inflation and interest rates.

All of these commentators have said that the inflation stick has been broken and that the skittishness that we have seen in the markets is apparently not justified in anticipating interest rates. This is a negative comment. It reflects the view of the opposition that good news for Australia is bad news for the opposition. It is consistent of Mr Downer. On the eve of the Fremantle by-election he tried to scare the markets with irresponsible comment, and on the eve of the Bonython by-election he is trying to do exactly the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of the OECD report on the causes of and remedies for unemployment, will the minister categorically rule out disincentives to job creation such as a jobs levy? Will he assist the states to abandon payroll taxes which the OECD report condemns as `driving a wedge between the cost to the employer of hiring a worker and the wage received by the worker'? What steps will the government take in its forthcoming employment-industry statement to remove the impediments to job creation that the OECD report identified?

—The only time Senator Short will find out these things is if he comes and sits in the Expenditure Review Committee, or the cabinet itself, and is part and parcel of the process of budget formulation. There is a long, long way to go before Senator Short can remotely contemplate having any such opportunity. He does not have it now and he is not going to get any further information from us at this stage of the budget process.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of all the concerns expressed by the OECD and most other observers, if not this government, about the cost of job creation schemes, will the minister confirm the estimates in the recent evaluation of the local government capital works program that only 46 per cent of the jobs involved went to unemployed people, and therefore only 1,600 unemployed people were given a job, and that the cost of each of those jobs was $286,000 per person?

—I am not familiar with those figures and I am certainly not going to confirm them off the top of my head without seeing the context in which Senator Short is quoting them. As to the OECD report, of course we will take that into account, as well as the policy prescriptions that flow from it. But it is not a time to be making any pronouncements about what we will be finally doing, as Senator Short well knows.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health and refers to the importation of a prohibited import, the French-manufactured drug RU486, for trial on Australian women. As a result of questions, both at a Senate estimates committee and in the Senate, is it not a fact that official undertakings were given that this prohibited import would not be given an exemption by the secretary to the department of health without the involvement of the minister? Was the minister or Senator Crowley involved in this decision to grant exemption for this prohibited import? If not, why did the secretary to the minister's department act in contravention of a clear undertaking given to me as a result of questions in the Senate and in a Senate estimates committee?

—I did discuss this matter with Senator Harradine on Monday. Since then I have been making some inquiries about this, because it is a serious matter. I will go through the arrangements as they occurred and then answer some of the specific questions that Senator Harradine asked. Last Friday I became aware of reports that two clinical trials of RU486 were to be carried out in Australia. The clinical trials, under the auspices of the World Health Organisation, are being conducted under the clinical trial notification scheme, CTN, which was announced by the minister in February 1991, with necessary regulations made in May 1991.

PARA.TAB: Under the scheme, sponsors may proceed with trials, provided they have the endorsement of the relevant institutional ethics committee and they notify the TGA. TGA approval is not actually required for the trial to take place. The TGA was notified of the trial last week, in accordance with these arrangements, and approved the importation of the drug for the trials. I doubt that a refusal to allow importation of the drug would have been sustainable, given that the trial was legitimate under the CTN arrangements.

The drug RU486 has been made available on a number of occasions since 1991 under the special access scheme. Applications have been approved for its use eight times: five for cancer—meningioma brain cancer and adrenal cancer—and three for the expulsion of dead foetuses. The present clinical trials are for both termination of pregnancy and post-coital contraception—the so-called morning-after pill. I am advised that an increased dosage of the standard oral contraceptive pill has been used for this purpose for some time by family planning associations. It is important to understand that the current trials, which are limited to 300 patients, are being conducted under the auspices of the World Health Organisation, and the drug is being supplied by that organisation.
Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know. The company Roussel is not involved. The trials are being oversighted by the ethics committees of the institutions involved, as required under the CTN scheme, and no application for general marketing approval has been lodged by the company for the drug. That said, when Senator Harradine drew to my attention the question of an undertaking given to him, I caused a check of the department's records to take place. It is clear that an undertaking was given to Senator Harradine, probably in 1988, to the effect that the minister would certainly be involved in any decision taken to approve clinical trials.

PARA.TAB: As it turns out, as I understand the situation, the official approval for the importation of the drug, and hence for the trials to begin, was given on Wednesday of last week. Senator Crowley's office—Senator Crowley is the minister responsible for the TGA—was notified on Friday, two days later. The reason is that, since the undertaking was given to Senator Harradine, there have been changes to those clinical trial arrangements. I have discussed this with Senator Crowley briefly, because an undertaking was given to Senator Harradine that clearly has been breached—I do not try to run away from that—obviously because none of us knew about it; it was some years ago with different ministers and different public servants. We will discuss the matter to see whether there is something we can do, even this late in the piece, to honour that undertaking.

—There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the government expect the public to find it credible that a seasoned media groupie and regular Fairfax visitor such as Senator Loosley would suddenly choose to ask for a familiarisation tour of the Fairfax plant just before those editors were about to give evidence to the inquiry? Is it true that Senator Loosley, unlike Senator Alston, discussed not only the print media inquiry but also the evidence to be given by certain witnesses?

—I am sure that Senator Loosley would be touched by Senator Ellison's description of him as a seasoned media groupie. I certainly know him as a man of honour and integrity and someone who would not under any circumstances get involved in the kind of squalid conversation that comes so naturally to the opposition's short-term acting leader in the Senate today.

—The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy would be aware of rapidly expanding markets for imported foods into Asia. Can he advise the Senate what steps the government is taking to ensure that Australian food producers take full advantage of the opportunities emerging in Asia?

—The continuing rapid expansion of the Asian economies is providing Australia with very significant opportunities for the sale of Australian goods and services into that area. For example, the Asian market for imported processed food will triple over this decade to $200 billion, involving 80 million customers.

PARA.TAB: The government has recognised that Australia's natural resource advantages and its very sophisticated technologies—they are well-recognised internationally—in food production could be more effectively exploited to take advantage of the emerging opportunities in Asia. This was the primary motivation for the establishment of the Agri-Food Council in 1992. It comprises industry leaders in the food sector, which Senator Cook and I now jointly chair.

I acknowledge the very significant contribution that was made to the agribusiness programs of the government by Mr John Allwright, a past president of the National Farmers Federation, who died recently. It was mentioned at a meeting of farm management people that I went to this morning that his extensive knowledge and very deep commitment to agricultural development will be sadly missed by the agribusiness board of which he was a member.

The purpose of the Agri-Food Council is to bring all the various elements of the food production, marketing and processing chain closer together. The council is seeking to identify impediments to the sectoral integration and expansion of this industry, particularly into export markets. The Agri-Food Council will have its fifth meeting tomorrow in Sydney. Senator Cook and I will be chairing that meeting.

Items on the agenda at the meeting of the council will include strategies on regulatory reform and quality in food production; problems in the transportation of food; the whole question of food packaging and its costs for exporters; and progress in developing more effective relationships between growers and processors in particular regions. The council will also receive progress reports from subcommittees on both workplace reform and industry innovation.

Another initiative that the government has recently set in train is the development of a paper to be presented to the Prime Minister's Science and Engineering Council on food into Asia. A working party is now being formed to investigate the role that science and engineering in Australia can play in developing an efficient and high quality food export industry in Australia. The working party will be made up of representatives from industry, export marketing, research and agricultural production and will present its paper to the Prime Minister's committee in the middle of this year. These two initiatives, together with the growing recognition in the industry of the great potential for Australia in Asia, will result in the expansion of food exports towards the Agri-Food Council goal of $7 billion by the end of this decade.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The coalition is very pleased to see increased economic growth and an annual growth rate of four per cent, but we are very concerned

QUESTION.PARA: that business investment has gone down by 12 1/2 per cent on a seasonally adjusted basis and that national household savings are at an all-time low.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you made up your mind yet?
—Order! Senator Faulkner!
—May I start again?
—You may.

—Can he explain to the Senate how economic recovery can be sustained when business investment and household savings continue to go backwards? Does he agree that unless the budget deficit for 1994-95 is between $8 billion and $10 billion, interest rates will rise and we will see a repeat of the boom-bust cycle which this government has become an expert at creating?

—The substantial content of Senator Gibson's question is about interest rates and I propose to answer some of those points. However, I think it is appropriate to make the observation to begin with that this question echoes the scaremongering that Alexander Downer, the shadow Treasurer, has tried to engage in.
—Haven't you read what the serious economic commentators have said today?

—I have read what the serious economic commentators have said today. I quoted them earlier in an answer to a question from Senator Colston. None of the commentators favoured the type of comment that Senator Short would be partial to and none of them supported the allegations of Mr Downer, which are reflected in this question. All of them said that the inflation stick was broken, that we were cruising in the recovery and that we had strong sustainable growth. They all said that we are at the head of the OECD table as well.

PARA.TAB: One of the elements in the quarterly accounts that have caused some commentary is, of course, the issue of investment. While there was no contribution to growth from total business investment in the December quarter, plant and equipment investment did record modest growth. New plant and equipment investment increased by one per cent seasonally adjusted in the December quarter, further underlying plant and equipment investment increased by almost three per cent in the calendar year 1993 compared with the calendar year 1992.

It must be said that business expectations for investment spending continue to improve. There is no doubt where business expectations are. That was commented on positively in the editorial in today's Australian newspaper, which I commend to Senator Gibson. Business expectations suggest that, as capacity constraints emerge, business investments will pick up in the course of 1994.

There is a range of economic fundamentals which continue to produce a favourable environment for a pick up in plant and equipment investment over the course of 1994. Let me mention some of those fundamentals. Cash flows and corporate profits have been improving steadily since mid-1991. The ABS measure of profit share of GDP has risen to 17.7 per cent in the December quarter—the highest since the September quarter 1985. The constraint imposed by balance sheet restructuring for major corporations appears to have eased substantially over the past year, with gearing ratios having returned to more normal levels. Inflation, of course, still remains low and capacity utilisation picked up sharply in the December quarter. Add to that business confidence—

TALK.START.PARA: —You quoted wrong figures.
—I did not quote wrong figures.
—You did so.
—I did not quote wrong figures, Senator.
—You got the investment figures wrong.

—I did not get my capacity figures wrong. There has been a substantial pick up in capacity utilisation in the December quarter. There is still some spare capacity in the economy. One expects—with a high profit share and the high earnings ratio of companies—that with further pick up in capacity utilisation there will be an increase in investment in the next part of the year. That is the expectation echoed by the surveys of business confidence. That is the expectation that we have and it is an encouragement that we give to businesses with their higher profits to now invest substantially in the economy. They are the appropriate things. This is not something over which there ought to be the sort of alarmist rhetoric that is coming from the opposition; it is something which we would expect, in the normal economic cycle, to manifest itself.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. But I remind him and the Senate of a fact that was in an editorial in this morning's Australian:

PARA.TAB: To keep the momentum going, much will depend on the Government. If it is to avoid the sins of laziness and short-termism, the May Budget will have to hold the tight line on deficit reduction.

QUESTION.PARA: Alan Wood wrote in his article:
. . . for quite a while yet, provided the Government accepts the need for fiscal restraint.
The Financial Review this morning stated:

PARA.TAB: All the more reason why Mr Keating should now take advantage of the economy's unexpected strength and . . . cuts to the structural deficit.

QUESTION.PARA: In the Sydney Morning Herald the composition of growth was described as `lopsided and unsustainable'. Max Walsh, who also writes for the Sydney Morning Herald, stated this morning:
Is the government going to adopt a fiscally responsible budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is, of course; we have always done so. The answer is also that if the opposition had conducted itself responsibly in the last budget debate, we would have been able to get our budget through and the medium-term deficit reduction program that we had in view would have been put in place a lot sooner. Had the opposition got its way in the last budget debate we would have pushed the deficit up, which would have been a terribly irresponsible thing to do. I was not able to follow all of the editorials being quoted but the first was an editorial in the Australian. When Senator Gibson quotes editorials he ought to reflect all of the contents of them. The Australian also said in that editorial today:

ANSWER.PARA: As business surveys keep telling us, investment will pick up over the rest of this year and next.

There is no joy there for Senator Gibson's argument, but there is total support for what I said in the first part of my answer to this question. In the context of all of the indicators, it is a responsible comment and one I suggest he pay some attention to and stop trying to be alarmist about the economy.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Vanstone

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 203, which states:

PARA.TAB: (1) If a Senator:
(e) persistently and wilfully disregards the authority of the Chair . . .

INTERJECT.PARA: I have given up counting how many times today you have felt it necessary to call Senator Faulkner to order. How many times do you need to do that before this standing order occurs to you?

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: it was only about a year ago that Senator Alston defied the chair for a full two hours when he was asked to withdraw. Maybe he would like to contribute to this point of order.

—If I were to apply the sorts of standards Senator Vanstone is suggesting, I would be naming a lot more senators than Senator Faulkner. I have warned Senator Faulkner a couple of times and I ask him not to interject any further.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to tensions on the Korean peninsula, and to efforts by the international community to have the DPRK observe the framework of a global nuclear regime. What is the significance of likely setbacks in the implementation of nuclear safeguards in North Korea? In the process of dialogue on this issue, what is the assessment of the Australian government?

—The director of the International Atomic Energy Agency yesterday reported to the IAEA board of governors that agency inspectors were prevented from carrying out some essential safeguards activities in North Korea. As a result, the agency was not in a position to verify that there had been no diversion of nuclear material for weapons purposes since inspections were halted by the DPRK last year.

PARA.TAB: This is a serious and disturbing development which again calls into question North Korea's commitment to peace and stability in North-East Asia, to a nuclear weapons free Korean peninsula, and to defining a negotiated settlement of the nuclear issue. We regret particularly that the DPRK chose to obstruct the IAEA's inspection activities after earlier having agreed in detail with the agency on the range of activities that inspectors would be allowed to conduct. This agreement had been reached as part of an initial package of steps leading to the resumption of high level talks with the United States.

The DPRK has been well aware that such obstruction would require action by the IAEA board of governors. That board will consider the matter at a full special session on 21 March under Australian chairmanship. That meeting is likely to result as a first step in the adoption of a resolution expressing the board's deep concern at these developments and calling for the DPRK's full cooperation.

In this environment we hope that Pyongyang will reconsider its position and allow IAEA inspectors to return to North Korea to complete the agreed schedule of activities. Completion of the inspections and progress in North Korea's dialogue with the South were the two conditions set down by the US for holding the third round of its own high level talks with the DPRK. Without progress on these fronts, there seems to be little prospect of dialogue proceeding constructively in the near future. As a result of these developments, the DPRK is likely to face stronger international action, including the possibility of action by the UN Security Council.

Finally, the Prime Minister and I have both recently made very clear the seriousness of this issue for Australia's and the region's security interests. I reiterate now Australia's commitment to dialogue and negotiation as the best way of resolving this issue. But we would also support action by the Security Council should this become necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Prime Minister remember telling me on 2 March that, in the context of its existing high level of indebtedness of $25 million or so, the viability of the Prime Minister's $430,000 piggery investment `may well depend upon its capacity to engage in a major expansion exercise', which is part of an $80 million joint venture with a Danish multinational company. Will the minister explain why such an expansion exercise, requiring an unprecedented prime ministerial level of debt along with governmental approvals by federal, state and local government, does not present the Prime Minister with the potential for a significant conflict of interest? Why does the minister keep saying that there is no such potential for conflict of interest in this investment?

—The main thing I can remember telling Senator Baume early in March is that this was none of his business unless he could come up with something more than hypothetical speculation about possible elaborate and complicated scenarios that might, under certain contingencies—if X and Y and Z were the case—produce some possible conceivable conflict of interest. That is not the way to respond sensitively, sensibly and properly as a senator in this place. To do that sort of thing, which Senator Baume has been engaged in for months on end, is to engage, as I have said so often before, on a trawling fishing expedition, with both arms right down in the middle of the grease barrel, poking and scraping around to try to find something to throw at someone. He has not succeeded at all in the past when he has been down inside that particular grease barrel. He has not succeeded in the context of AQIS—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. What we have had to date are clear personal reflections on Senator Baume. You ought to bring the minister to order. The question was not hypothetical. The question asked very specifically—and I quote the minister's own words—about the Prime Minister's `capacity to engage in a major expansion exercise'. They are specific matters that deserve a specific answer; they do not deserve personal denigration.
—I believe the reflections are two-way, but I ask the minister to avoid as much as possible personal reflections in his answer.

—I have been avoiding it as much as possible. It was just not possible to avoid saying as much as I did. There is quite a lot more to be said about Senator Baume's motivations and there is quite a lot more to be said about the effectiveness of his performance on this matter. For nearly a year he has been arousing spectres of breach of public interest and breach of private—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. This is a deliberate act of defiance of the chair. You have just told the minister not to engage in that conduct and, in three separate ways, he has defied you. I invite you to order him to answer the specific aspects of the question.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The point that Senator Alston made in taking that point of order obviously is something that this chamber has to address. It also has to address the double standards that have been shown in the debate and the reflections that have been taken on individuals who are not members of this place and who have not been members of other places. Senator Alston cannot have it both ways. If he is going to give it out he is going to have to get it back.

—Senator McKiernan has made his point. There is no point of order. As I have indicated before, there are reflections being thrown around in this place in both directions that are inappropriate in this chamber. I ask the minister to come to the point of the answer.

—The short point is simply that the nature of the Prime Minister's interests in that particular commercial venture are clearly on the public record. The nature of the possible expansion of that enterprise is a matter of clear public record and endless public debate and speculation. The Prime Minister does stand to benefit as a shareholder in that company, in the event that that company succeeds commercially. To state that is to state no more than the supremely, self-evidently obvious.

PARA.TAB: There is no question of secret deals. There is no question of misuse of prime ministerial authority to get special exemptions or special treatment in relation to any of the environmental or other issues that may well determine the expansion of that particular business. The Prime Minister has exactly the same kind of economic interest that from time immemorial has been held by ministers on the coalition's side of politics. Those opposite are full of double standards, hypocrisy and nonsense on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question related to whether there was a potential for conflict of interest. There is no evidence or even any suggestion that any other prime minister while in office has ever undertaken such a huge debt on which the capacity for repayment has depended on governmental approvals. Will the minister explain why Mr Keating's own criteria of conflict of interest, contained in his attack on the late Sir Phillip Lynch—high borrowings and the need for council approvals—over Sir Phillip's family company's relatively modest development in which he had a positive equity, do not apply to Mr Keating, whose piggery group has liabilities, for years has depended for survival on the support of its government-owned banker and depends on the granting of governmental approvals for its viability?

—Senator Baume has a hide coming in here raising these sorts of issues when he has hidden for the last seven years behind his own party's refusal to approve the establishment of a pecuniary interest register in this place—and did everything conceivably possible to filibuster his way out of being in a position to put his interests on the record.

—Mr President, I take a point of order on the issue of relevance. This was a very clear question from Senator Baume about the potential for Mr Keating to have a conflict of interest because of his investment. I ask you once again to direct Senator Evans to come to the question and cut out the personal abuse.
—In the cut and thrust of this chamber and with the nature of the questions that are being asked, I do not regard it as being out of order for Senator Evans to digress a little.

—Mr President, on a point of order: in relation to your ruling, could you indicate whether you think the standing orders relating to casting reflections on members entitle you to make an assessment of whether that is fair cricket, because you make an assessment of the nature of the question that was asked. You might consider whether you have this personal choice that you keep referring to about what you think about a question asked, and whether you think someone needs protection or not. I put it to you that the standing orders do not give you that personal choice. I invite you to come back later and explain what you have just said.
—I thought that was exactly what I was here for; to be an arbiter of those things. That is what I am asked for in points of order.
—You are here to follow the standing orders, not make up your own damn mind!
—Order! I call Senator Bourne.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Has the minister seen this week's media report suggesting that Australia is set to resume defence contacts with Burma's illegal military regime? Does this signal a change in Australia's longstanding policy of reducing links with Burma in light of that country's appalling human rights record? What guarantees can the minister provide that defence links with Burma will not be resumed until phenomenal progress is made in that country?

—The Australian government has no intention of resuming defence links with Burma. Indeed, I think I agree with the implication of Senator Bourne's question in that, given its human rights record, Burma is certainly not deserving of any substantial defence links at this stage. I can give her a guarantee that unless its human rights record improves we certainly will not be having such things as defence exports or military to military links.

PARA.TAB: I think some of those press reports probably came out of the esoteric decision to re-establish the accreditation of a defence attache, but that person's role is merely to report back to us what the regime is doing and what the military is doing. It is not there for defence links between the two countries. I think it is an erroneous view that has been in the press. I can guarantee that we will not re-establish the normal sort of regional defence relationships with Burma until it has a massive improvement in its human rights record.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. With reference to his press release last night on tax file numbers and disability pensions, why did disabled veterans have to suffer for so long?
