Why did he take so long to act when, by his own press release, the powers are within his hands to get rid of this nonsense?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have recently received a range of representations from veterans who are in receipt of a disability pension only and who have complained about the necessity to provide a tax file number to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I have also spoken personally, of course, to a number of veterans about this issue.

PARA.TAB: I will try to spell this out in monosyllables for Senator MacGibbon. As minister, I do not have the discretionary power under the Veterans' Entitlements Act to grant disability pensioners, or any other Veterans' Affairs beneficiaries, exemptions from the requirement to provide tax file numbers. Under the legislation, discretion lies with the secretary to my department.

It is also illegal and improper for me to direct the secretary to exercise a discretionary power in a particular way on individual cases. But, because I have received a number of submissions on this matter, I have asked the secretary to the department to sympathetically re-examine the discretionary guidelines that he established in 1991 in the light of those submissions. In asking him to look at that matter, I emphasise that I do not expect the secretary to provide exemptions which effectively cut across the fraud detection measures the government has set in place. The secretary has agreed to do this as quickly as possible and he will be reporting back to me.

As background for Senator MacGibbon, who obviously has a very limited understanding of this matter, the tax file number enables accurate matching of data across agencies such as Social Security to ensure that people are receiving correct payments and to eliminate duplicate or other unlawful payments. I think a number of people, including some senators, have obviously overlooked that the DVA disability pension is considered as income for pension purposes by the Department of Social Security. The tax file number is used in the data matching process to ensure the correct identification of those in receipt of both payments. It could be possible, for instance, for a person with a similar name to the disability pensioner to be unnecessarily inconvenienced by the need to provide further information to prove that he or she is not that person and is not receiving dual payments.

The use of the tax file number eliminates that problem. More than 250 cases have been detected to date where people had not disclosed their disability pension payments to the Department of Social Security and, as a result, were overpaid DSS pensions. Savings of $110 million from data matching across all agencies were reported to this parliament in 1993. The actual gross savings in program outlays achieved for the first half of the financial year by the Department of Veterans' Affairs are some $2 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Overlooking the fact that the minister committed suicide with his own tongue when he admitted that the contents of his press release were correct as I quoted them, that he directed the secretary to review the conditions under which tax file numbers led to the restriction of the disability pension, and given the great distress this has caused disabled veterans in Australia, some of whom have been denied a pension they are entitled to for over 12 months, why was it not proceeded with earlier? Why were other authorities, like the Department of Social Security, not required to obtain the tax file number when granting an age pension or one of those other benefits? Why were they not tasked with getting the tax file number when the disability pension is a right for a pensioner who has served this country and disabled himself in the service of the country with respect to the normal enjoyment of his life? Once he qualifies for that pension he is entitled to have it. He is not entitled to be harassed and treated as a criminal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what Senator MacGibbon had for lunch but it has obviously affected him very badly indeed. Under the legislation, it is up to the secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to make decisions about any extra exemptions—and there are many now. It would be improper for me to try to pre-empt the advice that he will give me. I have asked him to sympathetically look at the representations that have been made and give full consideration to all the issues that are involved. It seems to me that where disability pensioners have proof that their other income—for example, from DSS pensions—would rule them out, those may be examples of appropriate cases for exemption.

PARA.TAB: But properly and appropriately I will wait for advice from my department, and that is how it will occur. I believe that any fair-minded person would accept that that is a perfectly reasonable and proper process, and a legal process in the circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Panizza asked me, in my capacity as representing the Minister for Administrative Services, a question about rifle ranges. I have an answer to that question, and with the leave of the Senate, I seek to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Panizza asked the Minister for Administrative Services, without notice, on 16 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: What method is the department using in the disposal of (rifle) ranges and what, if any, preference is given to an established rifle club or clubs that have been using those ranges for many years—up to 100 years?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Government's general policy on disposal of any surplus Commonwealth property is that it is sold on the open market. In relation to rifle ranges, however, because of the historical relationship between shooting clubs and the Commonwealth the individual cases are considered prior to a decision being taken on the appropriate method of disposal. Arrangements have varied in individual cases from direct sale to a club, sale to a State Government which has allowed the continuation of shooting and sale on the open market. If the Senator has a particular property in mind I am happy to take the details and seek a response from the Department of Administrative Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Chamarette asked me a supplementary question in respect of McArthur River and I have an answer to that. Information on environmental aspects of the project was provided yesterday. The matter of native title and the McArthur River project fall within the responsibility of the Special Minister of State, Mr Frank Walker MP.

PARA.TAB: However, I have been supplied with the following information in response to Senator Chamarette's question on native title. I am advised that the Yanyuwa people have yet to lodge a claim with the Native Title Tribunal for native title in the Bing Bong area. The validation and regranting of the McArthur River leases and exploration licence, including the lease of Bing Bong under the McArthur River Project and Ratification Amendment Act 1993 in no way impairs the Yanyuwa's ability to claim native title.

If the regranting and validation of the lease has constituted an acquisition of native title, the Yanyuwa have a statutory right to compensation under Northern Territory law against the Northern Territory government.

On 12 March 1994 the Special Minister of State and the Borroloola Aboriginal community, represented by nine traditional owners, met in Borroloola to sign the McArthur River agreement. The signature on the deed in no way inhibits the Yanyuwa pursuing environmental concerns, or from pursuing applications for the termination of native title.
I am advised that dredging associated with the barge loading facility will all be within the mining lease area at the Bing Bong facility. No dredging is required outside the lease area.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time yesterday Senator Herron asked me how I could justify the expenditure of $9 million on the caucus-ACTU working party, examining my private health insurance reform proposals, and why we had allocated 15 staff to the working party. I said at the time that I was staggered that he could ask a question like that, given the answer that I had given to Senator Lees, but I will give this answer anyway.

PARA.TAB: The bulk of the money will be allocated to consultants and departmental staff to develop policy and examine technical issues. I note that officers of my department have undertaken to provide more detail of those consultancies to Estimates Committee C. The fact is that none of the $8.9 million has been used to support the caucus-ACTU working party.

In the hospitals and Medicare programs my department has provided two staff members to assist the working party in collating and analysing submissions—one at senior officer grade C level for eight weeks, and one graduate administrative assistant for four weeks. In addition, the department has paid airfares for one of those officers and a member of the caucus committee's secretariat who is providing administrative support for the working party. The cost of those airfares to date, for three trips to Melbourne and one to Sydney, is $3,126, not $9 million. The only other expenses paid by the department would be for postage and coffee and I have not got the costs of those yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about biscuits?

—I am not sure whether we provided biscuits. The department has not met any of the costs of travel or accommodation for any members of the working party, and so far has not bought them lunch—although I am thinking of doing so.

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron was aware of how the money would, in fact, be spent when he asked his question. In estimates on Tuesday he heard Senator Newman ask a series of questions on this matter. A moment later at that hearing he referred to my answer to Senator Lees and asked about the $2 million of the $9 million which was to be spent on studying costings for DRGs. His next question led to an admission by a departmental officer that some of the consultancies cannot be let until after the working party has reported, yet he still asked a question on how we are spending $9 million on the working party. That is what is called a pathetic effort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 25(12)(b)(i) I give notice that, on the next day of sitting I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report:
Taxation of Financial Arrangements—Consultative document issued by the Treasurer (December 1993).
(2)That during the inquiry consideration be given to the following matters:

TAB.TAB: (a)the adequacy of the existing law under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to bring to assessment on an appropriate basis income and gains arising from financial arrangement and, in particular, the synchronisation of treatment between taxpayers;

(b)the adequacy of the existing law under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to deal with the deductibility of costs and expenses associated with the entering into financial arrangements and, in particular, the synchronisation of treatment between taxpayers;
(c)the impact on business of the proposed initiatives contained in the Consultative document and, in particular:
(i)the taxing of certain financial arrangements on an unrealised basis, including foreign exchange gains and losses,
(ii)the introduction of a compound accruals method of calculating income from financial arrangements, and
(iii)the direct and indirect costs involved; and
(d)whether the proposed initiatives are compatible with tax simplification.

SPEECH.PARA: (3)That the terms of reference of the inquiry be advertised in the press in the usual way.
(4)That written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard in public, including oral evidence from the authors of the more important submissions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ellison this day, relating to the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in relation to the Print Media.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans raised one or two issues which ought to be canvassed by the chamber this afternoon, just as they were debated yesterday, and as I am sure we will continue to debate them in the lead-up to 4 May and the tabling of the report.

PARA.TAB: We now have an absolutely classic circumstance in the Senate of double standards operating—standards of office for the government, standards of high farce for the coalition. By the time the print media committee is finished, it will be remembered as the worst select committee ever created by the Australian Senate. In large measure, that is a testament to the person who chairs it. We now have a situation in which he is sustained only by a casting vote both in the chair and in his method of operation by which the committee operates behind a closed door, and by which material is not released or published.

A series of rhetorical questions might be asked at this time. Where is the legal advice to the committee? Why has it not been published? Why has it not been released? When is it going to be made available?
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am asking questions. This is another example of the classic double standards. Senator Alston says to the government, `Release material about the private meetings and I will have you before the Privileges Committee' just before he walks out to do a press conference. If that is not a double standard, what on earth is? Last night there was a press conference up in the press gallery. The other night in the chamber Senator Alston complained about people making available the details of private meetings. He said this should be referred to the Privileges Committee. Last night, after the committee finished, he did a press conference. Where is the complaint about that?

PARA.TAB: One can work on the simple basis that it is impossible for a chairman to do a press conference by way of the doorstop upstairs without talking in some detail about what happened immediately prior to his arrival. That is what happened last night, and I will be interested in his response as to why it happened like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is allowed to say what his decisions are.

—If he is allowed to do that, the entire subcommittee ought to be operating openly. To use Senator Kernot's expression, there ought to be a greater degree of openness. There ought not to be deals made behind closed doors and there ought not to be material suppressed. It is going to be absolutely fascinating when the legal advice is released later this week, or next week, or perhaps in the week that the actual report is published. What is the legal advice going to say? What is it going to say on public interest immunity, for example? What is it going to say on category one documents? What is it going to say on FIRB advice, on Treasury advice? It will be absolutely fascinating not only to see what it says, but also to know why it was not published as a consequence of last night's meeting. Why was it not published?

PARA.TAB: People can quite legitimately, deliberately and reasonably draw their own conclusions as to why this material is not in the public domain right now, why the committee has to seek legal advice on another single point, and why more public money is being spent. The circumstances of this committee are that it has descended into an absolute and utter farce. More is to come; there is no question about that.

Before this committee is finished, we will see it labelled, without fear of contradiction, the worst select committee ever created by the Australian Senate. This, of course, is in a circumstance where the government does not have the numbers, where the chair is held by a member of the opposition. And here he is: `Senator casting vote'. The casting vote is required for absolutely everything: it is required for suppression; it is required to keep you in existence. Senator Alston ought to become Senator cast-off rather than Senator casting vote.

Double standards exist. The double standards refer not only to the coalition in terms of high farce; they refer also to the circumstances where one side is told, `Release any of the details of the meeting and you will be before the privileges committee'. The circumstances were that the chairman then waltzed off to do his press conference. It was quite remarkable. The coalition has brought this committee to the point of absolute laughability. More is to come; watch this space.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, might I say that it was resolved at last night's meeting to make a public statement that further clarification was being sought in relation to the legal advice we had received. I remind government senators who were there last night that that was the case. It is a matter of fact. That was the decision—open and shut. The chairman, accordingly, made that statement.

PARA.TAB: I add that it is always open for a chairman of a committee to release statements on what the committee has decided. There has been no divulgence by the chairman of the content of the meeting. The honourable senator should take note that my question did not touch on the content of last night's meeting, which was a private meeting. My question touched on the activities of Senator Loosley, and prior activity. It is Senator Loosley who has upped the ante and wants to talk about the content of last night's meeting. It is Senator Loosley who asked, `Where is the legal advice? Why is it not published?'. That has been taken care of by the public statement, which was cleared by the committee, which said that we had received that advice and that it needed further clarification.

It is in the press today that government senators tried to close down the committee. Government senators are on record that that is what they want to do; they want to close down this committee of inquiry into what took place back in 1991 and 1993. They do not want the report of this committee to see the light of day. We all know that there are very good reasons for it. Senator Loosley himself has referred to this committee as a witch-hunt. Nonetheless, I can see no breach of privilege in what the chairman has done. He released a statement which had been authorised by the committee, and there is no problem in—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who drafted it?

—The question of who drafted it is irrelevant. It was a draft which was approved by the committee and was accordingly released in a proper manner. I would suggest to honourable senators that it is the government senators who want to discredit this committee. They want to discredit it at every turn. They have taken the opportunity to do so whenever they can. One has only to look at the press today to see how they have leaked matters to the media in respect of what took place.
—What about your backgrounding?

—I have not spoken to any members of the press, and I challenge Senator Carr to prove it, because I have not. I took particular care in my question today not to traverse the contents of the meeting last night. I do not want to string this matter out any further, other than to say that quite clearly the government senators have an agenda and that agenda is to devalue the currency of this committee. Government senators will not succeed. This is a matter of vital public interest and importance. If government senators take care and read the press articles, they will see that the press of this country do think it is a very important inquiry and one which is worth while reporting.
—Did Senator Loosley clarify his position?

—I note Senator Alston's comment that Senator Loosley did not answer the question I put forward as to his visit to the Fairfax plant, or as to the need he saw to do that prior to those editors giving their advice. Nor did he tell us whether there was any discussion as to the evidence. I notice that all those aspects of my question went unanswered. I can only conclude from his acquiescence that he must be agreeing with me. When one asks a challenging question of that sort, one expects an answer or some sort of vigorous denial. But did we have any denial? We had none. Senator Loosley, in the chance he has just had to address the matter, has not done so. In the circumstances, I find that quite amazing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: I would like to comment on a number of aspects of the question, and the answer from Senator Evans. For Senator Campbell to be constantly interjecting when he was not at the meeting last night and is unaware of the events as they unfolded, he must have a remarkable knowledge. I am sure that he has been well informed by his colleagues.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, there is a clear distinction between Senator Loosley's actions and the actions of the chair. Senator Loosley was on an inspection of the plant. There is a world of difference between Senator Loosley inspecting a plant to talk to staff, and Senator Alston, who is chair of the committee and who is also responsible for opposition media policy, ringing up an editor and attempting to silence a journalist by putting pressure on that journalist through the editor. There is a significant difference. It is a very different case.

Secondly, we have had some reference to the casting vote being exercised last night because one of the senators was away. Last night when the meeting began we waited for 25 minutes. All four Labor members were there at the beginning of the meeting. The other, opposition, members dribbled in late. Out of courtesy and recognition of the balance on the committee, we waited until every opposition member, and Senator Kernot, could be there so that the debate could take place properly. We did not take advantage of our majority, which was a significant majority for a significant period of time. Also, on a number of occasions, or one occasion at least, Senator Alston had to leave the room to talk on the telephone—probably to the media, knowing Senator Alston—and again the government senators extended him the courtesy of allowing the committee to adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had been there for two hours.

—No, we had not been there for two hours at that point in time; it was about an hour and a quarter. That was not why the adjournment was extended. It was extended out of courtesy to Senator Alston. I highlight these points—
—Senator Kernot is very touchy because her voting record on this issue, particularly the suppression of the legal advice—
—That is totally untrue.
—I will get to that in a moment and Senator Kernot will have her chance to respond. Her record on this issue is getting dirtier and dirtier every day.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I know that there is normally a lot of latitude allowed in debate on motions to take note of answers to questions without notice, but the fact is that we are here discussing an answer given by Senator Evans to a question from Senator Ellison which related specifically to conversations that Senator Loosley had with two Fairfax editors in the lead-up to this inquiry—a pretty serious matter and very specific. It is not, in any shape or form, related to the events of last night.

PARA.TAB: We all know that Senator Loosley chose not to address those matters. I found that to be very significant. I certainly did not want to object whilst that performance was under way. But I ask you, Mr Deputy President, whether Senator Sherry is out of order in dealing with matters other than the subject matter, which is Senator Loosley and his discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: I would ask you to extend to me the same latitude you extended to Senator Ellison.

—Senator Alston, strictly speaking, your point of order should be upheld. There has been general latitude on both sides with respect to taking note of answers. I will talk to the President about it, but my inclination is to continue to allow reasonably wide debate. But I would ask all senators to recognise that they are trampling on the bounds of standing orders when they trespass past directing their remarks to the answer provided.

—On a further point of order, and on a separate matter: in addition to those transgressions we also heard in the last couple of minutes Senator Sherry accuse an honourable senator—in this case Senator Kernot—of having a dirty record. He also traversed a number of matters including votes of the committee. I do not know whether those votes are recorded in public minutes or not, but it seems that Senator Sherry in his zeal and zest may be getting very close to committing a possible contempt of that committee. I request, Mr Deputy President, that you direct his attention to both of those matters.
—Senator O'Chee, I heard what Senator Sherry said.
—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: for Senator O'Chee's information—
—What is your point of order?
—If Senator Campbell were not so rude and would give me half a minute, I would make it. The votes are on the public record. They have been recorded in minutes that go to the public record.

—In respect of the matters raised relating to Senator Sherry's comments about Senator Kernot's record, I thought it was vaguely tasteless but I noticed that Senator Kernot let it pass. I thought that was perhaps the best way to deal with it. I would dissuade you, Senator Sherry, from reflecting on the conduct of any of our colleagues.

—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy President. I am very happy to do that. Indeed, I would not respond in that way if Senator Kernot would contribute to the debate in the proper way, rather than by making a barrage of interjections which on at least one occasion I responded to. I made references to Senator Loosley and his contribution to this. I want to put the record straight, as some media reports—I do not know where they came from—made accusations of thuggery on this issue of Senator Loosley's purported behaviour. Again, I would like to say this for the record: I challenge Senator Kernot, through you, Mr Deputy President, to affirm that there was absolutely no element of thuggery about last night's meeting. There was some firm debate. The only time one senator rose from his seat was when Senator Murphy went to get a cup of tea.

PARA.TAB: Other than that, the debate was strong and firm on occasions, but there were no overbearing, offensive comments. I think last night's meeting, given the topic and the nature of the meeting, was actually held in remarkably reasonably good spirit. On occasions there was actually some reasonable humour. In fact, the tenor of the debate and the strength of the language were far less firm than we have heard here during this debate, so I do not believe that in any way the events could be referred to as thuggery.

We did have skulduggery from the opposition when it suppressed the legal advice. I have that advice here. If those opposite want to get further legal advice, why would they not release this legal advice? The answer is simple: they do not like what is in it. When this advice is released to the public it will show that the reasons they sought this legal advice have blown up in their faces. The advice does not provide them with the answer they wanted, so they have suppressed it—at a cost of about $6,000, with an additional cost for further legal advice. That is what the legal advice will show, and that is why those opposite want to continue to suppress it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish we were really addressing the content of the answer that we are supposed to be taking note of. I find it absolutely curious that the thrust of that answer has not been refuted. The person who talked most about double standards, Senator Loosley, is the person at the heart of Senator Ellison's question and Senator Evans's answer.

PARA.TAB: The question we asked was: why should Senator Loosley, in committee meetings and here in the chamber, spend so much time accusing Senator Alston of using his position as the committee chair in a way which reflects unfairly on the committee and its dealings with the terms of reference at the same time as he, Senator Loosley, as a member of that committee, is acknowledged by Fairfax editors to have been a visitor to the Fairfax building just prior to this committee inquiry? The double standard there is that Senator Loosley is on the record as having discussed the inquiry. The editors say the inquiry came up. In Senator Alston's case, the discussion was about the Liberal leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —And balance—what about balance?

—Senator Carr is absolutely wrong about balance. We have been over this so many times. The notion of balance came up as a flippant remark. Senator Carr should be able to understand how natural that would be. I cannot talk to him about balance, because I am not talking to him about this issue—I accept that interpretation.
—Was there thuggery last night?

—Senator Sherry talked about the conduct of last night's meeting. He used the word `thuggery' and asked me to confirm or deny it. I would say that, in my four years in this Senate, that was the worst committee meeting I have ever been to.
—Was there thuggery?

—I do not know what Senator Sherry's definition of thuggery is, but I am about to explain my view of it. The meeting oscillated between calm and rational debate and what I would call extreme vitriol, emotion and accusation. It was extremely unedifying.
—Any worse than in here?
—I think that, in the confines of a small room, and given the dynamics of the relationships between committee members, it was heaps worse than the worst debate in here.
—You are oversensitive.
—No; I just have different expectations of the behaviour of members of the Labor Party.
—Your halo is slipping.

—That is Senator Carr's impression. The only thing I will confirm is that he is on a mission to do something about the so-called halo; that is his job. The second part of his mission is to derail the committee. I listened very carefully last night. I thought Senator Murphy, who can conduct his arguments in a totally different way from Senator Carr, made some very salient points. But I reject the methods that Senator Carr used last night to attempt to persuade me to his point of view.
—You had made up your mind some time ago, Cheryl!

—That is a very unfair reflection. I went to that committee meeting last night, as I have made it perfectly clear, unsure of how to vote on the first matter that we discussed: the committee chairmanship. So I take great objection to Senator Carr's imputing that I had made up my mind in any way at all. I will confirm on the record that, as far as I am concerned—because I am not in the Labor Party; I do not operate in Sussex Street—the behaviour of some members of that committee last night amounted to what I understand to be thuggery and intimidation.

—I think it is very unfortunate that we have brought the Select Committee on Foreign Ownership Decisions in the Print Media to the stage where we are seen to be running it by question and answer in this chamber. Some of the processes we have been through have been very difficult because some of the issues that this committee is dealing with are very sensitive. I thought that after last night the committee might go back to conducting itself in a way in which we would not be confronting—certainly not the very next day—a question regarding the propriety or integrity of a member of the committee.

PARA.TAB: Given the exercise that we have been through over the past few days, I also have difficulty with the way in which some of these matters are being reported in the press. We cannot always determine that, depending on who says what. With regard to some of the questions and views that have been expressed here today about some of the decisions that were taken by the committee, these matters have not been accurately reflected in the media, particularly the issue of legal advice that was sought in a motion which I think was initially put forward by Senator Sandy Macdonald.

Legal advice was obtained. Whether it suited some members of the committee and not others is not the matter in point. The government members of the committee sought to have that advice published so that people could make a judgment on it one way or another. But that was not to be. I think the decision taken by the committee was that Senator Kernot move a motion to issue a public statement with regard to a decision of the committee to seek further advice. This motion was carried by a majority vote. But that was not reported in the press. The government members of the committee have had great concern about this matter.

I go back to my initial point. It is very unfortunate for this committee now to be basically conducting its business by way of question and answer. I think this brings the integrity and propriety of the committee into disrepute. Regardless of the respective political views of members of the committee, there are some issues on which all members have sought to bring about some change with regard to operations, particularly in those areas that go to the Foreign Investment Review Board.

I hope that the question which was asked today is the last of its type to be asked in this chamber, because it will destroy this committee. It is pointless to ask those sorts of questions. When Senator Carr asked questions yesterday, the same course of action was taken by those opposite; they were jumping up and down about the reputation of the committee and the members of the committee—yet today the same process has continued. It is about time we took a really hard look at ourselves and stopped this sort of nonsense because it is not doing anybody all that much good.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just don't like it when the shoe is on your foot.

—We do like it. If we analyse the circumstances of this situation, we find a real question about the chairmanship of this committee and whether or not the chairman is able to act in an impartial way. He has not, and that is a fact. But it is pointless to come into this place and ask questions. I say to Senator Ellison quite frankly that, after last night's exercise, I do not think it was a very wise thing to do.

—I support the motion to take note of Senator Gareth Evans's answer to a question concerning Senator Loosley's lack of propriety with reference to the print media inquiry. In simple terms, people who live in glasshouses should not throw stones. Senator Loosley has been caught out—and caught out badly. This morning Senator Loosley described the different standards of propriety that apply to high office—in other words, to the government—and to high farce, which he said applied to the opposition.

PARA.TAB: In plain, simple terms, the Sydney Morning Herald editor, Milton Cockburn, and David Hickey have confirmed that Senator Loosley had visited the Herald building on the evening of 8 February to see how the newspaper was put together. What did Senator Loosley talk about? This is just a high farce. Here we have an established Fairfax contributor to the Sun-Herald visiting an established building and plant to see how the paper is put together. Senator Loosley has probably been sniffing around the paper and plant for 15 years. Senator Loosley, like the Hungarian count, oozing charm from every pore, would have oiled his way around the floor of the Broadway building for yonks. We can draw only one conclusion. Mr Cockburn is reported to have said that he could recall discussing the media inquiry—end of story; Senator Loosley has been caught out.

He said that the visit was simply to familiarise himself with the Fairfax operation and that he was not looking for political favours. Everywhere that Senator Loosley goes, everything he says is about politics and political favours. His whole reason for existing is to put himself or his party at political advantage. Certainly, if he can take short cuts for his political party, he does so. That is okay. Everybody knows where Senator Loosley is coming from, especially the media. They know him as `leaking Loosley' and that has been very much confirmed by the way he has performed in this committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the gallery.

—Yes, we should ask the gallery. It is very interested in this media inquiry, and it will get more interested. The more the Labor Party goes on about it, the more it squirms, the more it finds that it does not have control of this committee, the more pleasurable that becomes to the media and to us.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion Senator Loosley has been caught out. He has been shown to have behaved with a lack of propriety. He has been exposed by the media. I take the opportunity to remind Senator Loosley, who talks a lot about openness and fairness, about the Harris Daishowa contribution that he failed to declare when he was secretary of the New South Wales Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to quickly put on the record the reasons for some of my loud interjections on Senator Loosley. I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for three years, until the last parliament.
—You do not have to apologise.

—I am not apologising at all; not one little bit. I am going to show why Senator Loosley displayed such double standards and hypocrisy here today. He spent quite some time explaining why Senator Alston was saved by his own casting vote. This, of course, reflected on Senator Alston, as Senator Loosely intended. Two obvious questions are raised by that.
—Order, the time for the debate has expired.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask that the time for this debate be extended for at least another 20 minutes. Some time ago we entered into the spirit of taking note of answers to questions without notice on the basis that it was our chance to question ministers' answers.
—So the Senate becomes the opposition house.

—If Senator Carr listened for a while, he might learn something. That was the spirit of the arrangement that we entered into. Ever since that arrangement was put in place we have very rarely used the urgency motion. Government members are now using that time. Senators Chamarette, Herron and MacGibbon have been trying to get the call, so I wonder whether the government will give leave to extend the debate for 20 minutes.

—Senator Panizza, in part, is right. We did decide that in certain circumstances the half-hour rule would not apply. I do point out that we have some business to get through before 4.30 p.m. because then general business automatically cuts in. I would be quite happy for this to go another 20 minutes, but if we do not complete the business listed to be dealt with—committee reports and a few other things—then at 4.30 p.m. we will seek to go a few more minutes to finish that. It seems to me a fair thing and it will not cut into too much of the general business time. If that is agreed, I am quite happy for the debate to be extended for 20 minutes.
—There being no objection, it is so ordered.
—I seek the call to continue my remarks.
—Is this a further personal explanation?

—If I am not interjected upon, I probably will not take very long to make my remarks, but if I am I might go on for another five or 10 minutes. The Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is an evenly balanced committee. It has dealt with quite a number of contentious issues—obviously the sorts of contentious issues which are being considered by the print media inquiry. On occasions on Fridays I have had business in Perth and Senator Loosley has had business in Sydney. Whenever anything contentious was coming up, Senator Loosley and I would always make sure that, if he were not going to be there, I would be there and vice-versa. It was a very sensible, gentlemanly agreement to pair with each other. That is a sensible arrangement to make—as with the contentious issue last night over the chairmanship of Senator Alston—when it is known that one member of the opposition will be absent on parliamentary business overseas.
—That was not a point at issue.

—The point at issue here is Senator Loosley's double standards. If he chooses to say that Senator Alston survived only because he used his casting vote in his own favour, that is a reflection on Senator Alston and leads people to think that he hung on to the chairmanship by a thread.
—It does not matter; it was a majority decision.

—Senator Murphy says that it was a majority decision, but Senator Loosley said that it was only on the casting vote of Senator Alston, implying that he hung on to the chairmanship of the committee only by a thread. The reality is that, if Senator Loosley seriously thinks that Senator Alston is hanging on only by the thread of the casting vote of the chairman, Senator Loosley should either move to ensure that chairmen of committees do not have a casting vote or stand by the honour which existed between him and me on the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration that, when we have contentious issues, there should be a pairing arrangement.

—I rise to speak on this matter. I was a participant in last night's events and would like to express an entirely different view of the proceedings from that which we have heard from the coalition and the Australian Democrats. Last night we clearly saw a very divided committee, a highly polarised committee, as one would expect with a committee of this type. The very fact that the committee was established in such a partisan, party political way was inevitably going to lead to conflict. That is the nature of these sorts of committees.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite were serious about inquiring into the substantive issues under review, including the question of the operation of the Foreign Investment Review Board, they would have referred the matter to a standing committee, such as the committee dealing with government administration, just as we moved to do last night and on which we were defeated by the casting vote of the chair.

There was then a motion on the question of the publication of the legal advice that we had received. That legal advice did not support the contentions that the majority had been pursuing and, as a result, was said to be inadequate. Those opposite said that we had to get further legal advice to clarify the position. There was then a majority vote, on the casting vote of the chair, to suppress the evidence and the opinion. When that happens, of course we have to expect that tempers will be raised and that people will express a point of view strongly and forcefully.

The question that arises is whether or not that is an appropriate political expression of an opinion. I say it is. I say that we have a right to be able to say that it is wrong to use the Senate and the committees and their powers in this way to try to intimidate and gaol witnesses and to undermine the proper confidential advice to government and the workings of government. The legal advice of those opposite is that that is not appropriate. That is the sort of behaviour of an opposition that is intent on making itself a permanent opposition in this country and in this case it gets support from the Democrats. That is the issue here.

Senator Kernot indicated that her halo was slipping. I could not agree more with that. She has a view about the actions of Senator Alston, and on a couple of occasions she has expressed that view on the record to many journalists. It was fair enough for her to say, `I am still making up my mind'. She is entitled to that point of view. But I find it difficult to appreciate the way she walked in there in a sanctimonious way and suggested that she had made her position clear. I find it very difficult to understand the logic behind that other than that she is trying to tell the public that Constable Kernot is not intent on—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Carr to refer to his colleagues by their proper names.

—Senator Kernot is intent on using the powers of the Senate to gaol people, to try to extract from them a position on this matter which she finds suitable. She gets great power from pretending that she is a magistrate. She gets great power from the possibility that she, as a senator of this country, can lord it over the citizens of this country. That is terrific, but that is not a democratic way to behave. In a democratic country, it is not appropriate to say that senators in this country have more power than those in the American Senate but Australian citizens have fewer rights than the American citizens. That is an extraordinary argument for the Democrats to maintain in this place.

PARA.TAB: I would expect nothing better from those opposite. That is the way they behave. They believe that they are born to rule. Because of their frustration with and embarrassment by the existence of a Labor government, they have to use the Senate to try to even up the score. People say that we are a bit upset because we do not have the numbers. This is the nature of the Senate. It is essentially based on an undemocratic electoral system. Those opposite are benefiting from the fact that they won the 1990 election in the Senate, but they lost the 1993 election in the Senate. They are making clear their advantage in a partisan, political way. If that is the way they want to play it, that is okay. But they should not expect the Labor Party to say, `Well, that's fine. That's all right. You can do whatever you like. You can abuse the powers of the Senate in any way you like'. Those opposite should not expect us to say that we will accept that as an appropriate form of political behaviour, because we will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not intervene for terribly long. We have just had a contribution which is to modern thought what the Titanic was to passenger liners. One of the incredible things we heard from Senator Carr was that the government members on the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in relation to the Print Media believed that the whole matter should be referred to a Senate standing committee. Senator Carr, in particular, is irked that that motion was defeated by the casting vote of the chairman of the select committee.

PARA.TAB: The intention of the government members to refer the matter to a Senate standing committee was to ensure that they would always win because they would have the casting vote of the chairman. I do not think anything more needs to be said. Senator Carr has been exposed for the nonsense that he normally rambles on with in here. Frankly, he would do a much better job if he sat down and learnt some standing orders instead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree entirely with everything Senator Carr has had to say here today—
—Only today.

—Certainly on these matters. The fact is that select committees should really be renamed. They are no longer select committees to inquire into anything. It is very much like Alice in Wonderland: the sentence is first, the verdict is second and then the evidence is heard. That has been the approach of this committee from day one. From day one this committee has had a predetermined attitude to judge a particular issue. It has then gone out to find the evidence. I do not find that as offensive as Senator Carr does. I just accept that as the reality of this chamber. Members of committees often make up their minds beforehand and then they go out and seek the evidence to back up their prejudices. I do not see that as a major crime.

PARA.TAB: What I see as the major crime is the intense pomposity of the contributions of those opposite. We hear about the wonderfulness of this chamber, how it is the only democratic institution in this country and, by extension, just what wonderful individuals all senators are. Senator Carr hit the nail on the head when he said that these committees give their members, especially their chairmen, a vicarious thrill, especially trained lawyers who, for the first time in their lives, become judges in the tradition of Judge Roy Bean.

What have we had from this committee so far? We have had public statement after public statement from Senator Alston about what the issues are. Every morning when people turn on AM on the way to work, Senator Alston is commenting on the latest quirk. Will he subpoena Conrad Black? Will Mr Hawke attend? He is prejudging the issues entirely, yet, again, trying to keep up this fiction that this is an independent committee of inquiry and not just a political witch-hunt.

That is what it has been from the start; that is why the terms of reference were written in the way they were; that is why the numbers on the committee were so constituted; and that is why Senator Alston was elected to be chair of that committee, to do that precise task. I do not mind any of that as long as it is recognised that that is the process we are involved in. But what we have had recently—and what Senator Alston did not like—is basically his wanting a verdict from the committee that the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating) used undue influence in terms of the future ownership of Fairfax by asking for a balanced coverage.

I just note for the record that we got editorials out of the Fairfax organisation in the last election—every one of its editorials—saying, `Don't vote for the Labor Party'. I suggest that the opposition and others go back and have a look at Stuart Littlemore's Media Watch and his brilliant comparison of the coverage in the Sydney Morning Herald of the Labor Party policy launch at Bankstown and its coverage of the Liberal Party launch. He showed the distorted photos that were in that paper of our rally; the very nasty headlines—

TALK.START.PARA: —The pork-barrel republic.

—The pork-barrel republic, Senator Carr reminds me—exactly. It did all of that to us. But what happened in these present circumstances? Just for once the Fairfax press wrote the truth about the opposition. It actually wrote that Dr Hewson is not travelling too well. Then what happened? Dr Hewson—not of Senator Alston's own volition—apparently rang Senator Alston and said, `I want you to ring the Age and whinge and ask for a better coverage'. It never occurred to Senator Alston—chairing a witch-hunt committee that was going to be directed to finding a predetermined verdict—that ringing the editor of the Age and asking him for a more balanced coverage to protect Dr Hewson, when Senator Alston is going to bring down a verdict some time this year on what may well affect the material future of the Fairfax organisation, would involve a conflict of interest. As it is, I tend to agree with the editor of the Age. He did not find it that offensive; he found it plain dumb, as I do.

PARA.TAB: Let us cut all the garbage away from these committees. This committee was set up to find a specific verdict. It predetermined its position. It is going on with that position. It will not release any advice that does not back up its view of wanting to gaol public servants or in demanding documents. It will suppress that in the name of democracy and will use its casting vote to do all those sorts of things. Then the members of the committee come into the chamber and say, `But Senator Loosley visited the Fairfax organisation'. Did they adduce any evidence today from the editor of the Sydney Morning Herald to say Senator Loosely tried to influence the policy of the paper at all? Not at all.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the further answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) this day, to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron on 16 March 1994, relating to health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion because it is the third time that the minister has denied that there will be any change in the Medicare tax. I was reminded of a biblical reference as he was denying it on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), but on this occasion, however, it is Paul rather than Peter. As on that previous occasion, I am sure the same result will occur.

PARA.TAB: Every time that the Medicare tax has been increased the number of people privately insured has decreased. Prior to the introduction of Medicare, 70 per cent of the population were insured. When the Medicare tax came in at one per cent the number insured went down to 54 per cent. In 1986 the tax was increased by 25 per cent to 1.25 per cent and the number of privately insured went down to 48 per cent. Last year the tax was increased to 1.4 per cent and the number of privately insured went down to 40 per cent. It does not sound very much—1.4 per cent of taxable income—but it takes in $2,885 million. So we are talking about a sizeable sum of money.

I challenge the minister to tell us why the numbers of the privately insured will not decrease on the next occasion, because it occurred over that period—and in that time health insurance premiums have risen by over 100 per cent. So it is a matter of cause and effect. He does not seem to understand that. He does not seem to understand the connection which has occurred in the past and which will occur again in the future. It is fairly straightforward. But somehow or other it escapes him. Yet in October last year, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, we cannot continue to have private health insurance bleed in the way that it has in the past years because this does increase the strains on the public system.

The Australian Private Hospitals Association has cooperated with the minister since December last year in looking at his package of changes, which he calls reforms but which I call further destruction. Today it made the following statement:

The most bewildering aspect of the discussion paper is that it has correctly identified the major problems in the hospital system, that is, the high and . . . rising cost of private health insurance which causes Australians to opt out of private insurance which in turn leads to increased pressure on the public system, and those most affected are low income earners and the aged.
Having identified these problems, it has totally ignored them. There is nothing in the proposed reform package that provides any hope of a reduction in the price of private health insurance premiums.

He cannot have it both ways. On three occasions he refused to deny that there was going to be an increase in the Medicare tax and yet at the same time he is saying that he is going to encourage people into private insurance.

PARA.TAB: The other point I want to make in relation to that aspect is the $8.9 million going to consultancies that are in the process of being let, before the ACTU caucus working party has presented its report. The minister is going ahead—once again, we have the expenditure of taxpayers' money, over $9 million on this occasion—before he has got the report. He has prejudged what is going to occur. The money is to be spent in this taxation year. If any other report is brought in that money will be wasted because it is going on consultancies. Over $8 million is to be spent on consultancies.

As I mentioned in my question to the minister the other day, over a three-year period less than $4 million was spent on the Macklin national health strategy. The minister has already put off the report. I think the report is now due on 20 April. Regardless of that report, those consultancies are being let. This is another example of throwing money away on consultancies which may well be scrapped, and nothing may occur as a result. He keeps hiding behind this barrage of words that he uses.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Deputy President, and my colleagues. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) this day, to a question without notice asked by Senator Chamarette on 16 March 1994, relating to the McArthur River mine project.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister completed answering this question today. I asked the minister yesterday whether he was aware that the mine proponent had substantially altered the location and design of the facility. I asked, among other things: why has the government allowed the construction of the project to commence before the environment management plans have been completed? I believe the answer I was given today indicates that it is not a mere disregard for the invaluable and unique environmental features of the area that has led to this haste in moving ahead with the mining project.

PARA.TAB: The seagrass beds, the major significant breeding sites for the dugong and the turtle in the Southern Hemisphere, are also Aboriginal dreaming, turtle dreaming and dugong dreaming areas. Something else underlies the government's haste: in the answer I was given today, Senator Richardson assured me that the validation and regranting of the McArthur River leases and exploration licence, including the lease at Bing Bong under the McArthur River Project Agreement Ratification Amendment Act 1993, in no way impairs the Yanyuwa's ability to claim native title. However, he did not say that, while it does not impair their ability to claim native title, it also puts them in the category of having their native title extinguished by the Native Title Act that was passed in 1993. It is an example of the reason the Greens had serious concerns about supporting the bill in the first place.

He also says, `I am advised that dredging associated with the barge loading facility will all be within the mining lease area at the Bing Bong facility. No dredging is required outside the lease area'. It becomes apparent that the lease area has been designed so that the dredging required will have a dramatic environmental impact and will also be immune to any significant native title claims regarding its Aboriginal significance.

This will not be the last mention of this matter. But I mention it here to place on the public record that this is the first instance where the native title legislation, introduced with such fine rhetoric of protecting Aboriginal interests, is now exposed in its real motivation and may well be the first application where the Native Title Act 1993 is used for the extinguishment of native title. Following debate on the Native Title Bill, the Greens have not forgotten all the undertakings the government gave and all the arguments presented. There was no definite instance where pastoral or other leases would extinguish native title. The government now needs to show the Senate that it did not know that the Bing Bong station was one of the stations that would be found to be invalid by way of native title and, therefore, that it would be validated and then native title extinguished under the Native Title Act 1993.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator MacGibbon this day, relating to the provision of tax file numbers by veterans on disability pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: The question I asked Senator Faulkner related to tax file numbers and disability pensions. A disability pension is paid to Australian men or women who served in the defence forces and suffered an impairment in either their physical or mental capacities as a consequence of that service. It is paid, therefore, to those who qualify with respect to the diminution in the quality of life that they can enjoy compared to others of the same age group who did not go to war. It therefore means that it is not an income support pension. It is paid in a way that is not means or assets tested. It is almost never withdrawn. It is not taxed in the hands of the recipient. It is very much a pension to compensate these veterans for the impairment in their ability to live a normal life.

PARA.TAB: The government has demanded that they provide a tax file number before they can qualify or receive a pension. They qualify if they meet the standards required under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. A large number of veterans have refused to supply a tax file number because they believe that it is a gross invasion of their personal privacy. They allege that they have been treated as criminals. If they refuse to provide a tax file number, various people in the Department of Veterans' Affairs accuse them of having something to hide. It has caused enormous distress to veterans. A number of them have refused absolutely to provide it and, as a consequence, they have had their pensions withdrawn and they have suffered financial loss.

Since I asked that question, my phone has run hot. An example of this is the case of a war widow who was on a 100 per cent disability pension and whose husband was on a disability pension. When he died, recently, the Department of Veterans' Affairs—in her own words—`coerced and blackmailed' her, in the depth of her despair at the loss of her husband, to provide a tax file number; otherwise she would not get the payment of her war widow pension. I argue that people who qualify for a pension under the act—and, God knows, it is hard enough to qualify for one—ought to get it. It is not taxed, assets tested or means tested—unlike most pensions that the government provides. The obligation is on the other departments—such as the Department of Social Security, if it is going to provide an age pension—to do a tax file check to make sure there is no fraud. The obligation to do it should not be on the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Senator Faulkner accused me of being ignorant of the act. It was because I understood the act that I encouraged those people to come forward in recent days to talk about the great injustice that had been done to them. In the minister's own press release, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Although discretionary power legally rests with the Secretary of my Department and not with me as Minister, I have asked the Secretary to take a look at his discretionary guidelines for exemption from provision of the tax file number.

That is exactly the point I put to Senator Faulkner. What he did, in legal terms, is known as dissembling. The other thing he did was confirm that the tax file number is being used for cross-checking purposes right across all government departments. When the tax file number was brought before this chamber, the government argued and argued that it was for the Australian Taxation Office and was not to be used as a fingerprint, as an Australia Card substitute—for which Senator Faulkner has admitted that it is now being used.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner was acutely embarrassed by my question, because it caught him red-handed. It showed him to be totally insensitive and uncaring. This matter has been going on for years. I know veterans who lost their disability pensions in February last year. He has been shown to be totally unresponsive to the demands made on him. That provision was always in the act. He has not acted on it. He sat on it for years. It is absolutely inexcusable, as he realised when public pressure was building up yesterday. Six hours after Mr Leonard Teale appeared on the front page of the Australian, Senator Faulkner raised the white flag and surrendered. He admitted that he had the power to talk to the secretary to grant an exemption for those persons receiving a disability pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs only and to excuse them from supplying a tax file number.

I am glad Senator Faulkner has come into the chamber. I ask him not to confuse the debate by accusing me of not knowing the difference between disability pensions and other social service benefits. I am specifically talking about those pensioners who qualify only for a disability pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. They should not be required to provide a tax file number.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Minister for Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed that again Senator MacGibbon has tossed around words such as `criminal' and `criminality'. I fully accept, as does my department, that the overwhelming number of disability pensioners are totally honest and would never attempt to defraud the government, but I do believe that the government owes a duty of care to Australian taxpayers to ensure that overpayments do not take place. This issue has been linked by a number of individual beneficiaries of the Department of Veterans' Affairs with the issue of privacy.

PARA.TAB: The department has been very careful to advise pensioners that the information they provide may be supplied to other agencies and used in data matching. The Privacy Commissioner, of course, monitors data-matching activity to ensure that pensioners' privacy is protected and that departments, such as my department, comply with the Privacy Act 1988.

Tax file numbers are securely stored in a special computer system which is password protected and restricts access to only those directly involved in tax file number recording. The forms on which tax file numbers are collected are destroyed in conformity with classified waste procedures.

I tried to indicate to Senator MacGibbon and other senators earlier in question time that I as minister do not have the discretionary power under the Veterans' Entitlements Act to grant disability pensioners or any other beneficiary in the Department of Veterans' Affairs an exemption from providing their tax file number. I cannot make it any clearer than that. That is the situation. The discretion does not lie with the minister; it lies with the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

There are currently certain exemptions. Veterans who are currently exempt from providing tax file numbers are pensioners aged over 80; pensioners who may be profoundly disabled, be it physically or mentally; those who have been in receipt of a service pension for more than 10 years and who have had additional income of less than $20 per week; those who live overseas; those who are recipients of widow disability pensions; those who are homeless people; those who live in a nursing home; and those who are non-payee spouses of disability pensioners.

I have indicated that it is illegal and improper for me to direct the secretary in this area. I have asked the secretary to look at this matter sympathetically and quickly. This is an example of a minister being appropriately responsive to the serious representations that have been made to him.

Finally—Senator MacGibbon should take account of this—many veterans' organisations, particularly the RSL, have changed their policy on this matter. The state presidents and the national president of the RSL are recommending to veterans and entitled beneficiaries of the Department of Veterans' Affairs that they provide their tax file numbers. That is a significant change in policy from the position that was originally adopted by the Returned Services League of Australia. Senator MacGibbon ought to take account of the importance of that change in policy.
We are looking at this issue as sensitively as we can, and we are progressing properly. I am very disappointed that Senator MacGibbon seems to be one-out on this issue.

Operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974

The Government's responses to the Committee's recommendations are set out below. The relevant amendments to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 (the IR Act) made by the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993 (the Reform Act) are expected to be proclaimed to take effect on 30 March 1994. For convenience, they are referred to as if they are in operation.
R.1As a general principle, industrial disputes should be dealt with in the first instance under industrial relations legislation.
The Government agrees with the recommendation.

This principle is reflected in the Reform Act. In particular, provision is made for pre-litigation conciliation by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission where federally registered trade unions, or their officers, members or employees, are involved in a secondary boycott which is prohibited by new section 162 of the IR Act (which is inserted by section 38 of the Reform Act). Similarly, pre-litigation conciliation is required by new section 166A of the IR Act (which is inserted by section 40 of the Reform Act) where a tort action is to be taken against a federally registered trade union or its officers, members or employees in respect of an industrial dispute which is within the jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

R.2Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act be repealed and the Act revised to deal with boycotts involving competitors where they have the purpose of reducing competition in a given market or otherwise restricting the trade of particular enterprises.
The Government agrees with the recommendation.

Section 45D of the Trade Practices Act 1974 is amended by section 43 of the Reform Act. Section 45D now applies only to secondary boycotts which have the purpose and effect of causing a substantial lessening of competition in a market.
Section 44 of the Reform Act repeals section 45E.
R.3The Industrial Relations Act be amended:
(a) to enshrine the fundamental principle of the right to withdraw labour and that any qualifications attached thereto should be articulated within that legislative framework;
(b) to provide for a mechanism to deal expeditiously with boycotts and other industrial action of the kind which has hitherto been subject to action under sections 45D and 45E;

(c) to provide that where a dispute has been dealt with by industrial relations mechanisms, and a speedy resolution has been unable to be effected, a certificate should be issued enabling the matter to be dealt with in a civil jurisdiction.
The Government agrees with the recommendation.
As to R.3(a), the provision is made in the IR Act in relation to the internationally recognised right to engage in industrial action. This is achieved by amendments under the Reform Act.

Under new section 170PG, a federally registered trade union or a member, officer or employee of the union may engage in peaceful industrial action in support of a claim for an agreement which is intended to be certified under the IR Act. An employer is given a corresponding capacity to lock out employees, either in response to such industrial action, or in support of a claim by the employer. This is subject to certain notice provisions and to supervision by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (the AIRC).
Section 170PG and related provisions of new Division 4—Immunity from civil liability—of new Part VIB—promoting bargaining and facilitating agreements—are inserted by section 30 of the Reform Act.

As to R.3(b) and (c), there is now machinery for pre-litigation conciliation before the AIRC in relation to prohibited secondary boycotts—see above. This may be for up to 72 hours. At the end of that period (unless a certificate is given sooner), the AIRC must issue a certificate permitting an action for an injunction or damages or both to be brought before the new Industrial Relations Court of Australia (see new sections 163D, 163G and 163H of the IR Act, inserted by section 38 of the Reform Act).

In addition, as referred to above, there is now a requirement for pre-litigation conciliation before the AIRC where a tort action is proposed to be taken against a federally registered trade union or its officers, members or employees in relation to an industrial dispute that is within the jurisdiction of the AIRC. This may be for up to 72 hours. At the end of that period, if a certificate has not been given sooner, the AIRC must issue a certificate which will allow proceedings to be brought before a court for a common law injunction or damages. This is provided for by new section 166A of the AI Act, inserted by section 40 of the Reform Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to a report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on gas and electricity and combining efficiency and greenhouse. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.
