SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ON GAS AND ELECTRICITY: COMBINING EFFICIENCY AND GREENHOUSE
PREAMBLE

1.The report of the Senate Standing Committee, entitled Gas and Electricity: Combining Efficiency and Greenhouse, was tabled on 10 December 1992. The Government is now in a position to respond to the Committee's report.

2.The report contains 19 recommendations which form the basis of a national approach to energy supply designed to achieve energy supply efficiency and reduce levels of greenhouse gas emissions. The government commends the Committee for its report which has canvassed in detail the major greenhouse issues confronting the gas and electricity sectors.

3.It is important to consider the task given to the Committee in context. When the Commonwealth, States and Territories agreed in 1990 to the Interim Planning Target to reduce greenhouse emissions, they also agreed to work jointly to develop a National Greenhouse Response Strategy (NGRS). Policy options for possible incorporation in this Strategy were developed through 1991 in a series of reports, notably those of the Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) Working Groups. These in turn built on earlier reports, including the Senate Committee's previous complementary work on the greenhouse effect and energy use, Rescue the Future: reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect which had, incidentally, recommended that governments develop a NGRS.

4.The Government saw the work of the Committee as ideally complementing that done by the ESD Working Groups, in that it would provide another frame of reference in the development of appropriate policies which would assist Australia in meeting its Interim Planning Target to reduce greenhouse emissions.

5.The interim planning target agreed to by Governments is for Australia to stabilise greenhouse gases at 1988 levels by the year 2000, and to reduce those emissions by 20% by the year 2005 subject to Australia not implementing response measures which would have net adverse economic impacts nationally or on Australia's trade competitiveness, in the absence of similar action by major greenhouse gas producing countries.

6.The rationale for the Committee's focus on electricity and gas was twofold. Firstly, these sectors are major contributors to Australia's greenhouse emissions. As noted in the ESD reports, emission reduction strategies will need to focus on options available within the energy production and energy use sectors because they are the most easily quantified and the most readily controlled. The electricity and gas sectors have been estimated to account for nearly 34% of Australian greenhouse gas emissions.

7.Secondly, gas and electricity are key elements of the micro-economic reform initiatives being pursued by governments. The main objective of micro-economic reform in the gas and electricity service sectors is to improve economic efficiency and productivity. These benefits will flow through the economy which will enhance the competitive base of Australian industry.

8.It is important to ensure that the economic objectives of micro-reform and the environmental objectives of meeting greenhouse emission targets are appropriately integrated. This was the Committee's principal concern—to make recommendations which reconcile possible conflicts between economic and environmental imperatives.

9.The recommendations made by the Committee also need to be viewed against the NGRS and the National Strategy for Ecological Sustainable Development which have been agreed to by governments. The ESD and Greenhouse Strategies commit governments to a set of broad goals and principles which will guide their efforts to ensure that Australia's future development is ecologically sustainable. The Strategies also commit governments to a range of early actions, aimed at giving effect to these goals and principles.

10.The NGRS presented a range of actions for governments to take, as a first phase of responses to greenhouse issues. They concentrate on the use of "no regrets" measures, that is measures which have net benefits, or at least no net costs, outside of their effects on greenhouse emissions. The NGRS includes a section on measures to be undertaken in the energy supply sector. Many of these measures are similar to those that have been recommended by the Committee. Some of the required response actions are already under way.
11.In reaching agreement on the development of response measures, governments adopted a number of important core principles, including:
response measures should be effective in furthering the strategy goal, and economically efficient;
response measures should be directed towards the interim planning target; and
response measures should take account of other competing or complementary goals, policies and priorities.
12.Governments also identified the characteristics of first phase response measures, including:
in respect of both no-regrets measures and insurance measures, any economic and social costs will be low; and
first phase measures will meet equity objectives by causing minimal disruption to the wider community, any single industry sector, or any particular geographic region.

13.The timing of the finalisation of the Committee's report was such that it was unable to take into account, in the development of its recommendations, these agreed principles and characteristics. It is understandable, therefore, that in some respects the Committee's recommendations go beyond what has already been mandated by governments.

14.In this respect, the Committee has not accepted the thrust of certain micro-economic reforms proposed by the Government, particularly in the electricity sector, which are regarded as being inconsistent with environmental goals. The Government does not believe that this is the case. The rationale for many of these important structural and operational reforms rejected by the Committee have since been embraced by Heads of Government. In those few instances where the views of the Committee have not been accepted, the reasoning behind the Government's thinking has been elaborated in the response to the specific recommendation in question.

15.The Government believes that the approach it has taken with respect to certain areas of micro-economic reform is consistent with meeting environmental objectives. It believes that structural reform of the electricity and gas industries will remove distortions in the energy market which impede the pursuit of ESD and greenhouse objectives. The Government is firmly of the view that the micro-economic reform will be beneficial not only economically but environmentally as well. Those areas where the Government believes specific micro-economic reform initiatives in the electricity and gas sectors can deliver real environmental benefits has been spelt out in the response to the Committee's recommendations.

16.In general, and as already indicated, one of the primary objectives of the current program of micro-economic reform is to remove any excessive or unnecessary costs to Australian industry, and thus to raise Australia's trade competitiveness and general prosperity. A more prosperous Australia will be better able to afford any future costs that may be associated with emissions limitations measures. The reforms proposed by the Government, for the electricity sector in particular, are likely to achieve a number of the results the Committee is looking for. A more competitive electricity market, allied with commercially oriented suppliers, will produce incentives to promote electricity conservation, where such measures are more cost-effective than building additional capacity. The expansion of the interstate electricity grid will enable existing capacity to be better and more efficiently utilised, new generating capacity will be deferred and no new capacity will be developed unless commercially feasible and only where it is more cost effective than demand management. The gradual removal of existing capital subsidies and cross-subsidies will lead to more efficient and rational patterns of energy use and promote the greater use of renewables, particularly in remote localities where they are already cost competitive.

Recommendation 1: That where an independent energy audit is able to demonstrate that the cost of improving efficiency of new or existing buildings, under the control of the (Commonwealth) government, its departments or agencies, can be recovered by savings in energy charges in less than five years, building managers be required to implement these measures. (Para 1.26)
Qualified support.

The Government has a comprehensive energy policy which interacts with economic and social sectors to foster the more efficient use of energy in an environmentally benign manner. The policy is effected principally through a National Energy Management Program. The program not only utilises information dissemination but also provides financial incentives and is involved principally with the States in the development of national energy standards and codes of practice. An important component of the program is the energy efficiency of Commonwealth operations, particularly of buildings and motor vehicles.

In July 1992, a Commonwealth buildings energy audit program was initiated which applies to non-residential buildings occupied by Commonwealth departments and agencies. This program operated for the 1992-93 Financial Year and individual audits conducted for departments and agencies were paid for in full out of the program funds. A similar program operates for the industrial and commercial sector for which Government Business Enterprises are eligible. A number of other measures complement building audits within the Commonwealth sector.

The Commonwealth buildings energy audit program requires that the audits be undertaken by accredited energy auditors. Wider measures in place also require departments and agencies to develop energy management plans which provide a framework within which energy audits can be planned and appropriate measures implemented in light of the audit report recommendations.

Agencies have been given both the means and incentive to implement energy audit findings. The movement of property operating expenses into running costs provides incentives for Commonwealth agencies to improve energy efficiency. Once property resource agreements are signed, agencies will be able to allocate, or bring forward from later years, funds from their running costs to implement viable energy efficiency measures identified from energy audits. Net savings in energy expenditure identified by initial energy audits will be shared equally between the agency and the Budget. Whilst there is no compulsion on agencies to implement the findings of the audit report, as recommended by the Committee, the Government believes that these measures taken in totality meet the intent of this recommendation.

Recommendation 2: That in the future, governments and the electricity and gas authorities themselves take a broader view of their role and introduce whatever measures to reduce or control (greenhouse) emissions which can be shown to be economic. (Para 1.40)
Supported.

The NGRS, agreed to by Australian Governments, contains a series of response actions in the energy supply sector which will assist in reducing or controlling greenhouse emissions. These response actions place certain obligations on governments in the development of a competitive market for electricity supply in eastern and southern Australia. Electricity reform initiatives are being progressed through the National Grid Management Council (NGMC), established by Heads of Government in July 1991.

The NGRS requires governments: to accommodate cogeneration schemes in their planning activities by providing appropriate and fair buy-back arrangements for the purchase of surplus electricity; to provide for non-discriminatory access by generators, demand-side option suppliers and customers through competitive bidding; to develop an integrated least cost planning approach including both supply and demand side options; to expand the use of renewable energy where there are suitable opportunities; and to develop programs to facilitate the use of cost competitive renewable energy resources for stand-alone power supply systems for remote and rural areas.

The NGMC, in developing electricity reform proposals for governments, has been cognisant of the requirements imposed by the NGRS. The National Grid Protocol developed by the NGMC and released in December 1992, sets out a framework for the efficient development and operation of the electricity supply system. The Protocol, agreed to by Heads of Government, indicates that the national grid will be operated in such a manner that will enable many of the NGRS response actions to be addressed.

In this regard, the Protocol indicates that specific provision is to be made for demand side option suppliers under the competitive bidding processes in a manner which will provide for least cost long term solutions. The Government supports demand management and renewable energy options having equal opportunity alongside conventional supply side options to satisfy future electricity requirements. Further work is to be done in this area, including by the NGMC, with Heads of Government having called for a report on demand management opportunities to be provided for its next meeting.

The reforms provide for transparent pricing which will reveal the real economic cost of providing power from the grid to remote areas. The Government believes that this will create a positive framework for the development of price competitive remote area power supply systems based on renewable energy sources such as solar thermal, wind and small hydro and will further encourage the development of a renewable energy industry in Australia.

The NGMC is also investigating the technical and economic feasibility of extensions to, or upgrading of, the interstate transmission links. The Committee in its deliberations noted the potential this created for the sharing of spinning reserve with consequent reductions in fuel use.

Additionally, under the National Gas Strategy, the Government, in consultation with the States, is promoting the greater utilisation of gas through the freeing up of the market through the removal of impediments to free and fair trade in natural gas. This holds the key to encouraging greater exploration and development of this fuel. Greater utilisation of gas will have significant environmental and greenhouse benefits. Research is also being undertaken into the use of coal-bed methane to enable the harnessing of this valuable resource.
Recommendation 3: That there be a ten year moratorium on the construction of new conventional generation plant by the electricity authorities. (Para 1.50)
No action required.

The States and Territories have responsibility for their electricity supply industries, including the construction of new power generation capacity. The Commonwealth has only limited responsibilities in respect to the construction of new generation plant, for example if the project impinges on Commonwealth land or water, or if Commonwealth funding is involved.

Australia's international comparative advantage in electricity is based on coal fired electricity generation. The cost of producing coal fired electricity in Australia continues to decline, further improving Australia's international competitiveness in energy intensive production and enhancing the performance of our manufacturing sector. At the same time, the environmental performance of coal fired power stations continues to improve. The Commonwealth notes that the adoption of a ten year moratorium on the construction of new conventional generation plant by the electricity authorities was not a measure that was included in the first phase of the NGRS endorsed by Heads of Government in December 1992.

Another Commonwealth/State forum, the NGMC, has responded to this recommendation stating that it considered the approach to be too simplistic. The NGMC pointed out that the apparent justification for the recommendation was difficulties associated with objectively assessing whether all opportunities for cogeneration and energy savings through efficiency which can be realised at a lower cost than installing new capacity had been fully exploited. The NGMC accepted that there remain difficulties with making competitive assessments of demand and supply measures. Nevertheless, it was suggested that it would be more appropriate to seek to overcome such difficulties rather than imposing a somewhat arbitrary moratorium, particularly where a clear need for new capacity is demonstrated.

The Commonwealth suggests that the Committee's recommendation implies a vertically integrated electricity supply industry in which governments are able to dictate the timing and nature of new electricity generation capacity. Under the micro-economic reforms, agreed to by Heads of Government, a competitive market structure is to be implemented by 1 July 1995. This structure will provide for open access for new generation, including from the private sector. The need for any new generation capacity should be reduced with the implementation of micro-economic reform.

The nature of the competitive generation market and the overall framework for the efficient development and operation of the electricity supply system in eastern and southern Australia are set out in the National Grid Protocol. The Protocol indicates that competitive sourcing processes will ensure that new capacity, whether on the supply or demand side, is sourced in a manner involving least cost long term solutions. It is proposed that all expressions of interest and bids submitted under the competitive sourcing process would be subject to independent review. This approach, if successfully implemented, should provide an effective means by which alternatives for new generation capacity, such as cogeneration, energy efficiency and demand management will be fully explored. This, essentially, is the objective of the Committee's proposed moratorium.

In recent years there has been an increasing number of proposals for the construction of cogeneration plants, small hydro, and renewables including solar thermal, wind and agricultural waste. A competitive generation market is expected to provide further encouragement to these projects as an alternative to large scale conventional plant.

Initiatives being pursued by the NGMC which make more efficient use of existing capacity, including new and upgraded interstate transmission links and the greater use of demand side options, have the potential to delay the need for new generation capacity in the southern and eastern States until after the turn of the century. Generally, any increase in demand in this period in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland can be met by newly constructed generation units such as Loy Yang B, Mt Piper and Stanwell. Demand projections for Queensland, however, indicate that 300 MW of new capacity will be required each year from 1998 to 2001. The Queensland Government is currently examining options for meeting this demand. The need for the first increments in new capacity could be considerably delayed should the New South Wales and Queensland Governments agree to the construction of a transmission link between their States.

The only other coal fired generation indicated within the Committee's time frame is in Western Australia. It is not technically feasible for Western Australia to be connected to the eastern states grid and demand growth dictates that new capacity will be required. The West Australian Government at this time remains committed to coal, although gas is a feasible alternative.
Recommendation 4: That greater use of gas be made in a wide variety of applications including direct use where possible and as a fuel for power generation. (Para 3.15)
Supported.

The Government supports the Committee's recommendation and considers the most appropriate manner of implementing the recommendation is through the removal of impediments to free and fair trade in natural gas.

In this regard, at the Council of Australian Governments (CoAG) held in Perth on 7 December 1992, Heads of Government noted that there were barriers to trade in natural gas which could inhibit gas industry development and discourage exploration and the commercial development of gas markets.
CoAG requested the Australia and New Zealand Minerals and Energy Council (ANZMEC) to submit a report to the CoAG meeting held on 8 June 1993. The report:
identified and reviewed existing legislative or other government imposed impediments and barriers to free and fair trade in natural gas, within and between jurisdictions;
recommended action to remove impediments and barriers to free and fair trade in natural gas, within and between jurisdictions; and

outlined the work required to move towards a more uniform pipeline approvals process between States and Territories for pipeline development, including the recommended basis for third party access to gas transmission pipelines.

The ANZMEC report on removal of governmental impediments to free and fair trade in gas was considered by CoAG in June 1993. Heads of Government agreed to cooperate in the development of policies and arrangements covering the gas industry which are pro-competitive, facilitate the development of gas markets on commercial criteria and remove impediments to free and fair trade in gas. CoAG called for a further report for its next meeting on progress towards a pro-competitive framework including a review of regulatory arrangements, within and between jurisdictions, including those applying to third party access to gas pipelines.

The proposed ANZMEC study on options for, and implications of, increasing use of natural gas, as outlined in the NGRS, will also be relevant. The ANZMEC study will include examination of the full costs of gas and alternatives and the potential for extending the reticulation systems, in particular on the urban fringe. It will also have regard to the cost risk to which Australia would be exposed, where the further expansion of electricity generation was derived exclusively from coal and a much greater effort becomes necessary to limit greenhouse gas emissions within the economic lifetimes of current power stations. An outline and directions for the study were noted by ANZMEC Ministers on 23 July 1993.
Recommendation 5: That the Government examine ways in which the effect of gas price instability and the RRT (resource rent tax) on cogeneration schemes could be minimised. (Para 3.40)
No action required.
The RRT does not, and will not, impact on factors determining investment in cogeneration.

The RRT facilitates the full commercial development of economic petroleum (oil and gas) resources. This is achieved because the RRT is based on profits rather than on levels of production. The RRT is therefore sensitive to changes in prices and costs. As a result a project does not pay RRT until it has covered its costs including a return for risk. In addition, the RRT's responsiveness removes the threat of premature closure of production when oil prices are low.

Following the introduction of the more efficient RRT, significant investment is now taking place in offshore Commonwealth waters. This is expected to provide incentives for the recovery of oil and gas that otherwise would not have been produced. New developments are under way in Bass Strait and off the coast of Western Australia while recent gas discoveries in the Otway Basin are encouraging. The outcome is that markets can be assured that long term stable supplies of petroleum will not be impeded or distorted by secondary taxation.

The strong linkage between the RRT and natural gas prices assumed in the recommendation cannot be substantiated. A number of factors intervene between the RRT and the consumer to determine gas prices. These factors, which differ from one region to another, include the availability of gas, the presence of alternative energy supplies, production costs and the policies of State Governments.

For example, in Victoria a prime factor influencing natural gas prices to end consumers is the State Government's levy on the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria—the Public Authority Contribution Charge (PAC). The PAC, which collected $265 million in 1991-92, is three to four times the RRT attributed to natural gas if passed on. The Victorian Government has the option of reducing this charge. Currently the average city gate gas price in Melbourne before the PAC is applied is about one third of the price in other cities.
In light of these factors, the application of the RRT to petroleum production, including gas, will not inhibit the application of natural gas for cogeneration.

In relation to gas price instability, gas prices will continue to be determined by market forces. The Government has limited scope to influence pricing and it has no desire to formally regulate gas prices which in itself can lead to inefficiencies.

In future, price stability and transparency will be enhanced by improved national competition arrangements (as a result of the report by the Independent Committee of Inquiry into National Competition Policy, chaired by Professor Fred Hilmer and released in August 1993) and due to an industry specific regulatory framework for interstate trade in gas designed to increase competition and efficiency in gas conveyancing by eliminating discriminatory pricing, pipeline monopoly abuse and removing impediments to third party access to gas pipelines.

On 2 June 1993 the Government announced its intention to develop a regulatory framework for interstate gas pipelines, including arrangements for pipeline access and a role for the Trade Practices Commission in arbitrating access disputes.
Recommendation 6: The energy authorities vigorously pursue the possibilities of achieving emission reductions through such measures as shared reserve capacity. (Para 5.62)
Supported.

The sharing of reserve capacity is possible where there are strong interconnections across the transmission system sufficient to enable the transfer of power if required. At the present time, the non-interconnected States are required to maintain their own reserve capacity to cover any possible failure of their largest generating unit. The sharing of reserve capacity between linked systems has the potential to cut emissions through reduced fuel use.

One of the tasks given to the NGMC by Heads of Governments is to examine the scope for upgrading the existing links between New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and for new links between Victoria and Tasmania (Basslink) and between New South Wales and Queensland (Northlink). Although the feasibility studies for these various projects are being pursued by relevant States, the NGMC has been given a coordinating role.

The NGMC has already reported to Heads of Government with regard to upgrading of the New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia interconnections. That report indicated that upgrading of the links was not economic until the latter part of the decade. The existing links are relatively small and are primarily used for opportunity interchanges of power. Their small capacity provide for only limited sharing of reserve capacity.

Recent studies on Basslink indicate that the optimal timing is about the year 2000. With regard to Northlink, the technical feasibility of both DC and AC interconnections is currently being evaluated. Preliminary studies indicate economic justification before the end of the century.

The upgrading of the existing links and the provisions of new links would provide greater opportunity for the sharing between interconnected States of spinning reserve, with consequent fuel savings and positive environmental benefits through reduced emissions. There would also be considerable economic benefits, as identified in the Committee's report.
Recommendation 7: Queensland not be included in the initial assessment of possible grid extensions and until it could be demonstrated that their inclusion can be achieved economically. (Para 5.64)
Not supported.

The main concern of the Committee over the Northlink proposal derives from the view that transmission losses could erode the environmental benefits of the sharing of spinning reserve, with consequent fuel savings. The economic benefits of new links are addressed in response to Recommendation 6. However, such grid augmentations or extensions should only proceed where they can be demonstrated to be economic.

A major part of the assessment work being carried out by the States is to determine the economic merits of various proposals. At the present time Queensland is considering the construction of new generating capacity to meet the State's projected electricity needs from the end of the decade and beyond. The Commonwealth considers that this evaluation should also consider the merits of Northlink, which would enable the construction of expensive new capacity in Queensland to be delayed. The link would enable some of Queensland's power needs to be met by New South Wales which has considerable excess capacity.

Recommendation 8: That the most appropriate structure (vertically integrated or separating generation, transmission and distribution) should be determined following an examination of systems in each State and their potential contribution to the national grid. (Para 6.42)
Not supported.

The Committee did not support the separation of generation, transmission and distribution and more generally the pursuit of a competitive market model for the electricity supply industry, suggesting that the benefits of competition are based on theoretical models. Furthermore, it was suggested that competition would see environmental considerations ignored in favour of maximising returns on investment.

The Committee's views are at odds with the direction of reform proposed and the views of Heads of Government. The desirability of a competitive market was recognised by all governments in Australia at an early stage of electricity industry reform. From the outset the NGMC, as required by Heads of Government, developed the Protocol and the market trading and transmission pricing proposals in a manner which supports the competitive market approach.

The Committee's position is also contrary to the Commonwealth's preferred reform options set out in the National Electricity Strategy: A Discussion Paper issued in May 1992. The Commonwealth in that paper argued that the adoption of certain structural reforms was the key to the establishment of a competitive generation sector. In this regard, it proposed the separation of transmission into a National Grid Corporation, independent of generation and distribution interests, as the first essential step in the development of a competitive market. The need for structural separation is clearly argued in the National Electricity: A Strategy Discussion Paper. It is worth reiterating that the Commonwealth considers that structural separation is a necessary prerequisite to ensure that there is open and fair competition between generation and transparency of charging for access to the transmission grid. It also removes potential conflicts of interest and the potential for cross subsidies between different sectors of the industry and provides the greatest level of certainty for new entrants.

As early as the 11 May 1992 Council of Australian Governments' Meeting, Heads of Government accepted the principle of separate generation and transmission elements in the electricity sector. This was reaffirmed at the 7 December 1992 CoAG meeting. It was made clear, in a subsequent letter from the Prime Minister to State and Territory leaders that separation went beyond mere ring fencing. It appears that this latter position was arrived at too late for the Committee to take into account in its report.

More recently, at the 8-9 June 1993 meeting of CoAG, in considering a report prepared by the NGMC on the structure of the transmission network, participating Heads of Government agreed to the establishment of the interstate transmission network through adoption of the Multiple Network Corporation model. This will effectively separate the transmission, generation and distribution functions. Governments have further agreed to work to have the Multiple Network Corporation structure in place by 1 July 1995, consistent with the NGMC timetable for the introduction of a competitive electricity market. Only South Australia and Tasmania have, at this stage, reserved their position pending further examination of the appropriateness of this structure for them.

Governments have already taken steps to implement the decisions taken at the June CoAG meeting. The Victorian Government for instance, announced on 10 August that the State Electricity Commission of Victoria would be divided into three separate business enterprises comprising generation, transmission and distribution by 1 October 1993. In May 1993, the Queensland Government announced a restructuring of its electricity supply industry. The vertically integrated Queensland Electricity Commission is to be split into two Government owned corporations. One corporation will contain generation activities and the other transmission and distribution. The corporatisation process is due to be completed by 1 January 1995.

The Commonwealth's preferred option of a National Grid Corporation has not been closed off. Heads of Government have agreed to further examine, during the course of the establishment of the Multiple Network Corporation structure, whether the network structure for Governments to work towards should be a National Network Corporation or another option.

The concern expressed by the Committee that a competitive market will be detrimental to the achievement of environmental objectives appears misplaced. As discussed elsewhere, the Protocol indicates that the national grid will provide for the competitive sourcing of new capacity, including through demand management. Demand management has hitherto received only minor support from electricity authorities. Implementation of the Protocol principles should encourage the development of energy service companies providing demand side measures on a commercial basis. The competitive sourcing process, whether demand or supply side, will ensure least cost long-term solutions.
Recommendation 9: That as an expression of commitment to the reform process, the states give legislative force to the draft National Grid Protocol. (Para 6.61)
Recommendation 12: That a charter for electricity authorities be developed in preference to central regulation. (Para 7.30)
Recommendation 17: That governments consider the imposition of a strong regulatory structure (where the proposed charter for the electricity authorities fails) (Para 8.12)
Recommendation 18: The development of a national charter for public electricity authorities. (Para 8.37)
Supported in principle.

As part of moves toward the development of a national electricity market, the Government acknowledges the benefits of national, uniform objectives and priorities for the electricity industry. This would be an effective means by which environmental objectives such as least cost planning, demand management and the other priorities identified by the Committee might be pursued.

The commitment of governments to micro-reform in the electricity supply industry is not in question. Governments have committed substantial resources to this end and are actively pursuing reform within the NGMC established by Heads of Government for that purpose.

The first issue of the National Grid Protocol, published in December 1992, cannot be considered to be a final document. It has been developed having regard to assumptions about the present and possible future organisational environment for the industry. The Protocol will be subject to continual review and annual reporting, so that it will evolve as necessary, in accordance with principles agreed by Heads of Government. It is therefore a flexible document. To give the Protocol legislative force would pose unnecessary obstacles to further amendment.

There are, nevertheless, aspects of the Protocol as well as other dimensions of the electricity reform agenda which will require passage of legislation. Clearly legislation will be required to effect structural reform and in respect of regulation required to govern certain aspects of behaviour of the industry.

In the Government's view, the Protocol will effectively perform the function of a national charter for the electricity supply industry. The Protocol, even at this early stage of its development, has provisions which address many of the priorities the Committee identified in its report as being important elements of the proposed national charter.

Clearly it would, however, be inappropriate for such a charter to be applied to public utilities only. There is a growing trend toward private investment in the electricity supply industry, such as the partial sale of Loy Yang B in Victoria, the proposed purchase of the Gladstone power station by CRA and the proposal for the private construction of a power station at Collie in Western Australia; although this latter project may no longer proceed on the basis of private ownership. It is important, therefore, that the Protocol be applicable to both the public and private sector to ensure competitive neutrality.

In regard to regulation, the overall objective is that it should be as light handed as possible, with the extent of the required regulation diminishing as competition develops, particularly at the generation level. Regulation needs to be cost effective, transparent, and with a uniform and independent national approach to be adopted. Electricity supply arrangements in the States already involve substantial regulation in various forms. The implementation of a competitive national electricity market is a complex process which will require underpinning by a regulatory framework which will be particularly important in regard to the natural monopoly sectors of the industry. Regulation will be required in a number of areas. These include technical regulation to ensure reliability of system operation; appropriate safety standards to ensure adequate public and workplace safety; environmental regulation to minimise environmental impacts; regulation of market access and market behaviour to sustain and foster competition, including from renewables, and to provide an alternative to competition through determination of arrangements and pricing in the monopoly areas of the industry; and regulation over the financial transfers between market participants.

The development of appropriate regulatory arrangements for the electricity industry is being progressed by an NGMC working group. The working group has prepared an issues paper which was published in July 1993 to assist the process of public consultation. After consideration of the comments and submissions put forward in response to the issues paper, the NGMC will develop a report for governments with recommendations on the regulatory options for a nationally competitive electricity market. This is to be completed for the next meeting of CoAG (end 1993). The NGMC is conscious of the report of the Independent Committee of Inquiry into National Competition Policy chaired by Professor Hilmer and released in August 1993, which is likely to have a direct impact on the regulatory requirements in the electricity industry. The NGMC will take full account of the National Competition Policy report in preparing its recommendations for governments.

Recommendation 10: That this legislative guarantee (the Protocol) open access to the grid and include a mechanism through which demand side measures for making blocks of power available are incorporated into the bidding system. (Para 6.61)

Recommendation 14: That if they have not already done so, authorities and responsible State Government Ministers closely examine methods of reconciling corporate objectives and demand side measures. (Para 7.61)
Supported.
The Committee indicated that one of its key concerns is that participants are guaranteed open access to the grid.

The essential feature of the proposed competitive market developed by the NGMC, as described and set out in the Protocol, is that provision is to be made for non-discriminatory access to the grid by private and public generators and customers. It will enable all participants to be able to freely trade in bulk electricity through the national grid. While the Protocol states that to be a participant, generators must have a capacity of at least 30 MW, and customers must have a demand of 10 MW each, smaller modules, including renewables and demand-side measures, will be encouraged outside the Protocol. The initial limits applying to participants will be reviewed in the light of operating experience. Appropriate regulatory mechanisms will ensure that the market trading arrangements are fair for all participants.

At its meeting on 8-9 June 1993, Heads of Government called for the NGMC to prepare, for consideration by CoAG at its next meeting, a report on demand management opportunities. This was welcomed by the Government. The Government will, through its membership of the NGMC, be pressing for more attention to be given to how demand management can be encouraged within the national grid system to satisfactorily meet economic and environmental objectives. The Government will work to ensure that demand management measures are adopted that are in the best interests of consumers and the wider community. Equally, other environmental matters, including least cost planning, renewable energy and cogeneration will also be pursued in this context.

The Protocol indicates that in the national grid there are to be guidelines for the competitive sourcing of new capacity through demand side measures. It is proposed that new capacity, whether on the demand or the supply side, will be evaluated on an integrated basis which will aim to achieve lowest cost for electricity across the national grid over the long term. The Protocol thus acknowledges the need for a nationally focussed approach to demand side planning.

The Government does recognise, however, that the precise mechanisms by which demand side bidding will be incorporated in the market arrangements were not detailed in the NGMC paper Transition to a National Electricity Market of July 1993. One of the Commonwealth's main objectives is to ensure satisfactory arrangements for demand side bidding which provides the scope for reductions in present levels of power consumption. It is important, nevertheless, that demand bidding be an economic decision. Grid participants, in meeting their need for power should be able to take into account the bids of both generators and companies providing demand side services. The objective is that the proposed spot market should be able to accommodate demand side bidding.

The Government acknowledges that a number of State utilities have developed significant demand management programs in recent years and that these programs have proved quite successful. One of the reasons for this is that demand management programs can postpone the very significant capital investment needed to increase generating capacity in order to meet future demand projections. In this way economic and environmental incentives can work in the same direction.

The proposed separation of generation, transmission and distribution may see further increases in the adoption of demand management. Responsibility for demand management appears to fall most naturally to distributors, which, as part of a least cost planning approach to supplying customers, would be able to sell both supply and demand services. Distributors would no longer be constrained by broader corporate goals. Indeed, moves in this direction have already commenced. Sydney Electricity, the largest distribution authority in New South Wales recently announced it has established a new business venture, Sydney Electricity Energy Services, in partnership with energy management consultant Enman Pty Ltd, to provide demand management services, covering all forms of energy, not just electricity.

Recommendation 11: That the State Governments take action to expand the membership of the NGMC to include representation from industry and community groups, including trade union, environmental and consumer groups, and persons with expertise in demand management and environmental matters. (Para 6.63)
Supported.

The Government is committed to pursuing this objective through its membership on the NGMC. The Commonwealth has always been of the view that the membership of the NGMC should be expanded to include the key parties and sectors which have a valid interest in the reform outcome. This position is consistent with the Commonwealth's view as outlined in the National Electricity Strategy: A Discussion Paper which called for the evolution of the NGMC into a more broadly-based National Electricity Industry Council.

The NGMC was established by Heads of Government to report to them and that membership of the Council is subject to their joint agreement. Any change to the current membership is therefore something which the Commonwealth cannot progress unilaterally.

The Commonwealth has sought, at every appropriate opportunity, to press upon other members of the NGMC the need to expand membership as a matter of priority. At the Council of Australian Governments meeting on 8-9 June 1993, the Minister for Resources, the Hon Michael Lee, MP proposed that the membership of the NGMC be expanded to include a customer, union and distributor representative. The proposal was opposed by a number of States.

In the absence of what the Government would regard to be satisfactory membership of the NGMC, the reaffirmation by Heads of Government of the need for the NGMC to consult widely and visibly with major stakeholders was welcomed. The Commonwealth strongly supports the need for extensive and meaningful consultation in the process of developing proposals, particularly with key parties such as industry, and will work to ensure that this occurs.

The question of an expanded membership is, nevertheless, one of a number of issues that are to be further discussed at the next CoAG meeting to be held later this year. The matter is likely to be dealt with in the context of the three year review of the performance and organisational structure of the NGMC, scheduled to be completed by July 1994. It was decided that the parameters of this review would be agreed at the next CoAG meeting.

The Government welcomes the decision taken by the NGMC at its meeting of 23 June 1993 to establish a consultative committee comprising representatives of non utility grid participants to provide analysis and advice from their perspective on matters relevant to the development of a competitive interstate electricity market. This committee will offer an opportunity to involve, on a more formal basis than exists at present, other industry stakeholders in the Council's reform program. Draft Terms of Reference have been prepared for the committee which is expected to comprise 10 to 15 people. NGMC members have been asked to nominate possible representatives for inclusion on the committee. For its part, the Commonwealth has nominated a business, union, distributor and environmental representative for inclusion on the committee.

Recommendation 13: That this level of transparency (publication of comprehensive reports about activities and tabling of an annual report) be increased through the establishment in each State Parliament of a Parliamentary Committee to scrutinise the operations of energy authorities and to consider any major initiatives or changes in policy direction. (Para 7.31)
Noted.

The rationale for the Committee's recommendation flows from its view that there is a need for greater transparency and accountability for utility operations. This recommendation is essentially a matter for State Government consideration. The Government has a broad interest in the micro-economic reform of the electricity supply and gas industries as well as specific interests with respect to the Snowy Mountains Scheme and the Pipeline Authority.

The Commonwealth policy in regard to its own Government Business Enterprises (GBE) is clear and generally consistent with the Committee's views. Each GBE should have a clear mandate and set of objectives which include any requirements to meet explicitly stated Government social and economic objectives. Community Service Obligations should be specified and met at minimum cost. The cost of all CSOs must be transparent, and new CSOs normally met from the Budget. CSOs are discussed further in relation to Recommendation 15.

The Commonwealth has a policy of removing when practical special advantages and disadvantages that apply to its business enterprises by virtue of government ownership. Effect was given to this view in the May 1988 Economic Statement when the Government announced that the exemption of Commonwealth businesses from Commonwealth, State and local government taxes and charges would be phased out.

The application of taxes and charges, national competition policy and other competitive conduct norms to State Government Business Enterprises was considered in the National Competition Policy report. The report provides an opportunity for the States and Commonwealth to jointly consider a national policy. The Commonwealth will be seeking an outcome which enhances the ability of private cogeneration, new technologies and demand management options to compete in the supply of electrical power.

In regard to the operation of the Snowy Mountains Scheme, this has been the subject of a tripartite review by the relevant governments. Significant progress has already been made in the reform progress. All three governments recognise that the current legislative and other arrangements governing operation of the Scheme are unsatisfactory and outdated and stand in the way of maximising efficiency. The intention is that the Scheme be corporatised to improve its overall performance and efficiency and to improve competition in the south east Australian electricity market. At the June 1993 CoAG meeting, senior officials were asked to report back to Heads of Government on progress in the resolution of reform arrangements for the Scheme, underlining the importance attached to this task.

At the present time, all public electricity authorities, and the Snowy Mountains Authority, provide comprehensive annual reports on their activities which are actively scrutinised in the normal course of government business. From time to time, the utilities also prepare more specialised reports on specific aspects of their activities.

All governments, as part of their participation in the NGMC process, are being required to actively consider the implications for their electricity supply industries of the introduction of a competitive market in eastern and southern Australia. This has meant that the utilities have come under public and political scrutiny to an unparalleled extent. All governments, as part of broad structural and efficiency reform initiatives, have either completed or are in the process of comprehensively reviewing the future structure, function and operating parameters of their electricity supply industries. Even Western Australia, which is not a participant on the NGMC process, has recently undertaken a review of its electricity supply industry. The individual reviews being conducted by the States complements the work being done by the NGMC.

In addition, the electricity supply industry, having been identified as a target for micro-economic reform, has been the subject of extensive performance monitoring in the recent past. For instance, the Industry Commission report Energy Generation and Distribution was released in May 1991, this was followed by a research report by the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) International Performance Indicators: Electricity in February 1992. A contribution to the BIE study was made by the Business Council of Australia which commissioned a study by Swan Consultants An International Benchmark for Australia's Electricity Supply Industry (November 1991). The Electricity Supply Association of Australia (ESAA) on 20 August released its study Measuring the Efficiency of the Australian Electricity Supply Industry. An international bench-marking study is to be released by the ESAA shortly.

The utilities will not escape from the need for comprehensive performance monitoring and reporting after the establishment of the competitive electricity market. The Protocol indicates that a monitoring and reporting system will be established in order to provide the national and international comparisons needed to assess the effectiveness of the organisational arrangements. The reporting system is to provide appropriate measures of grid performance. The precise performance indicators are yet to be fully developed by the NGMC. It is appropriate that, with the development of a national market, the reporting requirements are developed on a consistent national basis, for both private and public participants in the grid, to ensure competitive neutrality and a common basis for comparison to enable appropriate bench-marking.
Recommendation 15: That governments make separately identified provision to meet these (community service) obligations. (Para 7.68)
Supported.

Pricing policies of utilities are often designed by governments to meet objectives other than efficiency. These policies require utilities to fund a range of community service obligations (CSOs), which frequently involve the subsidisation of particular classes of consumers, and this leads to inappropriate tariff structures. In general in Australia, industrial and small commercial consumers tend to cross subsidise domestic consumers. The imposition of uniform customer tariffs across customer classes also results in urban consumers subsidising rural consumers. As a consequence, energy prices may not reflect the full cost of production and supply. This has hindered the development of alternative energy technologies, for example stand-alone remote area systems, especially those based on renewables. An alternative approach for utilities might be the provision of serviced stand-alone remote area power systems to meet the needs of customers in these areas. Such stand alone power systems may be more cost effective than new transmission line extensions and as well as reducing the cost of meeting CSOs to these customers.

As part of the process of micro-economic reform, governments need to examine ways to remove impediments to the development of alternative energy sources so that energy prices can more fully reflect costs of supply, for example by eliminating cross-subsidies on remote area grid connections and removing any requirement for uniform state-wide electricity prices. If social objectives are considered essential, the associated costs could be met by way of direct appropriations from governments rather than indirectly through utilities: moreover such an approach has the advantage of being more transparent. Alternatively, the cost of CSOs could be explicitly identified in balance sheets, with returns to Governments being reduced by an equivalent amount. Regardless of the methodology adopted for meeting the cost of CSOs, they should be explicitly and transparently identified.

Recommendation 16: That an evaluation process be undertaken about the effect of foreign ownership of Australia's electricity generation infrastructure and whether this is in Australia's longer term economic and strategic interests. (Para 7.89)
Not supported.

At the present time the only foreign owned electricity infrastructure in Australia is a 51% share of Loy Yang B in Victoria by Mission Energy of the US, the remainder is in public hands. About six per cent of Australia's electricity is generated by private firms for their own use and for public supply in remote areas. There is no information on the degree of foreign ownership of this portion of the industry.

The Government's foreign investment policy is framed and administered with a view to encouraging foreign investment and ensuring that such investment is consistent with the needs of the community. The Government recognises the substantial contribution foreign investment makes to the development of Australia's industries and resources. Capital from other countries supplements domestic savings and provides scope for higher rates of economic activity and employment. Foreign capital also provides access to new technology, management skills and overseas markets.

The Government is in a position to maintain a watching brief over any increases in foreign ownership of electricity generation infrastructure. All foreign investment proposals to acquire existing businesses with assets in excess of $50 million are examined by the Foreign Investment Review Board.

Recommendation 19: That ERDC set up a working group in connection with the ESAA to identify means to encourage the commercialisation of renewable energy technologies, and in doing so to pay specific attention to the potential for local manufacturing and export. (Para 9.52)
Supported.

As part of the first phase of the NGRS, governments are committed to expanding the use of renewable energy sources in generating electricity wherever there are suitable opportunities, and to increasing support for energy research, development and demonstration, particularly of renewable energies. ANZMEC has been delegated to investigate the scope to promote commercialisation of renewable energy and energy efficient technologies in the industrial and commercial sectors. The Government will pursue this action through its membership of ANZMEC.

The Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC) supports this recommendation. ERDC is currently developing a renewable energy research strategy that aims to bring together and help focus the direction of its and industries' investment in renewables, as part of the total energy mix for the future. In doing so ERDC is liaising with relevant industry groups such as the Electricity Supply Association of Australia (ESAA) and the Australian and New Zealand Solar Energy Society on an informal basis. A number of joint research projects with ESAA and the utilities are under way. The ERDC is also liaising with the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development which is presently preparing an industry development strategy in consultation with the renewable energy industry. This strategy will focus on the employment and wealth creation and export potential opportunities that increased global environmental concerns are providing.

In line with its commitment to increase support for renewable energy research, development and demonstration, the Government will follow up on ERDC's renewable energy research strategy once it is completed. Before any financial or other incentives can be given to industry to manufacture renewable energy technologies, there will need to be sufficient preliminary research into the economic viability of the particular technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies on the 0055 reverse phone directory service. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE TO THE REPORT FROM THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING ELECTRONIC TECHNOLOGIES

PARA.TAB: The Government's response to the Committee's report incorporates Telstra's response, a copy of which is attached.
Telecom produces telephone directories and provides integrated directory assistance services in accordance with the terms of its general telecommunications carrier licence.

The Government supports the Committee's Recommendation 1 that a principle of informed consent apply in relation to the use and re-use for commercial purposes of telephone directories containing personal details of individual subscribers.

AUSTEL in its Telecommunications Privacy Report recommended that compilers and purchasers of reverse phone directories be encouraged to develop a code of conduct which recognised the sensitive issues that relate to these directories.
These issues are, at present, being considered by the Government in the context of its approach to privacy issues in general.

Telstra in its response has outlined its view that internationally agreed privacy principles be applied, which require information subjects to be aware of the uses to which information is to be put or should consent to particular applications.

It is the role of the Privacy Commissioner to encourage carriers to observe the Information Privacy Principles based on OECD guidelines. These were designed to be applicable to both public and private sector practices, but are not, as AUSTEL pointed out in its Privacy report, particularly easy to translate into practical guidelines for those involved in the telecommunications industry.

The Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, however, is able to investigate complaints relating to the interference with the privacy of a person in terms of non-compliance with the Privacy Principles contained in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988 or any industry specific standards which may be applicable at the time.

In relation to Recommendation 2, Telstra has in its response indicated that it has forwarded the Committee's report and recommendations to the Telephone Information Services Standards Committee requesting that the 0055 Code of Practice be suitably amended as a matter of priority.

Telstra has also advised that it has issued a direction to all Service Providers utilising the 0055 service (consistent with Recommendation 3) indicating that any reverse phone directory offered on a 0055 service should contain only business information similar to the Yellow Pages. Any advertising relating to reverse phone directories should also indicate that only business information is available.

The Government supports the view as outlined in Recommendation 4, that subscribers have the right not to include personal data in a directory and that their consent must be obtained before their personal data is provided by directory inquiry services.

Telecommunications carriers, suppliers (which includes service providers) and their employees are already prohibited under section 88 of the Telecommunications Act 1991 from disclosing silent number information, except in specified circumstances such as where consent is given, in life threatening emergencies or where the disclosure is made to law enforcement agencies for enforcement of criminal law.

However, while Telstra does not publish silent numbers in its white pages, Telstra's "Electronic White Pages" do list the name and initial of customers with silent lines with the identification NP (not for publication). (Up until April 1993, such listings also showed a locality and a postcode.) The Government does not consider this to be appropriate.

It is the view of the Government that there would be a reasonable expectation on the part of Telstra's customers that names of persons holding silent numbers should not appear in any directory outside Telstra.

I have written to the Chairman of Telstra requesting that Telstra closely review its handling of silent line numbers. In particular that Telstra consider the privacy implications of the name of a subscriber with a silent number appearing in the "Electronic White Pages".
In relation to the question of charging for silent lines, the Government considers that it is essentially a matter for the commercial judgement of Telstra.

Telstra has advised that the charge for silent lines is for the maintenance of security within its database. Telstra has also advised that it makes over four million changes to its data base each year making it necessary to develop a series of sophisticated checking processes in order to minimise any risk of silent numbers being inadvertently published. The charge, therefore, covers Telstra's cost of administering these security procedures.

Telstra is planning to introduce the option of excluding the address from White Pages directories, (suppressed address), by mid-1994. Telstra has advised that this option will, as in the case of the "silent line" option, incur a fee to cover the costs of administration and provision of security.
The Government recognises that privacy in relation to telecommunications is an area of legitimate concern to many people. AUSTEL's report has provided a useful analysis of the issues.

The Government agrees with AUSTEL that it is appropriate to establish a forum for consideration of these issues. An avenue for individual complaints is provided by the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman.

Consultations between the Department of Communications and the Arts, the Department of the Attorney-General, AUSTEL, the Privacy Commissioner and the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman have been necessary in order to formulate the Government's approach to privacy issues as they relate to the telecommunications industry. The Government expects to be in a position to respond to the AUSTEL report shortly.
Privacy issues will also be considered as part of the Government's foreshadowed review of telecommunications policy and regulatory arrangements to apply after 1997.
In conclusion, on behalf of the Government, I thank the Committee for a comprehensive report on the issue of reverse phone directories and related privacy issues.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 15 March, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation's mission includes the term `sustainability'. In practice, this is rarely interpreted as `ecologically sustainable'. In fact, the chairperson's report does not mention the word, and I heard on the grapevine that he actually does not like his staff mentioning it either. So we have a report that is supposed to be dealing with research on the environment that does not seem to believe in ecological sustainability. It would be good to have the mission amended so that it has a greater ecological base. The water programs have a greater ecological component than the land programs, which tend to be more about stability of productivity rather than ecological sustainability.

PARA.TAB: The corporation interprets its scope under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act as being supportive of existing primary industry. There is rarely acknowledgment of the need to examine whether such industries can be sustainable, let alone assumptions that changing practices will make them sustainable regardless of climatic, geographical, economic or biological constraints—that is, there is no questioning of the dominant production-based paradigm.

The corporation recognises the need for research and development in sociological and economic aspects of primary production, but has not necessarily translated this into research dollars. There is still a tendency for the technological fix. The corporation recognises the need for integrated, multi-disciplinary and multi-regional approaches. Unfortunately, this tends to be difficult in practice given the cultural barriers between nature conservation and primary production agencies, the institutional barriers between states and so on. The corporation is doing a reasonable job of forcing agencies and people together, but there are external constraints that are difficult to overcome.

An amount of $10.4 million from the Commonwealth government is not all that much to address research and development in all areas of ecological sustainability across the nation. While there has been considerable success in levying money in other areas, a number of other rural research and development corporations are not paying sufficient attention to ecological sustainability. Some additional funds may be gained through a direct levy on producers, which would be of great assistance.

There are still difficulties in coordinating research with the extension and adoption of programs, especially given the new delivery mechanisms for the national landcare program. The corporation considers research priorities, programs and projects well in advance to assist institutional planning. It requires that all research projects have an adoption component and is willing to find some or all of this. However, researchers have no way of ensuring that research priorities will have their adoption or extension components recommended for funding by regional or state based processes. This has been looked at, but not at the state level.

The corporation has done a reasonable job at ensuring that all projects and programs funded have a well thought out adoption and communication plan included and implemented. Some areas of research and development that tend to fall through the cracks are weeds, alternative land management, and inland rivers and waterways. But some of these are considered marginal issues. There is a long way to go and perhaps the major complaint that the Greens would have is that it is time we took the potential that we have with such a research and development corporation and translated it into action based on real ecological sustainability. It is also time to accept that we need to take action soon.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Debate resumed from 15 March, on motion by Senator Patterson:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: The government and the Law Reform Commission are to be congratulated, firstly, for the reference and, secondly, for this report. Significant problems have been identified by the report. Primarily, the report identifies the difficulty of women obtaining access to justice. There are structural problems embedded in the system of justice in Australia which militate against women obtaining due and proper access. For example, the paradigm for self-defence is based on a bar-room brawl, which is not appropriate for women endeavouring to protect themselves and their children. Similarly, premeditation as a factor that aggravates an offence is one that has a gender bias in its interpretation.

PARA.TAB: Even when there is formal equality, the lacunae in the legal system often result in women suffering. This is most apparent in the area of domestic violence. Traditional legal mechanisms have not afforded protection against domestic violence. From the material in this interim report it is clear that more needs to be done, both in the law and the mechanisms of access to and enforcement of the law. The Greens (WA) support the recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission that a national women's justice program be established. We see this as a priority and call on the government to ensure that funds are made available in this budget.

The Greens (WA) also look forward to further reports of the Australian Law Reform Commission on this reference and note that proper recognition and responses to the legal problems of women can occur only when women are adequately represented at all levels of the legal system, including the legislature.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to move notice of motion No. 680 standing in my name but, to enable that motion to be debated together with notice of motion No. 682 standing in the name of Senator Lees, I seek leave to move them together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: No.1—That the Senate—
(a)rejects the claim of Government members that this chamber was conceived solely as a State's house and should be abolished or weakened because it no longer performs that role;

(b)recognises that, contrary to this rewriting of history, the framers of the Constitution envisaged that this chamber would also be a house of review, with many favouring proportional representation to strengthen that role;
c)notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i)this is confirmed by statements made by Mr Edmund Barton and Mr Alfred Deakin who voiced strong support for proportional representation in Senate elections, and
(ii)the first bill to establish Parliament's electoral system, introduced in 1902, provided for proportional representation in this chamber;

SPEECH.PARA: (d)emphasises that the 1902 bill was rejected against the view of the Government of the day which argued that proportional representation was the only way to prevent this chamber from becoming a clone of the House of Representatives; and

(e)calls on the Keating Government to show the same mature commitment to democracy, and acknowledge the importance of an independent house of review elected by the present system of proportional representation.
No.2—That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i)proportional representation for Senate elections was introduced by the Labor Government of Mr Ben Chifley in 1948, and
(ii)the minister responsible for the legislation was none other than Dr Herbert Vere Evatt, to whom Senator Evans' Blue Book is dedicated;

SPEECH.PARA: (b)recognises that, notwithstanding the self-interest behind Labor's 1948 legislation, it attracted bi-partisan support because it strengthened and stabilised this chamber's house of review function;

(c)strongly believes that, by contrast, the self-interest behind the Keating Government's proposal for single member Senate electorates is a power grab which is not redeemed by any principle or higher purpose; and

(d)supports this chamber's proportional representation system, which for 46 years has ensured that party representation in this chamber reflects national voter support much more accurately than in the House of Representatives, notwithstanding the different sizes of the States.

Recent statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about his wish to abolish the proportional representation system in the Senate is the talk of a would-be emperor determined to achieve absolute power. However, he has been careful to dress up this grab for power in the trappings of democracy, claiming that this house was historically conceived solely as a states' house, that it is unrepresentative and that it is driven by the ambition to usurp the responsibilities of the executive. These are accusations he made on 3 March of this year when he answered a question from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), who asked whether it was his desire to alter the proportional voting system—no doubt a very handy dorothy dixer at the time.

PARA.TAB: When we go behind the rhetoric and look at the historic facts, we see that the Prime Minister is quite obviously wrong. This house was not conceived solely as a states' house. With regard to his claim that the Senate is undemocratic, he would do well to look at the facts. Far from usurping the rights of the executive, this house and my party, the Australian Democrats, are committed to ensuring that the executive remains accountable. This is, of course, the nub of the question. What really irks Mr Keating and what motivates all his utterances on the proportional representation issue is the Senate's determination to hold this government accountable.

I have no doubt that the Prime Minister would like the Democrats to just roll over when his ministers throw away public money with gay abandon at election time. I am sure he would want this house to ignore secret deals done with media organisations to ensure `balanced' coverage at election times. I am sure he would like a less powerful Auditor-General's office. I am sure he would like to prepare his budget without proper consultation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure he would like to be a dictator.

—Indeed he would. Like other arrogant leaders, he would like to rule without those features of government which make a system responsible. Like a ruler in a totalitarian regime, he would prefer to rule by edict rather than by legislation. I believe he has forgotten that he is a servant rather than the master of the government.

PARA.TAB: It is in the Senate that the voice of government is heard. Mr Keating's talk of changing the proportional system is his attempt at ensuring that that voice is silenced. I am confident that this house and the people of Australia will not allow this to happen. After 10 years of the Senate providing an effective check on government, it is hard to imagine that the community would want a Senate without the Democrats exercising independent scrutiny.

Mr Keating's rhetoric about the Senate usurping the privileges of the executive is in fact doublespeak for the Senate exercising its role as a true house of review. That role not only means that government is held accountable for its shortcomings and failures, but also that the government's legislation is scrutinised and assessed on its merits.

As a house of review, the Senate has a record of which it can be justly proud. The figures are revealing. Mr John Uhr, a senior lecturer at the ANU, has done some interesting analysis of the way legislation has been dealt with in this house. Of the 1,850 bills which have been passed by both houses in the 10 years between 1983 and 1993, around 20 per cent have been amended by the Senate. Some 5,000 amendments have been moved; some 1,055 were successful.

In addition, one can safely assume that a large proportion of the 1,950 amendments moved by the government were either inspired by the Democrats and Independents or were introduced to forestall or accommodate amendments we had foreshadowed. These figures do not represent the process of obstruction by non-government parties, but are a record of these parties contributing constructively to the improvement of legislation.

Examples of Democrat amendments are as diverse as capping Medicare costs for chronically ill people, including mentally ill people in disability legislation; protecting hard-pressed farmers from a further toughening of the assets tests; and prohibiting discrimination in employment on the grounds of age, disability and sexual preference.

The contributions to the formulation of policy made by the Senate committee system is also evidence of the constructive role played by the Senate in the legislative system. Indeed, the Senate has done its most constructive and reputable work in the area of legislative scrutiny, with an emphasis on civil liberties through such committees as that on delegated legislation, the scrutiny of bills committee, the legal and constitutional affairs committee and others, protecting the community against Mr Keating's sometimes very high-handed legislation.

Eliminating the Australian Democrats and Independents will have one of two results: either a rubber stamp Senate, which is controlled by the government, or a Senate dominated by the opposition, causing confrontational stand-offs and constitutional instability, as in 1975.
