Indeed, members of the Liberal Party have not excluded supporting Mr Keating, obviously in the hope that they will enjoy the spoils of absolute power when their turn comes. I was present at the meeting with Mr Downer when he suggested that if we do not support the opposition on budget legislation, this might indeed be the course of action that the opposition parties will take.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that was a joke.

—He said it with a smile, but the first thought that came to my mind was: this is gentle blackmail; perhaps it was not all that gentle. However, such a change, if it were supported by both major parties—which I am sure are both itching to get their hands on the lever of absolute power—would disfranchise the more than 20 per cent of people who cannot bring themselves to vote for either of the old parties and remove effective scrutiny of government action.

PARA.TAB: This is the other aspect of the Democrats role: to represent the people deeply concerned about the environment; peace issues; poverty here and overseas; unemployment; the rights of minority groups—Aboriginal people, sole parents, ethnic people, the disabled, the mentally ill, and people who are different such as the gay and lesbian community; and, indeed, about the government's responsibility to take action on economic and social issues to redress these failures of what should be, but is not, good government.

Mr Keating's assertion that the Senate is an unrepresentative house conveniently ignores how successful the proportional representation system has been in ensuring that the popular vote has been reflected in actual representation in the Senate, in contrast to the inequities of the single member preferential system adopted in the House of Representatives.

In the 11 years that the Labor government has been in power, not once has the Labor government won a majority of votes. Its largest share was 49.5 per cent in 1983. In 1990 it dropped to 39.4 per cent. In 1987 and 1990 the ALP was out-polled by the coalition. Last year's elections saw 45 per cent of the vote return 54 per cent of the seats. There is not much support here for Mr Keating's claim that the House of Representatives is a truly representative house.

Honourable senators should compare this to the vote of the minor parties at the last election. The Greens (WA), Democrats and others who polled 12 per cent in the Senate vote got 10 per cent of the seats. In the House of Representatives election the same grouping polled 10 per cent of the vote and got just over one per cent of the seats. These figures speak for themselves.

Mr Keating's analysis of the history of the Senate is typically ideologically driven. It is well known that the design of the Senate repeatedly gave rise to some of the most bitter disputes during the 1890s conventions. However, it is a misrepresentation that those debates were simply about how to entrench state powers in the Senate. It is more accurate to say that they were directed at three things: setting up a house of review in a federal structure; ensuring accountability of the executive; and providing for a system of proportional representation that would reflect popular political sentiment.

The element of proportional representation was crucial to the framers' design so that the Senate, by representing minority interests, would provide the checks and balances expected of a house of review. Indeed, Edmund Barton and Alfred Deakin were two of the framers who voiced strong support for the concept of proportional representation.

It should be noted that the first Commonwealth electoral bill introduced in 1902 provided for proportional representation for Senate elections and optional preferential voting for the House of Representatives. It was only after the first of the political deals that have characterised the history of proportional representation was done that a system of simple majority was adopted for both houses. This was over the advice of the government of the day that proportional representation was the only way to prevent the Senate becoming a clone of the House of Representatives.

I mention briefly a possible amendment foreshadowed by Senator Kemp which would suggest that my motion would include the statement that the representation of all states should be equal. We know that this is anchored in the constitution; we also know that the Senate does not operate as a states' house any more. While we do not suggest that this particular provision should be overturned, we are somewhat reluctant to accept it as a principle that should be enshrined forever. The Australian Democrats believe that there may be scope in the future to move towards regional government, for instance. Therefore, while we strongly believe that the Senate should always be elected by proportional representation, the representation of each state need not at all times in the future be equal, and certainly we should not commit ourselves at this point in time to that position.

The Australian Democrats believe it is quite on the cards that as the constitutional reform process in this country moves forward, while we should always ensure that the Senate is elected by proportional representation and remains a proper check on the government, the position of individual states should remain an open issue.

It is interesting to note the absurdity of the results that the defeat of the framers' intentions has achieved. For example, in 1934 a united Australia Party-Country Party coalition and the ALP divided the Senate by 33 to three. In 1946 the ALP government and the Liberal-Country Party divided the Senate in reverse order. It should be remembered that it was the ALP which, in 1948, saw the light and changed the system back to that envisaged by the framers of the constitution and introduced proportional representation. I do not say that it was done for elevated political reasons—the government was facing defeat at the polls—but what I do say is that it introduced a system the framers of the constitution always envisaged.

However, the main issue in this debate remains that the Senate should be preserved as a democratic check on government. Even people who do not always agree with our policies might oppose Mr Keating's push to get rid of the Democrats and turn the Senate into a rubber stamp. If they do, they should make it clear to Mr Keating that accountability to the community is essential for democratic government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motions moved by Senator Spindler. The coalition will be supporting these motions. However, we wish to foreshadow an amendment to Senator Spindler's motion. Senator Spindler's speech was a little like the proverbial curate's egg—it was good in parts and in other parts it was distinctly bad. It was good when Senator Spindler carefully analysed the real motives of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and why he is acting in this manner. That was the good part of the curate's egg. The bad part of the curate's egg was in the last part where he threw doubt on the current method of election of senators. There are two central principles or elements to the current method of election of senators. The first element is the use of a proportional representation system. The second element is that all states have an equal number of senators.
—Except the Northern Territory.

—All states, I said. It seems to me, if the Democrats persist with the view that has been put to us, it leaves open the very danger which Senator Spindler is most worried about. I think this whole system of electing the Senate depends on these two principles. Senator Spindler strongly supported one; he has not given support to the other. I would have to say that even if he had agreed to support this amendment, it is not enshrined in concrete forever, as he seemed to imply. The motions that we pass in this chamber do not have the weight of constitutional amendment.I am sorry we do not appear to be able to get the support of Senator Spindler for my amendment which enshrines the other great principle of the Senate. I hope Senator Chamarette, her colleague and Senator Harradine will, however, be prepared to support that amendment.

PARA.TAB: As I said, Senator Spindler's analysis of the motives of the Prime Minister was in general a good analysis. One thing I view as I sit on this side of the chamber is not that the Senate has been obstructionist, not that the Senate has forced the government to be too accountable—and I note Senator Richardson is looking curious—

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to know how outrageous this is going to be.
—I say to Senator Richardson that 174 bills have been presented by the government since the last election.
—I hadn't counted them.
—I had. I do my work; Senator Richardson does not. I do the numbers; he did not. He should appreciate that. Of those 174 bills, only four have as yet failed to pass this chamber.
—But how amended were the others?

—Only four bills have failed to pass this chamber. The government has got its program. The government got its budget early. The government, with the cooperation, I regret, of the minor parties in the Senate, was able to impose very substantial tax rises on the Australian public, in contravention of the solemn election promises that Senator Richardson, Mr Keating and his colleagues made during the election.
—You only wanted a GST.

—If Senator Richardson said to the Australian people during the election that his party was going to raise taxes by $3 billion, gee, I missed it and all members of the press missed it. If he was open and frank about his tax plans during the election, and if he did not say he would not be raising taxes, I will be the first to stand up in this chamber and apologise.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you that this is not an obstructionist Senate. I believe that quite the reverse argument applies. For example, there is the contentious issue of sports rorts. There was a proposal before this chamber to have an inquiry into that. Again, the minor parties joined with the government and prevented that inquiry. The government was able to achieve an historic victory for the trade unions. I think it was a bad victory from our perspective and the perspective of employers and future employment in this country. After 10 years of trying, the government, with the cooperation of the Democrats and the Greens, managed to remove sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act. Despite all its attempts in the previous decade, it was not able to achieve this.

The argument can be mounted—it is the argument that I am mounting—that this chamber has been exceedingly cooperative with the government. Yet despite this, Mr Keating cannot brook any challenge at all to his authority. He is not only the most abusive Prime Minister in Australian history; he is probably the most thin-skinned as well. The mere fact that the Senate wishes to debate the legislation he brings forward, the mere fact that the Senate wishes to hold the government more accountable, has led to the spleen Mr Keating has shown against the Senate and to the abuse he has heaped on the Senate. His latest proposal is to change the voting pattern in the Senate to remove any impediment to his capacity to impose his will on the Australian people.

Well-known are the imperial ambitions of Mr Keating. He may not like the royal family but boy is Mr Keating imperial. The test of an emperor is always a total unwillingness to accept any contrary view, to accept any idea that there are other players in the political system. Maybe the Australian people, with their great history of democracy, simply do not wish to give untrammelled power to this Prime Minister or to any Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really cannot believe that Senator Richardson is sincere. The Senate has been more than cooperative with his government, yet still this is not sufficient for him. In another time in another place the great Winston Churchill warned about `a handful of men getting hold of the state machine, having the right to make people do what suits their party, their personal interests or doctrines'. Churchill may well have been speaking this day in this country about this Labor Party. There is no question that Mr Keating and his senior colleagues would like to embark on a constitutional upheaval without parallel in Australian history. The aim of the Keating government is to remove any capacity of our institutions to effectively query or challenge his ambitions.

PARA.TAB: The first item on his agenda is the abolition of the constitutional monarchy. Mr Keating does not want an independent Governor-General; he wants a compliant president. The second item on his agenda, which he has largely achieved, is to strip the House of Representatives of its few remaining powers to force government accountability. He has largely achieved this goal. Mr Keating is the first Prime Minister in 93 years who does not feel that he has to attend question time. All the Prime Ministers that have gone before him have assumed, as we have all assumed, that question time was a vital part of the institution of parliament in which the government could be questioned. Mr Keating has stripped, in large part, the House of Representatives of that capacity. He has shown a remarkable capacity to humiliate the current Speaker of the House of Representatives and to destroy that particular institution as one which can lay claim to any independence whatsoever.

The third item on Mr Keating's agenda is to abolish the Senate or, if this cannot be done immediately, at least to destroy its capacity to review government actions. The fourth item on his agenda is to destroy the federal system and the capacity of the states to act in an independent fashion. He wants Australia to be ruled from Canberra unchallenged. The Democrats, not surprisingly, want their role in our democracy to be protected. I address these remarks particularly to Senator Spindler, who is with us in the chamber. Senator Spindler has made a plea—and many of the arguments he has put forward we would not quarrel with—that there be a role in our constitutional system for the minor parties.

But I would like Senator Spindler to show the same regard as he wants this institution and the Australian people to show him and his party to other major players in the system. I refer, of course, to state governments. I will be proposing an amendment to Senator Spindler's motion which will support his motion. Senator Spindler's motion, of course, is to the effect that the Senate wishes to retain the proportional voting system and also to protect the role of the states. If Senator Spindler wants his role to be protected, he should show consideration to other major players in the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they are more important than state governments.

—I have to say that this motion worries me in the sense that Senator Spindler is opening up a whole new level of debate about election to the Senate. If that is his intention, that is all right, but he is pleading with the Senate to protect his interests. He is saying that we must retain this proportional system of voting for the Senate, which I and my party support, to protect his interests, but he does not want to give that same consideration to the interests of others.

PARA.TAB: A large number of speakers wish to contribute to this important debate. I put it to the Senate that this is an important motion, but it does not go far enough. The amendment I shall move I believe solves that dilemma and affords the states the same sorts of protections as Senator Spindler is seeking for his own particular political party. I now move:
At the end of paragraph (e), add: "based on equal representation for each State within the Federation".

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Kemp and, indeed, to indicate coalition support for the motion moved by Senator Spindler, with the addition of the amendment moved by Senator Kemp. In the time available to me I would like to concentrate on some of the aspects raised by Senator Kemp. Also, as a newly arrived senator in this place, I have some particular aspects I wish to raise.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Kemp indicated, the Senate, in fulfilling the historic role assigned to it in the Australian constitution, has functioned as a house of review. Indeed, even in my short time in the Senate this house has not stood aside from its role of scrutinising and, at times, opposing government policy. To have a chamber that is simply a reflection of government power in the House of Representatives would not be a desirable outcome.

To have the Senate acting as a house of review in which government measures are scrutinised closely, may be sent to a committee, and legislative measures which are seen as impacting too harshly on particular groups in the community may be modified, is indeed a central part of the Australian system of government. To change the present role of the Senate and to introduce measures such as those which have been indicated by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), that is, to have single-member Senate-type electorates in each state, would indeed change the whole notion of the Senate. It would no longer be possible to discuss wider implications of legislation as it is presented to us.

I would particularly like to develop this notion of single-member Senate electorates as foreshadowed by Mr Keating. If we are to proceed with this proposal, a senator—or a member, as they would then be known—would represent part of the state rather than the whole state. In rural areas in particular this would mean that the members or senators would then become inexorably tied to the regional interests of their electorate and would be unable to take a wider interest in areas such as foreign affairs, international trade and other global matters.

Although I have a country background, because of my position as a senator for the state of Victoria it is possible for me to have my electorate office in the north-western industrial suburb of Broadmeadows. Through that I can take a much wider interest in areas of Victoria that I would not be able to take a great interest in if I were tied to a particular electorate or part of that state. For that reason alone I oppose Mr Keating's proposed changes.

As Senator Kemp outlined, Mr Keating's reasons for opposition to the Senate and his desire to change the Senate are well known. I will develop that point later on, if I have time. I would also like to point out that, much as I and the government may not agree with the points of view put forward by the minority parties, they nevertheless represent particular points of view held by a certain proportion of the Australian population.

The Prime Minister, in his remarks of 3 March in the House of Representatives, referred to the essential, robust element of our democracy as being the representative nature of the Australian ballot. Under the present system, the minor parties hold a number of seats allocated to them under the proportional representation system. So we have with us the Greens (WA) and the Australian Democrats because that is the way the Australian people have chosen to vote. Those two parties bring to the Senate a reflection of the way many people in Australia think. As I have said, although I may not agree with the points of view of the minority parties, I nevertheless uphold their right to be represented in the Senate because they have achieved a certain proportion of the Australian vote.

The importance of the Senate was underlined by the changes made to the budget last year. As Senator Kemp indicated, although the budget was not thrown out and not dismantled, through the presence in the Senate of minority parties and the coalition we were able to achieve modifications to that budget which made it impact less harshly on some members of the community. Mr Keating simply wants to push legislation through the Senate, regardless of the feelings of minority groups about issues such as the republic and changing the flag. He cannot bear to see anyone stand in his way.

For this reason, on 3 March the Prime Minister also referred to the Senate as `a spoiling chamber'. That is indeed an extremely derogatory remark about an institution that has certainly stood the test of time. Mr Keating has called senators `paragons of democratic virtue', when what senators are doing is representing their states' and their constituents' interests. In that never to be forgotten phrase, the Prime Minister also called senators `unrepresentative swill'. On the same day, he referred to this house as holding any government to ransom over budget measures.

As I have said, this house acts as a house of review. It enables legislation to be scrutinised very closely. In any democratic country there must be a mechanism for review. All Australian states except Queensland have retained their upper house. Even in Victoria during the excesses of the Kirner-Carr government in the 10 years between 1982 and 1992, the fact that the upper house—the Legislative Council—was not government dominated meant that those excesses were at least restrained and that there was some brake on the economic mismanagement which the Labor government brought to Victoria during that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much restraint now against Mr Kennett's mismanagement.
—But the fact that the upper house still exists must indeed be a good reason for what we are advocating today. For all those reasons, I wish to support the motion.
—The opposition would ask that the time limit for all of our speakers be set at seven minutes.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—I think you can be accommodated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not talk for very much longer than that, but I cannot guarantee that I will keep it quite that short. The point I should make at the outset is that most of the contributions to the debate on these motions so far seem to be premised on the assumption that the government has made a decision and is determined to go down the path of legislating to seek to change the voting system for this place. I make it very clear at the outset that the government has made no such decision. We have no current plans to do anything of the kind. But I should also say that we are certainly considering whether the place might not be made to work better by a change in electoral arrangements which would ensure that the government of the day, properly elected, is able to govern. What kind of electoral arrangements might guarantee that outcome is a matter for very considerable debate and quite a deal of uncertainty. But it is a real issue that needs to be considered, and it needs to be considered because there are problems at the moment in the way the Senate is operating and, indeed, our whole system of government is operating as a result of the role of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Let me spell out what those problems are. The first is the way the numbers are falling out these days in this chamber. The second relates to the powers of the Senate itself, which are extreme by any comparative standard. The third is the way the numbers are actually being exercised in this place with an increasing degree of irresponsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —And negativity.

—And negativity and general bloody-mindedness. Let me say something about democracy Senate style. If the Senate were a states house, as it was intended by the founding fathers to be, there would be something to be said for equal numbers of senators coming from each state with that being translated into the way in which the place is conducted. Once the Senate loses any rationale as a states house—which it really did in its very first session at the beginning of this century—immediately there is a much less obvious rationale for equality of numbers from each state. That is a constitutional matter; it is not something that could be changed by legislation. It is certainly not something that I am expressing any view about. I just make the point that, once we accept the reality that this is a party house and always has been a party house, there is infinitely less justification for the threshold requirements of the constitution applying in the way that they do and introducing the electoral biases they do than would otherwise be the case if this were genuinely a states house.

PARA.TAB: The second point to make about the way in which the Senate numbers are operating at the moment is that the proportional representation system viewed constituency by constituency or, in this case, state by state tends to create overall a greater approximation between the number of votes a party or group gets on the one hand and the number of seats into which that is translated on the other. That just follows arithmetically from the reality of a proportional representation system. To that extent it is sometimes argued that the PR system is more democratic in a way than a system of single member constituencies. The way in which the PR system operates in Australia and the way in which things work out when we look at the voting returns as a whole all over the country demonstrate some very great idiosyncrasies indeed and a very conspicuous failure to match the notion that numbers of votes are translated into numbers of seats.

Taking into account the 4.6 million votes the Labor Party received at the last Senate election, with 43 1/2 per cent of the vote, also taking into account the effect of the earlier election, and similarly taking into account the 4.5 million votes that the coalition parties received, each of us has got roughly the kind of percentage of seats that follows from that sort of percentage of the vote. I do not contest that analysis. It is complicated by the fact that the present Senate is the product of two elections, not one, so that we in the government are sitting in here with reduced numbers as compared with the numbers on the other side, with a situation where we have only 30 people in the Senate as compared with the opposition's 36.

The real point that I want to make is that at the last election—if we leave aside the impact of the earlier vote—we got a higher percentage of the votes, 43 1/2 per cent, than did the opposition with around 43 per cent. Yet, we are sitting in here, as a result of the staggered system of election, with considerably fewer seats than the opposition. On the last occasion the electorate had to reflect its views of who should be governing the country, that was not translated into the number of seats that presently exist here. That is just a point made in passing, with no great portentous significance attached to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the next election could work the other way.

—It can work the other way—election by election it has in the past. What is harder to accept, and is an aberration of democratic principles—and what I would like the opposition to think long and hard about because it will be, perhaps at some stage in the next 25 years or so, the beneficiary of this particular system—is the way in which it operates so far as minority parties are concerned.

PARA.TAB: Let us contemplate the situation that prevails here in the Senate. The balance of power for all practical purposes is being exercised by three people whom the opposition needs to join with to constitute a majority—the two Greens and Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine comes in here with 32,000 votes—one-third of one per cent of the total number of people voting in the last Senate election. He is occupying a very pivotal seat. The Greens have the grand total between them, in terms of direct primary votes for the Western Australian Greens at the last election, of 53,000, although I know that Senator Chamarette inherited Senator Vallentine's seat and Senator Vallentine, let it be acknowledged, had 76,000 primary votes when she was elected.

As compared with the nearly five million primary votes that the Labor Party had and the 4 1/2 million or so that the coalition had at the last election, the Greens are sitting there with the grand sum of 53,000 primary votes—carry over the 76,000 from the previous election to be generous—barely one per cent of the vote in the whole Australian electorate. Senator Harradine is sitting there with 0.3 of one per cent of the vote; and here they are exercising the power to, in effect, run the country.

It is not as if there is any guaranteed majority in terms of overall votes built into this. People say, `The Greens and Senator Harradine can only exercise the authority they have by voting with the opposition'. That is true in terms of creating a majority inside this place but, in terms of representing a majority of votes in the population at large through the transmission belt of this representation, it works very differently indeed. The opposition with its 43 per cent of the vote nationally at the last election needs only to link up with these 160,000 votes or so—in effect, this scarcely more than one per cent—to determine the fate of governments, the fate of legislation and the effectiveness of public administration when, between them, they represent very much less than 50 per cent of the primary votes in this country.

There is something a little unhealthy about that degree of power being concentrated in people with that little claim to represent any kind of democratic mandate in the sense of a majoritarian democratic mandate. It is all very well for minorities to have their voice. We appreciate their voice and it is all very nice having them chirp up from time to time, but it is not very nice having around 50,000 votes determining the ability of a government with five million votes to govern. Another point I want to make goes to the powers of the Senate. We are talking not about any old upper house but the most powerful upper house constitutionally in the Westminster world. There are no ifs, buts or maybes about that. The opposition does have the power to knock off budgets and money bills. It does have the power not just to delay legislation but to overturn legislation. It does have the power in this place to do more than any other upper house in the Westminster world—anywhere in the world.

Moreover, the opposition has a demonstrated willingness to exercise that power. Not only in 1975 was the power to block supply exercised, but right now a majority of votes in this chamber is made up from people who have not denied themselves the capacity or the right to use the power to knock off governments. I do not think I am doing either the Greens or Senator Harradine an injustice when I say that I am not aware of them having committed themselves to never voting against blocking supply. I know the Democrats have, and I applaud them for that. But that is certainly not a position that has been adopted by the coalition or, to my knowledge, by the Greens or Senator Harradine.

So at any time at any budget we could confront the situation once again that we confronted in 1975—that power not of review but of destruction. What is involved when we are talking about the operation of this particular chamber at the moment is the capacity to destroy; the demonstrated willingness to do that in the historical past, in 1975; and a demonstrated willingness to do it again at any time the mood so strikes those opposite. That is a pretty unhealthy state of affairs, I believe, and one that does not fit any rational conception of the way the Westminster system should work—which is that the government should be allowed to get on with the business of governing and should be rewarded or punished at the end of its term of office, depending on how well it has done.

It is not a matter of saying that the upper house should not have a role at all. I strongly believe that the upper house has a legitimate role. I am on record in innumerable places as talking about the proper exercise of the right to review. I have talked in many places about the legitimate role of the committee system when it does work: to scrutinise legitimately governments; to operate to keep them accountable in terms of finance and administration; and, when it operates, to generate policy ideas, particularly in new areas of application. There are all sorts of useful things a properly constructed, thoughtful and democratically minded upper house can do and that the Senate has done, with varying degrees of success, now over quite some time.

But let us have a look at the way in which these powers are being exercised and these numbers are being exercised at the moment. We have, I think, all the elements of a deteriorating situation so far as the quality of democracy in this country is concerned. Look at it first from the point of view of the budget. Okay, we got through one way or another the budgetary process last year, but what a nerve-racking process that was. Of course, all of the things I am talking about are a product of the opposition acting in a thoroughly negative, obstructive, bloody-minded and unprincipled way as a result of its deep, very considerable distress—perfectly understandable distress, might I say—at losing the last election and a determination to destroy the capacity of the government to govern in every conceivable way it can at every step along the way.

In terms of the operation of the budget last year, we managed, as I said, to stagger through the process and we may have put in processes now which will avoid a repetition of some of the worst excesses of that exercise last year. We can only sit and keep our fingers crossed and hope and pray that that will occur. But we have a situation emerging where, unless people do take a cold shower and a deep breath and think about the way in which Westminster systems work and operate, our budgetary process could very rapidly disintegrate, descend down that spiral staircase and get us into the budgetary process that is all too unhappily familiar in the United States.

In the United States, every annual budget is the product of an extended negotiation, a mercilessly protracted negotiation, between the executive arm of government and the Congress, with results that are all too readily apparent in terms of total fiscal irresponsibility as the executive, year after year, has to do deals left, right and centre in order to attract the necessary congressional majority. It has produced a desperately irresponsible budgetary process in the United States, which has worked to the economic disadvantage of not only the United States but indeed the whole world economy as a result of the blow-outs that have occurred and the inability to exercise any kind of discipline. That is the problem we face and there are all sorts of signs of that happening.

Moreover, we have the problem that every time there is some grumble or whinge from a Green, as happened a few days ago when one of the Greens did not think the fiscal framework document was really going to be good enough, tremors are sent quivering through the financial market. It has a direct and immediate impact on the bond market and a direct and immediate impact on the exchange rate, for God's sake, just because, with the utmost respect to Senator Margetts—I am not wanting to get personal about this—someone whose latest date with the last electorate produced precisely 53,000 votes for her party, for her in particular, is able, by uttering a little bit of a whinge or a grumble of a fairly innocuous kind, to send tremors and shivers through the financial market because of the potential impact this was seen as having on the budgetary process and a responsible set of outcomes. It is, frankly, just loopy to be caught up in this state of affairs and it is food for thought, I would suggest, for those opposite as to how we are going to go.

Similarly, there is a place, of course, for a properly developed and constructed committee system. I have written lots about committee systems in the past. In fact, I once called them, I think, the Portnoys of the parliamentary system doing work that was all too often unproductive, not very satisfying but extremely tiring. Be that as it may—I will not pursue that particular metaphor any further on this occasion—I do acknowledge that the work in review and policy development that committees do can sometimes be very useful indeed.

That is not the way in which we have seen the committee system operating in recent times: the proliferation of select committees; the number crunching that has gone on to compose those committees, completely ignoring the principle of legitimate government chairmanship and majorities on them; and the attempt that was taken to extreme limits with the proposal for the sports program committee on which the government would have had just two out of seven members.

Today we had the situation even with the pecuniary interests register committee, essentially a housekeeping committee, where the numbers had to be crunched in such a way that the government was thrown out of its legitimate role, and the procedure on other committees, of having the majority and having the chairmanship. But those opposite want to do it differently. If they proceed down this particular path, they are going to turn into crude partisan vehicles, institutional entities, committees which are capable of playing a much more constructive role in the system.

We have seen the way in which the numbers in this place have been used and misused so far as legislation and the parliamentary timetable are concerned. I do not mind a substantial and a substantive debate on key legislation such as the IR bill or the Mabo bill last year. But did we need 29 hours of debate on the IR bill? Did we need 52 hours of debate, for God's sake, on Mabo? Of course we did not. The substantive issues that were involved in that legislation could have been dealt with in a fraction of the percentage of the time. But the filibusters continue and the numbers are used in such a way that it is legislation by exhaustion.

Again we have problems with the actual effective administration of the country by the government: the escalating demands for the production of documents and the demands that are being made upon public servants to engage in massive tasks of bureaucratic file searching and data preparation, all to satisfy passing whims and fancies which, very often, are not followed up with any kind of thoughtful use of the material thus obtained at vast cost.

We had the exercise with the vote on the Kelly disallowance regulation the other day where, for the first time in living memory, a legitimate government financial arrangement was made in order to move sideways someone who had not been a success in one job but clearly had a massive contribution to make to the public life of this country in a continuing position. The traditional flexibility that governments have had to act fairly and negotiate these sorts of arrangements with individuals was cut across by a Senate quite frankly getting too big for its boots in this sort of situation.

I am not going to talk for very much longer except to say that in all these ways the Senate, I believe, has been becoming increasingly unmanageable from the perspective not of a rogue government but of any government wanting to get on with the serious business of governing this country. I believe it is very important that all those in this chamber think very seriously about the responsibilities that we have, not just the transient bit of point scoring but about what we need to have a stable and sensible system of government.

Other Westminster systems have operated on the principle of allowing a government to get on with the business of government. In the United Kingdom, of course, the government is allowed to do that for five years in an untrammelled way without any effective limitation by the House of Lords or by anyone else. In Canada it is the same. New Zealand does not even have an upper house at all, of course. In other Westminster systems governments get on with the business of governing. If they muck it up they bear the responsibility and the electorate votes accordingly.

I am not suggesting for a moment there is no place for accountability mechanisms. I am not suggesting there is no place for review mechanisms. I am not suggesting in any way that governments should be able in this day and age to go about their business immune from scrutiny and immune from accountability. Of course not. The Senate has all sorts of roles to play in that respect, as do the judicial review mechanism and lots of other systems we have introduced in administrative law over the years.

Getting on with the business of governing is what the population wants governments to do. Unless and until the Senate focuses a lot more carefully on the responsible exercise of the extreme power it has in this respect, obviously governments, and oppositions for that matter, will go on thinking about the possibility of ways of ensuring that that power is exercised more responsibly in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating two motions moved by Senator Spindler which relate to the role and function of the Senate and the amendment moved by Senator Kemp. Never in the history of the Australian parliament has the Senate been under as much attack as it is at the moment by this discredited government of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Today we have the opportunity to expand on Senator Spindler's motions.

PARA.TAB: Both Great Britain and the USA would tell us that they have the greatest and purest forms of democracy in the world, embracing the ultimate system of checks and balances to maintain government accountability. Senator Gareth Evans just alluded to those two systems, although he did not do it all that well. In my opinion, the Australian Senate, modelled on both those systems—the House of Lords and the American Senate—is the keystone of what really is the most democratic system of government in the world. This being the case, I put forward a number of key questions. Is Mr Keating truly concerned with the level of democracy and accountability in the Australian parliament or are his actions based on his own personal objectives?
Opposition senators—Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators are dead right. I believe his attempt to align the Senate voting system with that of the House of Representatives has more to do with a desire for a clone of the House of Representatives than the pursuit of democracy. Does Mr Keating seriously believe that the change would make this parliament more representative, as Senator Evans has tried to argue, or do his motives originate from a desire to exploit his current position as Prime Minister to achieve absolute executive dominance? As Senator Kemp said, the Prime Minister wants to be the emperor, and that is what this is all about. Does the Prime Minister wish to appropriate the power of the states, which the Senate directly represents, and give the federal government supreme power over taxation—
—Oh, come on! It does not represent the states.

—Senator Richardson would love to have taxation completely in his hands. He wants to raise taxes all the time, like he is doing with the Medicare levy; that is his idea. If so, does Mr Keating's master plan include erasing those significant lines on the map called the state borders? Does he want to change the map of Australia as well?

PARA.TAB: If the Labor Party happened to gain control of the Senate through the first past the post voting system, would it award itself flexidays or rostered days off, as it has in the lower house? Would it do that up here as well? I bet it would; it would like some more rostered days off. Would the Labor Party allow inquiries into foreign ownership of the print media? If in control of the Senate, would it allow inquiries such as those into the sports rorts affair, which its executive government would have allowed to go through carte blanche because it likes to ram things through and do things in its own style?

It is obvious that the Labor Party still holds quite a grudge against the Senate because of what occurred on 11 November 1975. Like a spoilt child, the painful memories seem to be rekindled every time the Prime Minister fails to get his own way. He is like a spoilt, petulant child who, if he does not get his own way, kicks his heels up in the air and throws his bat on the ground and jumps on it. The Prime Minister forgets the service this house performs for him every time he tries to ram his half-baked bills into the law books. If these bills failed to be subjected to the essential scrutiny of this place—that is, to be debated and amended by the house of review—it would not be long before legal weaknesses and deficiencies were found, which would quickly result in a rush on our already-congested judicial system. We will see that with Mabo. It will all come back and haunt us. We tried to warn the government about it.

Senator Evans said a little while ago that we should let the elected government of the House of Representatives get on with the job. I would like to give some facts and figures to show what would have happened if we had allowed that to happen. In 1993, of the 432 amendments moved in the Senate, 182—nearly half—of those amendments were moved by the government itself. For God's sake, the government had to amend its own bills! Of the 432 amendments that were moved in the Senate, 182 were moved by the government and 178 of those were agreed to. The fact that the government has to make such wide ranging amendments to its bills makes one wonder about the quality of those bills in the first place.

First past the post in zonal representation systems would be the beginning of the road which would lead to the abolition of the Senate entirely. After a while, people would be inclined to say that there is no difference between the House of Representatives and the Senate. What chance would less populous states and the more remote areas have of an effective voice in Canberra without a Senate? Why is the Prime Minister trying to undermine the power of the Senate, reducing it to no more than a rubber stamp? Does the Prime Minister want to be free to become the president of Australia, unfettered, without a Senate to keep him honest? The opposition will not let the Prime Minister get away with it, and neither will any other senators here who have any thoughts for Australia.

In conclusion, the media and the general public have not been slow to recognise that Mr Keating's proposed reforms are his first steps along the long road to his ultimate goal—to elevate himself to the position of president of the republic of Australia. There is no doubt about it. I see the suggestion to alter the voting system in the Senate as a personally motivated attack on this great Australian democratic institution. I urge everyone to join with us and vote for this motion and Senator Kemp's amendment, to make sure that these things do not ever happen in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I listen to some of the contributions from those opposite, I am reminded of a story about the chaplain of the United States Senate who was showing a parishioner from home around the halls of Capitol Hill. They finished in the Senate chamber. In the ornate, gilded hall, the parishioner asked the chaplain what he did every morning by way of saying prayers. He said, `I expect you stand up at the rostrum, think about your responsibilities, and pray for the senators'. The chaplain said, `No, I stand up every morning, go to the rostrum, look at the senators, and pray for the country'. The simple fact is that nothing is immutable in our political system, and nothing is immutable in the American political system.

PARA.TAB: The Labor government subjected the Senate to reform in 1948; there is no reason why a reform proposal cannot be entertained now. People are saying the Senate is the only body in the country that really ought not to be subject to review and reform. But is it not a simple proposition to entertain; could not the Australian Senate actually work better than it does now? Could it not be more effective? Could it not be more deliberative? Could it not be more able to represent opinion and aspirations? I think it could. There is no doubt that it has a role as a house of review and in examining legislation.

I took Senator Brownhill's point about the amendments, but there is nothing wrong, improper or even untoward about a government amending its own legislation; it is simply a case of being reasonable. From time to time—I know from Senator Watson, for example—there are amendments suggested quietly by the opposition that are taken on board and form the stuff of government amendments: there is nothing unreasonable with a proposition like that.

The main problem that the coalition has with proposals for reform is that it automatically looks back 100 years or more. We have come a long way since the time Andrew Inglis Clark wrote the first draft of the Australian Constitution. We had gone a long way to the point in 1948 when the Labor government of Mr Chifley reformed this chamber. We have come a long way since the voyage of the Lucinda, and we have come a long way since the founding fathers wrote the original document.

The simple fact is that it is very easy to be in opposition. Those opposite have 36 negative votes on just about everything: everything they choose by way of exercising a negative vote they can see realised. That means in reality, even with the best will in the world, the government has to put together a coalition of interests on every measure that comes into the chamber to guarantee its passage. By and large, with the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine, I think there is a degree of cooperation, and people understand that. But we see creeping into our processes the same problems of the United States Senate where the American Congress cannot balance or put together a budget, because the painful measures are removed and eliminated.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called democracy.

—Senator Herron, my old friend the surgeon general, interjects that it is called democracy. That is true, but there has got to be an element of responsibility and obligation in that, surely. The United States Congress has been chronically incapable of balancing its budget for at least a decade. It takes the painful elements out of the legislation all the time because it is concerned about the constituency, the electoral reaction. So the painful measures are taken out. Over the past few weeks we have seen a similar process creeping into the Australian Senate—$15 million removed here in a measure; $20 million added there. If we are not careful, we will go down precisely the same road as the Americans.

PARA.TAB: Many coalition senators would prefer in the Westminster system a House of Lords where its members simply sit there and pass judgment. The coalition will not exercise governmental power in the foreseeable future, so it is easy to fall back on being negative, on being obstructive. We saw that at the end of last year with Mabo. The performance opposite really was a sad chapter in this place. I acknowledge that three National Party of Australia senators, including from memory Senator McGauran, crossed the floor on one or two occasions endeavouring to represent part of their constituency. It is a great shame there was not more of that. It is a great shame that more people were not prepared to negotiate and to discuss the issues instead of simply exercise the block 36 negative votes. It is very difficult, even with goodwill involving the Greens, the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine, to put together a coalition of interests on everything.

Let us look at the Senate's performance over the last political generation or two. The years 1974 and 1975 do not bear repeating. They were acts of constitutional vandalism. Australian history judges the opposition for that; I do not even have to make the argument. It has been a spoiling chamber. The 1993 budget process ought never to be repeated. The budget is now becoming an accounting function. Proposals are going in other directions and, in that respect, we will see what happens with the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on employment, industry and the regions at the end of April and the proposals that emerge from that. We will see whether the same agonising process of trading has to be gone through again in the Senate. It would be a great shame were that process to characterise what happens with serious policy issues. It ought not to occur. Heaven help us if further attempts are made in this chamber through the exercise of 36 negative coalition votes in perpetual opposition. The effort to gut the Prime Minister's statement may well be the objective again.

On this side of the chamber we have shown greater respect for the Australian constitution than any other political party. We have shown greater respect for our electoral processes than the coalition. It is a simple matter of historic fact.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator O'Chee! You have a position as deputy whip on the opposition bench. You should be setting an example to some of your colleagues, particularly the new colleagues. I would ask you to restrain yourself if you could. If you cannot, please leave the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Gareth Evans made clear earlier, the government represents very substantial opinion, as does the coalition. We try to act in a positive way. Unfortunately, the coalition tries to act in a negative way. But the votes are there and the votes are reflected in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Evans made the point about a total of 53,000 votes having been polled by one of the Green senators, Senator Chamarette said, `More than the Prime Minister'. I think I am quoting her correctly. The Prime Minister's constituency is only 75,000 in total. Senator Chamarette's constituency is the best part of one million. That actually reinforces Senator Evans's argument. I was stunned by that.

As to the direction in which we go, there is no fear on this side of the chamber in looking at proposals. We are not frightened of ideas, debate or discussion. Immediately, the coalition rears up in negative reaction. I heard Senator Abetz's in his first speech, for which I compliment him, in the chamber speak about the trifecta. He is right about Tasmania: it is a great state. There is no doubt about that. However, I disagree with him about the Liberal Party in the Senate. Unfortunately, all too often the response of the Senate to political change has been as a house of reaction, as we saw with the time wasting, the filibustering, the frustration and the negativity on Mabo last year. Just like 1974 and 1975, Australian history will judge the coalition very poorly for that.

The debate will go on for a long time. There are proposals for reform. Whilst those proposals are not set in concrete, they are worth considering. It is a long time since Clark, Barton, Griffith and Deakin sat down to write our original constitution and the Lucinda set sail. It is about time we debated ideas about the future of the Australian Senate and proceeded on the basis that we should do better. This chamber has some first-class features. I think some of the committees are first-class, but there is a long tale about the way in which the chamber operates.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the print media one?
—I am glad Senator Herron said that. I do not include the print media committee. I ask him please not to bait me. I will resist the temptation to respond. There are weaknesses, there are flaws—

PARA.TAB: Senator McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran interjects and wants to talk about 1975 again. Frankly, the labour movement has won that debate many times over. If he does not think it has, then he can just try it again. I will conclude my remarks by saying that the Labor government has no fear of ideas, of debate, of impassioned debate. The coalition ought not to rear up in simple negative responses. It is too easy. I see coalition senators sitting at Aussies every morning sipping coffee. It is too easy in opposition.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I do not know whether Senator Loosley was referring to me, but I often happen to be joined by Senator Loosley.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Kemp, you are quite aware that that is not a point of order. You are abusing the chamber by raising such frivolous points of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Potestas in populo, authoritas in Senatu: power in the lower House, authority in the Senate. When Cicero coined this expression over 2,000 years ago, he was referring to an anomaly that is present in bicameral democracies—the anomaly of the upper house holding greater authority than the popularly elected lower house. Centuries later the debate still continues. Cicero's statement is as appropriate today as it was then. It is interesting that Cicero was a senator and he was proscribed—that is, he was assassinated—on the order of Emperor Octavian. Today, Emperor Keating is advocating proscribing the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Bicameralism is the division of a legislature into two parallel but separate political bodies which must act in agreement for legislation to be enacted into law. In supporting a bicameral system of national legislature, the overriding argument in favour of such a system is the role of the upper house in providing a check and balance on the operations of the lower house and the political executive. No lesser person than Winston Churchill said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this idea that a group of super-planners making the masses of the people do what they think is good for them, without any check or correction is a violation of democracy.

The Australian upper house, the Senate, has the power to review, amend and ultimately reject any legislation presented to it from the House of Representatives, making it one of the most powerful upper houses in the world. This power to review and amend legislation is shared by many upper houses around the world and, although constitutional powers differ in each, the review process is a dominant function in nearly every one.

PARA.TAB: The importance of this power is seen as very important, particularly given the increasing influence of the executive over the lower house. I refer Senator Loosley to the recent proposals brought in by procedural changes in the House of Representatives whereby the Prime Minister absents himself whenever he wishes. That is a clear demonstration of the power of the executive over the lower house.

The executive in many cases has a monopoly on drafting legislation and policies, and has almost a guaranteed passage in the lower house. The second chamber is not only a safeguard against the hasty actions of the lower house; its accessibility to minority party and independent or non-aligned members allows for dissenting voices in the assembly. This capacity for dissent encourages genuine debate on legislation and, through committee review, permits time for the legislation to be digested by the public.

The composition of members in the upper houses, by virtue of the electoral process in place, means that it is possible for the ruling government of the day to have a minority in the upper house as we have at present. Although this has been attacked—Senator Loosley attacked it this afternoon—as undermining the stability of government, it emphasises the point that members of the upper house may not feel pressured or duty-bound to follow party lines but vote according to the merit of the legislation.

I am delighted to be a member of the Liberal Party. I personally experienced this power shortly after entering this chamber. I was able to exercise the power that I have as a member of the Liberal Party. Although party politics is certainly evident in the upper house, the potential for party manipulation is greatly lessened.

The revisory power of the upper house is a prime argument supporting bicameralism. With the political executive becoming increasingly dominant in legislative decision making, judicial appointments and vice-regal selections, as it is in the case of many Commonwealth nations, the upper house is perhaps the only forum for true debate and scrutiny over legislation.

Some argue that the Australian Senate, the states house, was established as the price of federation. However, in an era of new federalism, where the states are gaining greater autonomy, the need for a forum for state issues may be seen as even more important, particularly in light of the declining control individual states have in premiers conferences and the Loan Council. Thus, in a federal system, the upper house's role may be seen as far more effective than in unitary systems. Under conditions where members of the upper house are democratically elected, the presence of such a chamber is just as important to the democratic process of government as the lower house. In the extreme, one commentator even suggests that, if unicameralism is to be considered in Australia, the lower house should be the one abolished.

The proponents of unicameralism point to Scandinavia and Pacific nations as models of cameral reform. Unicameral legislatures are operating in Denmark, Sweden, Papua New Guinea and New Zealand. In the Scandinavian case, both countries embraced constitutional reforms in order to remove control from the monarchy and place it with the democratically elected legislature.

The inherently conservative and unrepresentative upper houses were abolished by drafting new constitutions. In the New Zealand example, the Legislative Council—that is, the upper house—was abolished in 1950 not out of contempt for the house but because of its failure as a revisory chamber. It was abolished in order to establish a more functional second chamber. These examples of functioning unicameral legislatures do not justify adopting unicameralism in federal systems as their relatively small size does not require strong regionally representative houses such as the Australian and American senates.

A review of the bicameral process is far more desirable than a rejection of the upper house. Reform and review can establish controls on both houses and still allow them to maintain their independence. The upper house is not just a relic of Westminster but an honourable institution. In a nation such as Australia, with its narrowly defined constitution, the Senate remains perhaps the last bastion in protecting state and civil rights in this country.

Although there are definite problems within the bicameral system of legislature, the long-term need for bicameralism far exceeds the often temporary obstacles that it may create. The fact remains, however, that in most federal bicameral legislatures the powers invested in the upper house are there by design. They are deliberate and calculated measures to ensure that the legislative process has checks and balances on the often dangerous and easily exploited system that is democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very exciting time for democracy in Australia's parliamentary history. The fact that in the Senate we have five groupings that cannot be controlled by any one group means that we can have issue-based debate rather than a numbers game. It does not mean that we achieve that, but it means that at least it is possible for people to focus on what is of major concern in the community and not be polarised on a party political basis.

PARA.TAB: Senator Gareth Evans said that he believed the Senate is becoming too big for its boots. While there is no room for complacency and arrogance, there is a need for the Senate to look at the way it conducts its business to see how it reflects the community. However, my usual motto, `Look at the criticism and see how it applies to the criticiser', indicates that perhaps some people are getting too big for their boots. It may well be that government members have become a little too used to having control of the numbers, even though they have not actually had a majority in this chamber for more than a decade.

It is very disappointing that the parliamentary accountability provided by the bicameral system is not understood or, if it is understood, is not valued by either the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). It indicates, as I mentioned before, a lack of respect for parliamentary democracy and accountability. A three-year term is not a mechanism for keeping a government honest or accountable, particularly when the modern Western equivalent of bribery for votes is the traditional pork-barrelling exercise that happens every three years regardless of which party is trying to determine the outcome.

It is very disappointing that there is not appreciation of the value of Senate, but it is also very reassuring that Senator Evans says the government has no plans to damage the democratic underpinning of our parliament. The rest of his speech, unfortunately, did not really reinforce that view. In his criticism, which was published in the Age on 21 February 1994, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . yesterday that the Government had been considering reforms—
I would scarcely call them reforms—
that would ensure the ruling party was guaranteed a governing majority in both houses of Parliament.
I believe Mr Ted Mack's response in the House of Representatives was very apt in this connection. He said:

Senator Evans's threats to change the proportional voting system of the Senate in order to eliminate minority parties have frightening echoes from history. In 1933 the Nazis were frustrated at not having control of the German parliament. They talked other right-wing parties into joining with them to form a majority to expel the communists. The reduction of seats then gave the Nazis a clear majority and, as they say, the rest is history.

PARA.TAB: At the time Germany had proportional voting, much the same as the Australian Senate, in which the public's wishes are reflected in the number of seats. In contrast, the single-member electorates used by this House—

SPEECH.PARA: the House of Representatives—
have always resulted in massive distortions of the public's will.
As Ted Mack said, if Germany had had our single-member electorate system, the Nazis would have won virtually all the seats in 1933.

TALK.START.PARA: —A classic Ted Mack response.

—It is classic Ted Mack; and it is quite an important observation. My response to Senator Evans's comments was in a letter to the West Australian in which I said I regarded the threat by the government to change the Senate voting method as a compliment. It means the Senate is doing its job. For the first time since Federation the Senate is properly scrutinising legislation and overseeing the operations of the executive. As a result, the government wants to change the rules and make the Senate less representative. The Prime Minister called members of the Senate `unrepresentative swill'. However, the membership of the Senate is determined by the votes of over 85 per cent of the electorate. Control of the House of Representatives can be obtained, as at the last election, by a vote of 40 per cent of the electorate.

PARA.TAB: The proposals of Senator Evans and the Prime Minister would result in the Senate becoming as unrepresentative as the House of Representatives. Any change in the manner proposed by them would also give rise to either a tame Senate or a rubber stamp, as people have mentioned earlier, or a perpetually hung parliament because of different parties controlling the two Houses. Only retention of the current system or an improvement for even greater representation can ensure that the people of Australia receive the representation they need and deserve. Perhaps we ought to, as I believe one of my colleagues said earlier, be recommending the proportional representation system to the House of Representatives.

I refer to Senator Kemp's amendment. Senator Kemp suggested that there should be an additional statement based on equal representation for each state within the federation. The Greens do not support that amendment because we believe that it is already in the constitution and it does not require change. However, we feel it is contradictory to the motion as presented. We do not feel that it actually aids the argument to insist that the Senate is a states house or that that is its primary raison d'etre. It is actually the Senate as a house of review and consideration that is important. If it were a states house alone—and I think that would serve the Prime Minister's arguments very well—it would have been initially called a states assembly and not a Senate.

Nevertheless, I have considerable sympathy with those wanting to refrain from moving over to the Prime Minister's rather radical proposal. He thinks it is unfair that the states have equal representation in spite of unequal populations. What would he want, I wonder? That we have 12 times the number of senators from New South Wales than we have from Tasmania? I am sure he might like that, but I am sure we would not. No, thank you; we have quite enough representation from the New South Wales Right—and perhaps that does not mean that we should be encouraging this kind of thinking by the Prime Minister. I will not talk about the quantity of votes because I actually think this is more than a numbers game; it is an opportunity to reflect community views in our country and do justice to the issues that are raised.

The Senate is more representative, as I said before, than the House of Representatives. It reflects community views, and those who support the Greens, the Democrats and currently minority views are very grateful for that. The Senate is valuable to the major parties also because it is a way of signalling the way in which the community is thinking about the important issues like the environment, social justice, peace and disarmament, and participatory democracy. It is ignored by the major parties at their peril.

The Senate is extremely valuable to the House of Representatives and to the government as a mechanism for addressing its accountability to the people of Australia, not to the parliament. That is our role as a Senate: to keep the government and the executive from becoming arrogant or refraining from respecting the views of the people, and to keep them accountable within the three-year electoral periods that they submit themselves to. The Senate is important in that respect. It is also important for us to reflect on the fact that we have quite a long way to go in respecting the views of the Australian people. Any mechanism that diminishes our accountability and our representation of the views in the community is a very damaging one and we should actually be going in the opposite direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak in this debate because it is a very different sort of debate from those we normally have in this place. We are often so concerned with the nitty-gritty of legislation that we rarely have an opportunity to stand back and look at the whole system of government that we have in this country. Preparing for this debate, and standing back and looking at the whole system, really made me appreciate what we have in terms of parliamentary democracy, why what we have created is so precious, and why we should not let the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who has ulterior motives on this matter, to tinker with what is probably the best system of government in the world.

PARA.TAB: If we look back in history, we can really appreciate how new the system of government we have is. With that, we can really appreciate how fragile this system of government is. Australia, which was settled by Europeans 200 years ago and which has had a federal system for only 93 years, is the sixth oldest democracy in the world. That shows us how fragile the system is. We created, I believe, a unique amalgam of the civilisation from which we had sprung in terms of the American and the British systems of government. I believe we have a superior system to the British and American systems because we took the best of both worlds. This is best exemplified, I believe, in the creation of the Senate. We created one of the most powerful upper houses, if not the most powerful upper house, in the world. When creating that upper house we gave it the opportunity not only to review the legislation of the government but also to represent the very diverse and vast regions of this country.

When I came into this place I really came to appreciate the role, power and responsibility that the Senate had in keeping government in this country on track. The fact that there was a check on government was probably one of the Senate's strongest features. I was absolutely amazed not only at the amount of legislation that went through the parliament but also at how often the government got it wrong. I was also amazed at the number of amendments introduced. Senator Loosley talked about the Mabo debate. How many amendments were there to the Mabo bill? I think there were about 270 in the end. If we had a unicameral system, how many amendments would there have been to that bill? I suspect none.

This was brought home very strongly to me when I first got here with the Education Export Bill. It was the first bill I worked on in committee. The government brought in a piece of legislation hastily prepared and poorly drafted and, by the end of the process, we had successfully introduced 32 amendments to this bill and totally reversed its direction from overregulation to deregulation. Since that bill came in, the educational export sector has grown from $800 million to $1,200 million. This sort of framework we set up allowed our education and our exports to expand. It was because of the role of this house of review and the creation of more sensible legislation that this took place.

Now the Prime Minister wants to tinker with this. He wants to tinker with a lot of things: the flag, the constitution and constitutional democracy, and now he wants to tinker with the way in which the Senate is elected. We have to ask why. The basic answer is that this Senate stands, like those other things stand, as a bulwark against the untrammelled power of an elected lower house. That is our unique position in keeping that under control. The Prime Minister is not saying that he is going to abolish the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —He actually has; he has said that.
—Perhaps in a fit of pique at one stage he might have said that. I am sure he did not mean it. I think he meant that he wanted to reform the Senate so that he could control it.

PARA.TAB: One interesting reform he is suggesting is to change the system of election of the Senate, from the excellent system set up by a Labor leader, Dr Herbert Vere Evatt, who, on introducing and putting forward the ALP arguments for the current system of proportional representation, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For many years there has been a demand that the Parliament should provide a system of electing senators which would give more equitable results and enable the electorate to be more truly represented in the Senate. The Government has given careful consideration to the matter and had closely examined alternative methods. It has decided that, in relation to the election of Senators, where each State votes as one electorate, the fairest system and the one most likely to enhance the status of the Senate is that of proportional representation.

Dr Evatt did not get much right in his life but he certainly got that right. He created an excellent system. Why does Mr Keating want to change it? We can see the reason when we look at my state's results in the lower house and the upper house. In the lower house, the government controls 34 of the 50 seats—68 per cent.

PARA.TAB: What happens in the Senate? In the last election we on this side won three out of six seats—50 per cent. That represents the true feeling of the people of the country. The state boundaries of this country cannot be rorted and the Senate is elected on state boundaries. The Prime Minister cannot change that. The government can fiddle around with the lower house boundaries and produce distorted results, in some cases ones that Governor Gerry of Massachusetts—who invented the original gerrymander—would have been proud of, but the Prime Minister cannot change the Senate boundaries.

In this country, Labor has won the last five elections, having only 30 seats to the coalition's 36. This, accumulated over the last two elections, shows the real balance of power, the real reflection of the people's will in this country. That is why it is absolutely vital that this system stay as a bulwark against this government. We have created a unique system of checks and balances in this country. The Senate is one of the most important of these checks against the unbridled power of government and we tamper with it at our peril.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate has been conducted on the basis of the Senate being in the same form now as it was when the rules were developed in the 1890s, in a situation where separate colonies had their own customs systems and their own defence responsibilities and were connected directly to the United Kingdom—or Britain as it was then called. The only way those colonies were prepared to come together, obviously, was by some representation which safeguarded, as they saw it, their own particular interests. For that reason, the first constitution contained the right for the states to have equal representation in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The first constitution also contained a provision, which is still there, for the Senate to contain about half the number of people in the House of Representatives. There was a suggestion that, regardless of the need for any particular number of senators, if the number of members in the House of Representatives were increased to look after the interests of their constituents, which is a very real task for them, then the number in this house would have to be increased. I believe this was a ridiculous proposition at the time and it still is. I cannot agree with anybody who tries to convince a reasonably fair and intelligent person—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like you?

—Certainly not like Senator Abetz—that the argument for equal representation is still valid just because at one time, in 1890, the states in this country had to be given equal representation to encourage them to join a federation. I do not believe anyone could be convinced on that argument.

PARA.TAB: The Senate was clearly introduced as a states house, which it has never been. I will not suggest that the Senate has never acted as a house of review. It has on occasions, and in the process of its operation it has overseen changes in suggested legislation. As has already been agreed here today and on other occasions by people on this side of the house, suggestions by people on the other side to improve legislation have often been picked up. Of course, our drafters and the people who are in charge of legislation are not perfect and we do make some errors in that regard—and we appreciate any assistance on the matter—but there are also issues upon which we will not move.

This country is unarguably over-governed.
