I believe the number of politicians we have in this country to govern such a small population and the amount of duplication in services to the community are shocking. It is time we looked to some changes. It has been very difficult to change the constitution over many years unless both parties have been in agreement. I believe that is certainly no reason to suggest that we should not look at it.

People are saying that proportional representation is the be all and end all, that it is a great way in which to elect people and that it gives true representation. If that is the case, it follows that the method of election in the House of Representatives should be changed—which I do not agree should occur. I believe the House of Representatives is the way to go. Even if one were to accept proportional representation as the way to elect people to this chamber, it does not necessarily mean that we need 12 senators to represent each state to have a proper review process operate and to get quality legislation. The single chamber process has operated quite successfully in certain areas. In Queensland it has operated for many years—

TALK.START.PARA: —China!

—Senator O'Chee's party, the National Party, which held sway in Queensland over all those years in a very undemocratic fashion, agreed with the single house process and operated it quite happily over those years, as the Labor Party has since its re-election.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that many intelligent people say to themselves, `Here we are in the federal sphere where we spend quite a lot of money on elections to elect members of the House of Representatives; we pay them reasonably well; it costs us a lot of money to support them in terms of the work they do. But then we merrily go on and elect a group of other people who then reject the legislation of the House of Representatives'. That does not make a lot of sense, even though I agree with the question of review—and some people might say the total right of the single house process—but to me the constitution can contain those sorts of prohibitions, and also the High Court can prevent any excesses that might occur in a federal government which was a single house operation.

At one time it was the policy of the Labor Party to abolish the Senate. I agree; I think that policy should be in vogue because I believe the House of Representatives has the capacity to rule this country in a proper and reasonable way.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can drop your resignation in after you've finished.

—I can assure honourable Senators that I will resign the day after Senator O'Chee resigns because my resignation will not present this country with a single chamber operation of government. But if every other person in this Senate is prepared to work and make decisions to abolish the Senate, I will certainly be in there with everyone else. I believe that the proposition that has been put forward by Senator Spindler is not based on proper consideration and thought. Even though this house may be a house of review on some occasions, I believe that it presents a problem in terms of efficient and effective government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first came into this chamber I looked across to the opposite side, and I saw a gentleman there with a mop of hair. I thought how much he looked like Albert Einstein. Since then there has been a haircut, and I have also learned that the contributions of Senator Burns really are not of an intellectual level. Indeed, his contribution in this debate—
—I take a point of order. I find that objectionable.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—I would ask that you withdraw that, Senator Abetz. It is a reflection on the honourable member.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz is not too stupid to realise it.
—Senator Burns took offence at it.
—He took offence that he looked like Albert Einstein, who was intellectual?
—No. He took offence that there was no intellectual content there.
—If he is offended by that, I, of course withdraw.
—An unqualified withdrawal.
—He has.
—No, we have not had that. There needs to be an unqualified withdrawal—not contingent on any particular `if' or whatever.

—On a point of order: unqualified withdrawals are withdrawals which are made, for example, if I say, `if a senator takes offence, I withdraw'. A qualified withdrawal is when I say `in deference to you', or `in deference to you alone, I withdraw'. What we heard from Senator Abetz was an unqualified withdrawal. It was certainly better than many of the withdrawals we have heard from Senator Bolkus. I do not believe that Senator Bolkus has a point of order.

—I find it offensive to say that in my withdrawals I have been disrespectful to the chair. I ask for that to be withdrawn as well after, however, Senator Abetz makes an unqualified withdrawal of what he said about Senator Burns.

—On the point of order: I need some guidance from you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Abetz claimed that Senator Burns was not intelligent. Now you are ruling that to be out of order, but you would have heard Senator Burns yell across to Senator Abetz that he was stupid. I think `stupid' is more offensive that `not intelligent'. I ask you to rule on that.
—Yes, but we will deal with the first objection. You may raise that, Senator McGauran, but—
—Sir, I thought I had withdrawn without equivocation. If I need to do so again, for the benefit of Senator Bolkus and others, I do so.
—I also withdraw what you were going to ask me to withdraw!
—Thank you, Senator Burns. I call Senator Abetz.

—Thank you, sir. It is a reflection on the Labor Party that in my second speech in this Parliament I have to rise to defend the role of the Senate. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Labor Party have embarked upon an ongoing campaign of denigration against this chamber, which is so very important to the people I represent—the people of Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister's attacks on the Senate with comments like, `unrepresentative swill' are a disgrace, and reflect especially poorly on someone who claims that he is the `all Australian person'. If anything can be said about the Senate, it is that it is uniquely Australian. It did not come from the House of Lords, it does not reflect the requirement to have a peerage or, as in other upper houses, some landed qualification. It is not purely a states' house as in Canada or Germany. The equality of state representation does not, of itself, make it unrepresentative. It needs to be remembered that but for the equality of the representation of the states there would never have been the federal compact which has made this great nation.

No-one can argue that the Liberals, the Labor Party, the Democrats or any other group have benefited as a party in a disproportionate way because of the equality of the states within the Senate. Indeed, what equality does ensure is that all parties have a real input from all the states so that issues that uniquely affect a state such as Tasmania are able to be put forward in the Liberal, Labor and Democrat party rooms.

What we have in Australia is a uniquely Australian institution designed by Australians, for Australians, taking into account the need, in a bicameral system, to have an amalgam of qualities in this house, being a house of review, a states house and an upper house. It is a bit like our flag—we have taken bits and pieces from other peoples and their heritages and made them uniquely Australian.

Senator Burns acknowledged in his contribution that he still wished to see the Senate abolished, and there should be no doubt whatsoever in the mind of any Australian that the Labor Party still believes that the Senate ought to be abolished. In 1980 Mr Hayden said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are committed to its eventual elimination.
Senator Evans is on record as having said:
The way to abolish the Senate or at least muzzle it is to white ant it from within.

Senator Evans is the person who now parades as Leader of the Government in the Senate—it is like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank. I will quote from Senator Evans's comments about the Senate. He said:
The Senate has by all accounts always been a rather silly and pompous institution.

It could well be argued that his contribution to this debate falls into that exact category. I believe the Senate has played a very important and major role within Australia. Before concluding, I indicate that a former Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, and former Senator Murphy, are both on record in 1970 as trying to defeat the then Liberal government by opposing money bills.

PARA.TAB: In supporting the Democrats' resolution, I conclude by saying how very disappointed I am that the Australian Democrats are not committed to the equal representation of the states in this house. I believe that the Tasmanian people will be very disappointed to learn about that. I think that Senator Robert Bell's chances of re-election will be so much more difficult as a result. I support the role of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Democrats' motion and Senator Kemp's amendment which balances the Democrats' motion. When this debate was first raised by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) I thought it was just a passing remark in frustration at some of Senator Kernot's remarks and the pressure that the Senate was putting on the government. I did not think that it would go anywhere in particular. But I am now concerned because some of the heavyweights in the Labor Party have weighed into this debate.
—Yes, Senator Burns.

—I would not describe Senator Burns as a heavyweight. I am talking about people such as Senator Gareth Evans, Mr Beazley and the Prime Minister. They have all stepped into the breach. I believe that what Senator Burns said today probably represents what the Labor Party in its heart of hearts really wants—the abolition of the Senate. Most Labor Party members would not be silly enough to retail that to the electorate. They know the electorate would not have a bar of it.

PARA.TAB: What we are seeing now is an undermining of the Senate. The government knows it cannot achieve the abolition of the Senate in the short term. It is now going to review it, restructure it and reform it. They are all euphemisms for the emasculation of the Senate. That is the way in which the government will operate. It has undermined the constitution, the flag, the states and now the Senate. It is all fitting into a pattern.

This Labor government cannot leave alone anything that works. It has a need to destroy things that Australians are proud of. We have lived in a federation for 90-odd years and there has never been a problem that our constitution could not solve. This house of review, this states house, has worked particularly well for 92 years. Yes, it is frustrating in government, but government senators should try being in opposition and see how frustrating that is. If the government wants to attain a majority in the Senate, it should go out and sell its policies to the people, as we have done. We now find ourselves with a majority of six over the government—36 versus 30.

There are a number of other reasons why the Senate must be maintained in its current form. We have heard people of such eminence as Senator Gareth Evans say that it is not a states house. I can assure Senator Evans that I have stood up in here on many occasions and supported industries in my state. Sometimes I have not been popular for doing so, but I have done it.

I can understand Senator Abetz walking out of here fearfully because if any state needs equal representation it is Tasmania and, to a lesser extent, Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia. All the representatives of those states are joining in this debate. The presence of 12 senators from Tasmania or Queensland in the caucus or the joint party rooms gives a balance.

The government's proposal is that 12 large Senate electorates be created in each state and that senators would be elected from those electorates rather than from the entire state. On many occasions I have debated issues such as tobacco, sugar, small business, the Torres Strait Islands, and Aboriginal communities. If we were elected from one constituency, we would have the same narrow view of the constituencies that is reflected in the lower house.

In the Senate we can look at the bigger picture and take an active role in the issues that cover all the states or all sections of the states. For that reason, I believe that the Senate must not and cannot be interfered with now. Senator Burns has made an impassioned

SPEECH.PARA: speech to remove the Senate. I am alarmed that anyone in the Labor Party would allow Senator Burns to get up and make such a speech. Perhaps someone should check what he is going to say in the future.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of reasons why, in the short time that I have left, I say to the Senate and to the people out there that we have had a constitution that has guarded this nation well, that has lifted this nation to having the 18th highest standard of living in the world. The Senate is part of that constitution. The states are part of that constitution. I do not see any need to alter our wonderful constitution because of the continual frustrations of the government. If the government wants to win the balance of power in the Senate I suggest to the government that it lifts its game and campaigns to increase its numbers in the Senate. Otherwise, do not touch something that is working, that is unbroken, that is effective and that has given Australia a great way of living.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to address the issue of the Senate as a states house. When I go round to schools in Victoria talking to students of politics about the role of the Senate, I ask them: `Can you tell me what you know about the role of Senate?'. They will say, `It is a house of review and it is a states house, but it is not a states house because you do not vote on state lines'. My answer to that is, `It is very sad that many of your textbooks are written by teachers who are not actually practitioners, who maybe have not spent time sitting in the galleries or who have not been members of parliament'. From the outside it would appear to many that the Senate is not a states house. Obviously, Senator Burns, who hardly every speaks in this chamber, does not think about the issue of the Senate as a states house.

PARA.TAB: But let me tell the Senate some of the things I say to the students. One of the major issues is that as a states house—and I do not know what goes on in the caucus room, but I know what goes on in our party room, although I will not disclose the things that go on—if an issue comes up about transport, I can bet my bottom dollar that the Tasmanians will be on their feet. If an issue comes up about gold tax, I know that the Western Australians and some of the Victorians will be on their feet. I know that if it is an issue about some other area that relates particularly to a state, those senators will support the House of Representatives members from those states and argue vehemently in the party room. I do not know what they do over there on that side of the chamber, but on this side I know that those senators represent their states in the party room. So in one of the major parties the states are represented in the party room. That is one of the benefits of the Senate; it gives the smaller states representation that they would not have in the major party rooms.

I also say to the students that one of the things that happens because we have a Senate is that the many thousands of people who vote in their electorates and who do not happen to win—Liberal supporters who vote and do not win or Labor supporters who vote and do not win—in their senators have direct representation in the federal parliament. If they are Liberal voters living in a Labor electorate they can go to a senator who they know shares similar views to theirs. If this were a single-house parliament they would not have that access.

One of the other things that can happen is, for example, between 1990 and 1993 we had no Labor seats in rural Victoria, except if we took Burke, an electorate on the edge of the city which had some city-based towns and some rural area—not very much. This meant that between 1990 and 1993 there was not one member of parliament representing the views of rural Victoria.

Let me tell honourable senators what happened during that period. There was an issue. The then Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, in his wisdom decided that one of the ways the government could rationalise things was to merge all small rural nursing homes in Victoria that were less than 250 kilometres apart. That was the sensitive, caring thing the government was going to do. So, if a nursing home in a little town in Victoria had fewer than 20 beds, the government was going to merge it with a nursing home less than 250 kilometres away. So a person 85 years of age living in a nursing home in a rural town could be shifted to some other nursing home in Bullamakanka or wherever in Victoria. That person's spouse, who might be 83, would then have to travel all that distance to visit.

When I heard about this decision I went into orbit. I could not believe it. I could not believe that this caring Labor government, as part of this wonderful economic rationalisation, was going to merge these small rural nursing homes. I talked to my colleagues from the other states about it. Guess what? They were not concerned. Why were they not concerned? The answer is that there are hardly any small rural nursing homes in the other states. In fact, almost none were going to be affected by this decision. It was going to affect Victoria in particular. I got that message from across the state.

When there is an issue, such as small rural nursing homes, people go to their representative in the House of Representatives. All they know is that it is an electorate issue. But, as senators, we get the overview of the whole state. We begin to see that it is not only happening in Bourke, Wannon or McEwen; it is happening in every electorate in the state. So, with that overview, we can raise the issues that affect our states in the party room. It is a nonsense to say that the Senate is not a states house. It may not be a states house in the traditional sense that our forefathers, who set down the constitution, believed it was going to be. We know that.

Senator Burns may stand up and say, `Yes, we vote along party lines'. He has not learnt his history because he said the Senate—I do not want to misquote him but I think he implied this—had never voted along state lines. That is not correct; it has in the past. But, as I said before, in the party room the smaller states are heard very loudly and are supported because they have five or six senators in each of the major parties who can put their views. They are in addition to the very small number of members of the House of Representatives from states like Western Australia and Tasmania.

Because of a quirk of fate which lasted from 1990 to 1993, not one member of the House of Representatives came from rural Victoria. Rural Victoria was not represented in the government of the day. The only way it could be represented in the Labor caucus room was by Labor senators. I think that that speaks for itself.

One of the other valuable roles that a senator can play is to look at issues on a state-wide basis. People can legitimately come to us. I can understand that a member of the House of Representatives may be very busy when somebody from an electorate far away rings them up and says, `I have a concern'. If small rural nursing homes are not their big beef, they will do what they can for the small rural nursing homes in their own electorates. But they are not going to be terribly concerned, because something that happens in another electorate is not going to win votes for them. If they are concerned about people, they might see them, but they will not have the same commitment that a senator has because these people are the senator's constituents. That is the issue. The major point that I want to make today is that it may appear from the outside that the Senate is not a states house but, when we look at its function, we find that it is in fact a states house.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Spindler's motion. We are debating the wider notion of Senate electoral reform. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and others have attacked the Senate as unrepresentative because states of vastly different sizes have the same number of senators. We have heard a lot about that this evening. Perhaps one way to remedy that is to have equal numbers of senators from electorates of equal size. That is an option for discussion that I think we should talk about. That remedy would require a constitutional referendum—not a joint sitting and a vote of both houses. Most of us know that the history of constitutional referenda is that a referendum would probably fail, but there is no harm in discussing options.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that, despite the different sizes of the states, the composition of the Senate very closely follows the national vote for each party. That is because proportional representation does tend to compensate for electorates of different sizes. This means that the Senate is much more representative of voter intention than the House of Representatives. In 1990, Labor won control of the House of Representatives with 39.4 per cent of the primary vote. That could not happen in the Senate. Only a few per cent of Senate primary votes do not go to a winning candidate. This compares with more than 50 per cent of House of Representatives votes which go to losing candidates.

Any move to strip Australians of an effective vote will further alienate the voting public from the parliament which is supposed to represent them. It is ironic that, just at a time when New Zealand is introducing mixed member proportional representation to remedy precisely the problem we are talking about, this government is toying with the idea of sending our electoral system back to the 19th century.

There has been a lot of propaganda about the way in which the Senate was only ever supposed to be a states house, yet it has failed to play that role. The Senate was established with two roles in mind: one was as a states house and the other as a house of review. That is why many of our constitution framers, including some of its most distinguished, favoured electing the Senate by proportional representation. That is also why the first ever Commonwealth electoral bill, tabled in 1902, provided for the Senate to be elected by proportional representation. The bill was defeated, but it showed beyond doubt that the Senate was widely seen from the outset as a house of review.

The Prime Minister believes that this Senate has failed to act as a house of review and that it has tried to usurp the role of executive government. The Democrats agree that the machinations of this chamber have been pretty hair-raising at times and occasionally we have put a toe over the line. For example, we disagreed with the double deadline motion and the way in which debates over the budget and native title were unnecessarily drawn out.

But, looking beyond the theatre and at the actual outcomes, what has the Senate done to upset the government so much? We made the budget fairer, with the overwhelming support of the Australian public, while leaving the government's deficit targets intact. We passed native title and industrial relations reforms with significant improvements. We have insisted on uncovering the circumstances surrounding the sale of large slabs of the Fairfax press to Conrad Black. We pressured the House of Representatives to take a proper look at Mrs Kelly's ministerial performance and we won agreement for a range of accountability reforms. It is the outcomes which ultimately matter. These outcomes have been responsible, constructive and democratic.

Have we obstructed the government's legislative program? Hardly. The government has often struggled to provide us with enough legislation to keep the chamber working. Have we set ourselves up as an alternative government? Hardly. We have acted within the constitution and, for the most part, within the bounds of convention. It is the government which has tried to usurp the role of the Senate—not the other way round. Remember the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill? It was a blatant and unconstitutional attempt to avoid parliamentary scrutiny.

One reason the Senate is able to function as a house of review is that we are elected by proportional representation. The Australian people have used proportional representation strategically. They have ensured that no single major party controls this chamber and that a more diverse range of views is heard than in the House of Representatives. The result is that legislation cannot be rammed through and, equally, oppositions cannot easily obstruct. That means that negotiation is required and negotiation is often a good thing because it forces us to focus on the merits of the issues.

Our decision making processes are more open and more accessible than those in the House of Representatives, and this imposes a greater discipline on us to act in the public interest. The result, I would argue, is decisions which are more creative, more independent and, in general, more rational. They are not all good, but they are light years ahead of those made in the other place.

Who would gain from the sorts of changes Mr Keating has threatened? It is hard to judge that, because we would have a Senate dominated by either government or opposition. The result could well be either meek obedience or total obstruction, but the biggest blow would be to democracy, which would lose the most. Australia would lose its most powerful check on executive government.

We all know that any electoral change is motivated in part by self-interest. Labor's introduction of proportional representation for the Senate in 1948 was no exception. Labor calculated that it would give it control of the Senate if it lost government in 1949, and it was right, if only for two years. But the bill passed with bipartisan support because there was also a higher principle at stake.

The preferential bloc voting system was a joke. It had been recognised since before Federation that proportional representation would strengthen the Senate's house of review function. This Prime Minister's threat to change the Senate voting system has no such redeeming features. It is motivated by nothing more than a contempt for the important role the Senate plays and for the views of the Australian public. The government cannot avoid facing voters at election time, but it would dearly love to avoid accounting to them between elections.

I think the difference between the view of the Democrats on the role of the Senate and the need for change and the view of the government is the weight of historical and contemporary argument in favour of our view. We can point all the way back to the constitution's framers. We can point to John Stuart Mill's argument that second houses of parliament should be elected by a system which allows minority views to be represented and allows the chamber to act as a check on executive government. We can point to the WA Inc. royal commission, which argued for a house of review elected by proportional representation, and we can point to the worldwide trend—including just across the Tasman—to more representative electoral systems.

I have yet to see one considered opinion in favour of single member electorates for the Senate, but I have seen numerous editorials and opinion pieces which range from the sceptical to the hostile. The most interesting comment was by Crispin Hull in the Canberra Times of 7 March. Mr Hull points out in his article that if the government legislated to establish 12 single-member electorates in each state then it could be argued that half of the voters of each state would be deprived of a vote at each half-Senate election. This may be constitutionally unsound. It certainly would be very unpopular as well.

An alternative would be to divide the state into six electorates. There would be two senators per electorate, one of whom would go to the polls at each half-Senate election. But a problem arises in the event of a double dissolution, where two senators would have to be chosen per electorate. This is what happens now in the ACT and the Northern Territory, and the result would probably be the same—a hung Senate with 38 senators on each side.

I think our focusing on this motion is timely, because maybe the government needs to be reminded that this Senate is not a factional brawl and that this parliament is not the sole possession of the Labor tribe; it is the property of the Australian people, and it deserves a lot more respect than it has been shown of late. The Senate's present system of proportional representation is a pillar of our democracy. It is what makes this chamber a house of review. It gives almost all Australians a primary vote which counts, and that is important.

The Senate is the only house which is prepared to stand up to an arrogant government and hold it to account. In discussing this motion, I guess what we are saying is if we undermine proportional representation, we undermine democracy. If that does not worry the government, then maybe the fact that it would almost certainly lose control of both houses just might. Perhaps the thought of a double dissolution focusing on the role of the Senate and the constructive role of minority parties within that Senate would be the ideal issue on which to go to an election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for the time that she has given me to speak. She did finish on a very interesting note, I must admit. She is now calling for a double dissolution—
—I did not.

—As I understood it. The opposition supports this motion but knows that the Australian Democrats are angling for a double dissolution. They will cause as much disruption in the Senate as they can to get their double dissolution. Senator Spindler, more than anyone, wants a double dissolution because he cannot go to the Victorian public at a half-Senate election.
—What nonsense.

—Nevertheless, I am pleased to follow my colleagues in this debate. Senator Boswell made the very good point that Labor seems to be obsessed with destroying what is uniquely Australian. I know Senator Boswell is puzzled as to why this would be, but it is because those opposite are just plain uncomfortable with being Australians; they are strangers in their own country. Senator Abetz, who has remained in the chamber—
—A great Australian.

—I take up Senator Kemp's interjection. Senator Abetz rightly stood up for his state, which has the most to lose in relation to representation in the Senate. But we have not seen one Tasmanian Labor Party senator stand up and defend that state.
—Or Democrat.

—Or Democrat. As Senator Abetz pointed out, we will find their chances of re-election at the next election greatly diminished. Senator Patterson also made a telling point for our side of the argument: from time to time this place really is a states house. The best example of that is Victoria with its unique aspect of the bush nursing homes, which require direct representation by the Victorian senators. It is quite obvious that Western Australian or Tasmanian senators from either side of the house are not going to have the same interest in that issue. That is a prime example of how a states house can operate.

PARA.TAB: In the light of our wishing to take this matter to a vote, I just make the point that we would have thought that the government would have known the attitude of the Australian public in this debate. There is enough modern day evidence for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to realise this. We have only to hark back to the 1984 and 1988 referenda. On both occasions, people were asked whether there should be change to the voting patterns of the Senate and the rotation of senators and the Labor Party got a resounding, thumping no. One single point more: I cannot let Senator Loosley's Irish day logic go by; I cannot let him quickly rewrite history and walk out of the chamber in relation to 1975. The people spoke in 1975, and what they said is still true today.
Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Spindler's), as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall now put the question on the second motion. The question is that the motion be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration entitled Asylum, border control and detention is a mixed bag of goods. The report does not recommend, as it should have, a scrapping of the detention system in favour of releasing asylum seekers into community care while their cases are being decided. There are, however, a number of other recommendations which are an advance. The committee's main recommendation was that unauthorised border arrivals who claim refugee status be held in detention while their cases are assessed but that, if they are held for more than six months as a result of lack of action or error by the department, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs should consider releasing them with a bridging visa. The introduction of the bridging visa is an advance on the previous system.

PARA.TAB: The report also recommends that the minister have regard to any special needs based on age, health or previous experience of torture or trauma, whether applicants are likely to abscond and whether there are adequate community support arrangements. Other positive recommendations are that priority should be given to the processing of claims by refugees, that an advisory committee should be established on the conditions and services in detention centres, that children in detention centres should be allowed to attend local schools and that medical personnel should be provided to detainees who can speak the language of the detainees.

However, perhaps the most negative and most deplorable aspect of the report is that it also recommends that moves be made to curtail legal challenges to decisions on refugee claims by amending legislation to limit the opportunity for making such challenges in the Federal Court. This would move us further in the totally unacceptable direction of creating a class of people who appear before Australian courts but who do not have equal rights with other people in Australia. This principle of equal rights is one we should not relinquish. It is a principle to which every civilised society should subscribe.

The Australian Democrats did make a submission to the inquiry. We said in that submission that the system as it stands contravenes our obligations under international human rights law. It is economically inequitable, causes undue hardship on detainees and compounds their emotional, psychological and physical ill health. As I have indicated, the recommendations in this report do not adequately address these particular shortcomings. The preamble to the universal declaration on human rights declares:

SPEECH.PARA: "no one shall be subjected to arbitrary arrest, detention or exile."

Yet, as I said, the recommendations in that report do not go as far as to put an end to the shameful provisions of detention that we have practised for quite a number of years. While there are some improvements, they certainly do not go far enough. Article 22 of the international convention on the rights of the child says that children are entitled to:

. . . receive appropriate protection and humanitarian assistance in the enjoyment of . . . rights set forth in the Convention and in other international human rights or humanitarian instruments to which the state is a party.

Very clearly, what we are continuing to do does not meet the standards set in that convention which Australia has both signed and ratified. I turn to the international convention relating to the status of refugees which provides:

States shall not impose penalties, on account of the illegal entry or presence, on refugees who, coming directly from a territory. . . where their life or freedom was threatened . . . are present in their territory without authorisation, provided they present themselves without delay to the authorities and show good cause for their illegal entry or presence.

States shall not apply to the movements of such refugees restrictions other than those which are necessary and such restrictions shall only be applied until their status is regularised or until they obtain admission to another country. The contracting states shall allow such refugees a reasonable period and all the necessary facilities to obtain admission to another country.

I express regret that the committee has not seen fit to address these standards to which we as a nation should aspire. I return to what I consider to be the most deplorable situation. Twice now we have passed legislation in this parliament which denies a particular class of people equal rights before Australian courts. We have passed legislation which limits grounds for appeal. It is difficult to believe but we in this parliament have excluded, as a ground for appeal, bias by the tribunal in the decision on refugee status. Despite the strenuous opposition of the Australian Democrats, this parliament does not think that if somebody shows bias that should be sufficient grounds for appeal. This chamber has also excluded natural justice as a ground for appeal, over the strenuous opposition of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: It is deplorable that the committee has not seen fit to be critical of those decisions and to recommend that they be reversed. On the contrary, the committee has suggested that further restrictions be imposed on the legal rights of asylum seekers. I think it is worth remembering that these things are contrary to the basic legal rights that every citizen should have. We are saying, `We are entitled to guard our borders. We are entitled to ensure that some 500 people who come here by boat do not enter and do not jeopardise our security and our immigration policy, which admits migrants, immigrants and refugees of the order of 80,000 or 90,000'. For the sake of imposing restrictions and guarding our borders against several hundred people, we are prepared to jettison a basic principle of human rights and legal safeguards. I think that is a great matter of regret and continues to be a blot on the record of this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter that I believe has to be pursued on the basis of the future interests of our country, having consideration to the matters of security and health. But it should be tempered with compassion. I do not wish to proceed any further in the debate at this time. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am conscious of the time, so I will try to keep my remarks within the time limit. I rise to speak to the 46th report of the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges. As honourable senators would be aware, I wrote to the then President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, on 27 September last year asking the Senate to consider whether false or misleading information had been supplied to Estimates Committee E or to the Senate regarding the proposed tax on the diesel fuel rebate scheme and whether the matter should be referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges. The then President, having considered the matter, referred it to the privileges committee and its report has been tabled in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The minister responsible for the Australian Customs Service, Senator Schacht, wrote a letter to the privileges committee outlining why he felt that false or misleading information had not been provided to the committee. In this letter he concluded by asking:

SPEECH.PARA: What possible benefit or motive could there have been for providing false or misleading information?

I agree that in the minister's case there was no possible benefit or motive. In fact, it would have been positively stupid for the minister to knowingly mislead an estimates committee, but there were also senior customs officers involved in this incident, and I suggest that in their case the question the minister asked was the wrong question.

PARA.TAB: The question that should have been asked is: when faced with two separate opportunities on the evening of 26 August to provide the correct information to Estimates Committee E about the legislation required to implement the tax, why would senior customs officers, including Mr Frank Kelly, the then comptroller-general, and Ms Virginia Stretton, the national manager of inland revenue, fail to provide that information? What logical explanation can there be for this failure?

To my mind, there can be only two explanations. First, these senior officers—despite their seniority and expertise, despite their attendance at briefings on budget related matters, despite discussions that must have taken place within Customs about the need for legislation, despite drafting instructions having been issued by Mr Stephen Holloway of Customs on 17 August, a full week before the hearing on 26 August, and despite a draft bill being in existence and present in Customs on 24 August, two days before the hearing—were so vague, so unsure and so unprofessional that they simply could not recall any details whatsoever that might have led them to have suggested to the minister at the very least that legislation might be required, let alone the fact that it was required and a draft bill was already in existence.

I simply cannot accept this explanation. It defies all logical explanation, and I reject it completely. The privileges committee also had great difficulty with this concept. The committee stated, quite generously, that it `had difficulty understanding the collective lapse in memory amongst a number of officers'. The committee also stated that it was sceptical of the reason given by Mr Kelly as to why other officers did not even bring the possibility of legislation to the minister's attention. The reason given was that these officers thought the minister knew something that they did not. This would have to be some sort of record. It would be one of the few times that public servants thought their minister knew something that they did not.

As for the collective lapse in memory, as I have already stated, it is simply not believable that this took place. I do not accept that not one of the senior officers, including Ms Stretton, who is the manager of the branch that would be responsible for collecting the tax, could recall any details that could be passed on to the minister. It leaves only this alternative explanation: the officers did not tell the minister all the information within their knowledge. The question I ask is: why?

I accept that on 26 August, when I first asked questions about the possibility of legislation, the officers concerned were perhaps a little uncertain. After all, Mr Stephen Holloway, the legal officer who issued the drafting instructions for the legislation, was not there. But what I cannot accept is that, during the 1 1/2-hour interval when customs officers left the hearing room to seek more information about the tax, it did not occur to them—any one of them—either that they knew drafting instructions had been issued and a draft bill was in existence or, at the very least, that there had been discussions about the new tax which the inland revenue branch would have to administer.

Mr Kelly has suggested that his officers either did not recall or were so unsure that they decided not to mention to the minister even the possibility of this new legislation. Apart from this explanation not being believable, it simply does not tie in with what the minister advised me after the 1 1/2-hour interval. The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, it has been determined that it is not necessary for legislation to have an administrative fee . . .

The minister did not say, `My officers aren't certain', or `They can't recall the details', or `My officers don't know but will check for you', or anything like that. Instead, the minister made the positive statement, `It has been determined that legislation is not required'.

PARA.TAB: It appears to me—maybe I am wrong—that the officer or officers who gave the advice to the minister gave him something in writing or told him verbally that it had been determined or decided, or words to that effect, that legislation was not necessary. I cannot imagine that the minister, having been advised by customs officers that they really were not sure of the situation, would of his own volition have stated quite clearly, `It has been determined'.

I believe that the impression was given to the minister on 26 August that these officers had gone away and found the answers to the questions I had raised. That would explain the answer given when Senator Hill asked:

SPEECH.PARA: So you have satisfied yourselves that it is simply a matter of your announcing that you are going to deduct what you deem to be an administrative fee which you define as one per cent and that there is no further regulatory or legislative process necessary to implement that.
The minister responded:
As I understand it, yes.

Only the officers concerned know why they would have implied to the minister that they had gone away and confirmed that legislation was not necessary. As I have said before in this chamber, it has been suggested to me that Customs saw an ideal opportunity to mushroom the minister.

PARA.TAB: Given all the circumstances of this case, I believe the privileges committee has arrived at the correct and proper verdict and has made appropriately strong comments about the actions of the customs officers involved. It is obvious that the committee has strong reservations about the reasons given as to why the officers involved did not provide the minister with correct information. I concur with those reservations.

I thank the members of the committee and its staff for the time and effort they put into investigating this matter and preparing the report. Nevertheless, it is still my opinion that the full story has not come out. I can only repeat that I simply do not believe that, of all the customs officers present on 26 August, not one of them could recall any detail of the proposed legislation. I also do not accept that these senior officers were so unsure that they decided to keep the doubt to themselves and not inform the minister.

Even if these officers honestly did not recall or had doubts, they had over an hour to verify the situation. There was absolutely no excuse for that not to have happened and for them to give misleading information to the minister, who then told the estimates committee that it had been determined that legislation was not required.

Finally, as it would appear that many of the statements that I have made about customs have been circulated far and wide, I take this opportunity to reassure customs officers that I fully support their role in enforcing the law as it relates to customs. But I do not support customs officers taking the law into their hands, as happened in the Midford Paramount case, and ruining people's lives and businesses. (Extension of time granted) I also do not support such actions being covered up by the customs service.

The comments I have made in this chamber over the last seven months about Customs have been directed only at those officers who were involved in Midford Paramount either directly or in the cover-up, those who seek to perpetuate the myth that Customs did nothing wrong in the Midford Paramount case, those who seek to avoid proper parliamentary scrutiny, those who do not take the estimates process seriously and those who believe that Customs can operate outside the law. I am very aware that this relates to only a minority of officers. I am concerned that if voluntary redundancies are called for in the future it will be the good customs officers who leave and the bad apples who remain.
My concern is on the record. I asked the minister about these issues at the last estimates hearings and I am encouraged that the minister also shares this concern.
