SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 March I asked Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Treasurer, whether he acknowledged that the Australian Taxation Office's pre-consultative document on taxation of financial arrangements would add substantially to compliance costs and run counter to tax simplification. I referred to the government's commitment to tax simplification and contrasted that goal with the document whose effect is that, on a five-year debenture involving a partnership or a company, 1,826 separate calculations may be required in computing the daily internal rate of return.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I thank the Treasury officers for their very generous offer of a briefing on the paper. This may be necessary, given that Senator Cook's answer clearly avoided the central issues to which my question was directed—the increased compliance costs to corporations and the stark contrast of this document in the face of the promises of simplification of taxation laws. To bring in during question time a calculator with an internal rate of return button and wave it around as the simple answer to my question is to trivialise and attempt to simplify a matter of concern to many corporate taxpayers, particularly those who have thousands of transactions a month and have hundreds of investment products.

The press of a button will not, I am sure, be sufficient documentation for the tax office in a tax return. It will require a spreadsheet, for example, to justify Senator Cook's calculation. Under the circumstances, particularly on a discounted security on maturity, it may well run to 14 or 15 pages of spreadsheet.

Senator Cook's gesture also showed that he was unwilling to do the calculations involved in answering my question. This makes his trivialisation a major concern. Clearly, this is a further demonstration that quite frequently the Australian Public Service is not aware of the consequences of so many of its proposals. This gap, unfortunately, is one that is manifested, I believe, in the taxation of financial arrangements.

Senator Cook's answer unjustifiably downplayed the increased compliance costs using the compound accrual system. The daily compounding rate is not usually used by companies in calculating the spread of income or expenditure associated with financial transactions. To require companies to return their financial transactions using the daily compound accrual rate, therefore, will increase their compliance costs quite substantially. Naturally, compliance costs in the first year will be greater than those in latter years because the first year costs will include one-off items such as increased software, hardware upgrade and replacement and design costs.

In his answer Senator Cook also said that a company or partnership having to calculate the daily internal rate of return could use a standard calculator but that some further adjustment to this figure may be necessary depending on such factors as irregular spacing of coupon payments and the degree of precision required. Has he consulted with the Taxation Office on the degree of precision required? Was his calculator waving exercise a government assurance that the Taxation Office would accept a calculation based on a simple financial calculator? Let me also point out to Senator Cook that the consultative document, unlike his answer, concedes frequently throughout the publication:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . reflecting the economic substance of complex arrangements is likely to mean that some complexity in the law will be unavoidable.

It is beyond my comprehension how time and time again this government can say that we are going to simplify the tax legislation and time and again seek to add more pages to an already complex tax system. The consultative document in itself is about 160 pages long, and I guess the legislation to implement the proposal would be at least as long as that, if not longer. The parliament has currently before it yet another example of the further complication of tax laws. The government added to its amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1993 a number of other amendments, particularly in relation to superannuation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook is right in saying that the straight-line method will involve one simple calculation. However, he misled us all by implying that many taxpayers could use the straight-line method. The document proposes that the accruals tax system will not cover financial transactions of natural persons except where there is an opportunity for significant tax referral. Even that exemption is qualified. The exemption will not apply if the taxpayer's holdings of financial arrangements exceed a specified minimum value threshold of $500,000. This will catch many small business transactions.

I concede that the document does state that if the straight-line system basically produces the same result as the daily pending accruals system, that sum can be used. But I wish to point out that a calculation will still be required to determine if both systems produce approximately equal results. So either way both methods still have to be calculated, which is quite time consuming, and under taxation law there has to be documentary proof to show those calculations—it could be a simple calculation that runs to something like 14 to 15 pages on a computer spreadsheet. My question was specifically aimed at partnerships and corporations, and the document says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to reduce compliance difficulties in respect of relatively small and unsophisticated financial dealings, consideration will be given to the feasibility of extending to business the threshold that will apply to natural persons but subject to similar conditions.

I will now turn more generally to the taxation of financial arrangements. Does the government think that it has in fact made out a case for compound accrual accounting in any circumstances? I hope that Senator Sherry will be able to answer that. If he is unable to answer it, I believe that this matter should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration so we can get an answer. This is the matter that I put down for report earlier today. I do not believe that a case has been made out; in fact, there was no attempt to make out a case.

PARA.TAB: The Taxation Office's attitude appears to be that the implementation of this document is a foregone conclusion. But is this not a so-called pre-consultative document? Hence, there is all the more reason for Senate overview. I remind the Senate that the Coles Myer decision highlights the need to clarify the law in relation to this matter. The High Court in that case adopted a straight-line basis rather than a compound accrual basis. The problems that I have referred to here with respect to the application of the accrual system to debentures is equally applicable to foreign exchange gains and losses. This fact was highlighted by a letter written to the editor by Mr Robin Speed, which appeared in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, in which he states:

SPEECH.PARA: If he purchases (equipment) under the proposed accruals tax system he will be taxed on any currency movement between the date of the order and year end, regardless of the fact that he has not received machinery let alone paid for it.

In addition, the compound accrual system will adversely affect a company that goes into insolvency before the financial transaction is complete. In that circumstance the company will not be able to recover the tax paid on the transaction at all, because we do not have such a system of recovery. Senator Cook's answer should be viewed as something of an embarrassment to the Treasurer's office. It clearly sought to trivialise a matter which warrants much more thought than he obviously gave it. Therefore, I would like to see Senator Cook waving a calculator at the tax office and claiming that his calculator justifies a figure in a tax return. I believe it would not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on the Senate record that tonight we have a historic occasion. For the very first time in the history of this parliament, we have a woman occupying an acting leadership position in this chamber. On behalf of the Senate, I congratulate Senator Newman for being the acting leader in the Senate.
—Why doesn't the government do the same?

—Senator Watson raises an excellent point. This government makes much of the point that it is the party that stands up for women but the facts belie this. If honourable senators look at our front bench compared with the government's front bench, they will see that we are the party that attracts quality women—not only in quantity but also in quality—and promotes them on their merits.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal Party has always done this. In the 1940s, we were the leaders in affirmative action for women in the party organisation. We reserve positions for women in the vice-presidencies of the party. Half the vice-presidencies of the party had to be taken by women, and women also had to fill a certain number of other positions. I believe that tonight we see another example of the Liberal Party's commitment to women and I congratulate Senator Newman on her position tonight.

I wish to speak also on quality assurance and some of its bad unintended effects, particularly on two institutions in this city: the Australian National University and the John Curtin School of Medical Research. I spoke on this matter the other night but I did not have time on that occasion to include comments on the way in which the John Curtin School of Medical Research and the Australian National University have been disadvantaged by quality assurance mechanisms. I will do that tonight.

Honourable senators will recall that the other night I spoke about the nature of this mechanism. The government allocated $76 million—not of new money, but of money clawed back from universities—for redistribution in a most inequitable and unfair way. It has taken $76 million away from the 37 universities and given 65 per cent of it back to the top nine universities. The newer universities in particular, which need nurturing and encouragement, have actually been discriminated against, with the bias being towards the older, larger and—the most important point—better-endowed universities.

It is amazing that this Labor government that speaks about equity has set up a system in higher education where the rich will get richer and the poor will get poorer. Probably the greatest tragedy of this process is the way in which the government allocates the money. It uses a totally unfair system. Honourable senators should remember that this is supposed to be a quality assurance mechanism, but only 40 per cent of the factors dealt with excellence. The other 60 per cent actually dealt with the process; in other words, whether universities had quality assurance mechanisms in place. It was not about quality; it was whether they had the mechanisms in place. It was all about how successfully they could fill out forms and how prepared they were to jump through bureaucratic hoops.

The most ludicrous outcome of all was that the world-ranking University of Sydney achieved second ranking. As I pointed out the other day, the government allocated this money to one university in each state—it could not give it to two universities in New South Wales—and the University of Sydney missed out. Everyone realises that the whole situation was ludicrous and that the University of Sydney is by far ahead of a number of the other universities in level one. The silly nature of what the government has done is demonstrated by the fact that it ranked the University of Sydney second.

Let us congratulate the Australian National University, which achieved first ranking. There is an unintended effect of quality assurance with the John Curtin School of Medical Research. The Senate will remember that two years ago we had very serious concerns about the invasion of autonomy of the universities. At that time the government proposed to take the John Curtin medical school from the ANU and to administer it through the department of health. Following that, the administration of the John Curtin school became very complex. At a dinner I attended at the ANU two weeks ago it was said that all the problems that were created by this separate mechanism are still there and that what they would dearly love is for the whole thing to come back under DEET.

The funding is separate and therefore, when this quality assurance mechanism came about, the world-ranking John Curtin medical school certainly contributed to the assessment of the ANU as a first-class institution. The rub was that, having been part of the contribution to that, when the funding came back to the ANU there was nothing for the John Curtin medical school because it was administered through the department of health. Not only did the school lose, but the whole university lost because the amount of funding it got in total out of quality assurance was reduced proportionately.

All the fears we had about this funding mechanism, of administering the John Curtin School of Medical Research through Health, have come to pass. The funding of this school is yet another example of one silly government decision compounded by another silly government decision—the quality assurance mechanism.

We on this side of the parliament are all for quality in universities, but it must be measured in a proper way. The ones who deserve the funding must get the funding and we must not damage first-class institutions such as the ANU and the John Curtin School of Medical Research. Certainly what the government has done has created such damage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer tonight to the national parliament of Turkey and to the detention of some Kurdish members of the parliament this month. I have heard today that they are no longer detained and that their detention was to ask questions of them. But whenever in any country there is the apparent arrest or detention of members of parliament, and in particular when there are charges that may carry the death penalty, all members of parliaments around the world should be concerned. Senator Childs spoke about this matter in the adjournment debate two nights ago. I fundamentally disagree with his assessment of the situation that he described. Tonight I wish to set out where I differ from him.

PARA.TAB: In his speech Senator Childs indicated that he was calling upon all senators to join with him `in calling on the Turkish government to immediately grant these members of parliament the rights and entitlements that they should enjoy'. On the face of it, those words seem innocent enough, but the petition that was circulated in the Senate at question time yesterday addressed these words to the Prime Minister of Turkey:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to lift the parliamentary immunity of the MPs as a result of expressing their opinions in order to fulfil their duties to their constituents causes deep anxiety and bewilderment to us. This will not make the solution of political problems easier. The Members of Parliament, as accepted universally are the representatives of their constituents. Hence any action taken against them is against the political rights of their constituents.

We strongly call for the return of the parliamentary immunity of the Turkish Grand National Assembly members. Without this immunity Turkey lacks conditions where political parties can perform their activities in a democratic environment.

When I read those words yesterday following Senator Childs's speech the night before, I immediately decided that I could not sign such a petition to the Turkish government because it was only half right at best; it was misleading; and it failed to give any account to a number of factors that I believe should be understood when we are making an address to a foreign government.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I have five reasons why I would not urge senators to sign this controversial petition. First, the wording of the petition is derived from a lobby group within Australia. The structure and the words of the petition are not those of parliamentarians, but have the style of a lobbyist. There is an apparent logic about duty and about constituents and about rights, but that logic is superficial and misleading.

The second reason is that I believe Senator Childs's assessment of the situation with regard to Kurdish terrorism within Turkey, as he has set out in his speech, misses the point and is not reliable. In particular he has not consulted the Turkish embassy here in Canberra to check the claims of those who have lobbied him. I had mentioned to Senator Childs that I would be speaking in this way this evening, but he must have another appointment as I see that he is not present in the chamber.

I believe that it is a courtesy and it ought to be a requirement for us to check with the accredited ambassador in this city regarding any events about which we may purport to have received information, so that we can hear what that ambassador and his government would want to say about a matter. After the facts had been checked, then we could make claims or urge senators to action within the Australian parliament.

In the last five years Turkey has become a close ally of Australia in many ways. There is a growing relationship—not only an economic relationship; an area of political understanding—and an alliance in a number of fields. I note, for example, the visit by the foreign minister of Turkey to this city earlier this month, which was a real success. It was hosted by the foreign minister of Australia, in the company of many members of the parliament from all parties.
I seek leave to incorporate at the end of my speech the statement about Senator Childs's speech which has been written by the Turkish Ambassador.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The third reason why I would not sign the words in the petition is that it does not refer at all to Kurdish terrorism or to the secessionist war carried out by a small minority of Turkish citizens. The Kurds represent about 10 million of the total population of about 60 million in Turkey, but the great majority of the 10 million are living in the industrialised western part of Turkey. Only a minority of Kurds live in the south-east, and only a minority of them are represented in part by the Kurdish Workers Party, the PKK, which is waging a violent secessionist war in which there have been thousands of deaths. The failure to refer to that context, I believe, disqualifies the petition in its present form.

PARA.TAB: I also note a fourth reason for not signing the petition is that the seven Kurdish MPs who, it appears, were detained this month have been charged with acts of crime such as inciting to kill. One MP is charged with having given shelter to a PKK terrorist in his own house. The eighth MP is charged with defaming modern Turkey's founder, Ataturk, which is specifically prohibited by Turkish law. Such crimes are cited as grounds for the parliament to invoke articles 83, 84 and 85 of the Turkish constitution following a defined examination of the MPs by a parliamentary committee. MPs do retain their status during any trial. Any verdict is appealable from the State Security Court to the High Court of Appeals. Nothing of this legal context is reflected in the circulated petition.

A fifth and final reason I draw the attention of honourable senators to is that, whilst it is always difficult to make international comparisons, the assessment of PKK secessionist terrorism in Turkey must bear some comparison with the IRA in the United Kingdom, the Tibetan splittists in China, the militant fundamentalists in Egypt, the recent parliamentary insurrection against the Russian government and other examples. It would be generally naive and unsound to encourage Australian parliamentarians to sign inadequate petitions that appear to signal support for one of the contending sides.

However, Australian parliamentarians can only be concerned that it does appear that eight members of parliament in Turkey have been detained this month. I understand that two were almost immediately released and, as I have said, today's news is that all of them appear to be no longer in detention. It is also of concern that the parliament of Turkey appears to have voted, following constitutional procedures, to lift normal parliamentary immunity in respect of these eight MPs.

I conclude by suggesting that the appropriate response would be to write to the ambassador for Turkey here in Australia in order to express our concern, to ask for an explanation, to request international observers at any trial and to insist on full accountability for the safety and fair trial of these parliamentarians. I now incorporate the document to which I referred earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: TURKISH GRAND NATIONAL ASSEMBLY/ DEPUTIES
Responses to the arguments made by Senator CHILDS

PARA.TAB: 1. Senator Childs is arguing that the deputies have had their parliamentary immunity lifted as a result of expressing their opinions in order to fulfil their duties to their constituents. This is totally wrong. The immunities are lifted because the MP's in question are accused of acts which constitute crimes with respect to laws in Turkey, such as inciting to kill, protect terrorist criminals and acts directed to the secular foundation of the State. 7 MP's have expressed views which were provoking terror and violence. The MP's openly supported the acts of terror and violence of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) which is recognised as a terrorist organisation by many countries including Australia.

On the other hand, this argument of Senator Childs ignores the fact that the constituents of these deputies which dwell in the southeast of Turkey are intimidated by the terrorist tactics of the PKK which are very similar to those employed by Pol-Pot in the past. In fact, the terrorist organisation PKK since 1984 has claimed mostly civilian 10,000 lives including Kurdish babies and women in this southeastern part of Turkey by engaging in cross-border operations from their sanctuaries in the neighbouring countries.

It should also be kept in mind that in countries ruled by democracy, the lifting of Parliamentary immunity is as much a constitutional right as is Parliamentary immunity. The immunity of Parliamentarians in France, for example, is limited to the sessions of Parliament. Apart from these periods French parliamentarians carry penal responsibility. In fact, on 7 December 1993, the immunity of the deputy of the Socialist Party from Bouches de Rhone, Bernard Tapie was lifted by the Parliament following the report of the Parliamentary Commission and the initiation of a suit by the Public Prosecutor on charges of financial corruption. Tapie is the 5th parliamentarian whose immunity has been lifted since 1958. In Germany, the immunities of 12 parliamentarians have been lifted since 1990.

2. The argument that the European Parliament has formally criticised Turkish Government. The decision of the European Parliament is based on lack of information as well as misinformation. The decision to lift the immunities was reached as the result of the voting by the representatives of the Turkish nation at the Turkish Grand National Assembly (TGNA) in accordance with article 14 of the Turkish Constitution which stipulates the conditions under which basic rights and freedoms may be restricted.

Therefore, the waiving of the immunity is an act of the legislative and not of the executive organs. In accordance with the principle of separation of powers, the executive organ has no say in this matter. In fact, the TGNA, in an effort to protect its respectability and credibility, asked the judiciary to render a verdict concerning the grave accusations directed at the deputies. With its decision the TGNA has only made it possible for the judiciary to take action. It will be the independent judicial organs that will give verdict on grave accusations. The decision of the TGNA allows commencement of the legal procedure.

The decision of the courts may be appealed. In fact, appeals have been initiated before the Constitutional Court against the decision of the lifting of immunities. The Constitutional Court will give a decision within two weeks.

The Turkish Parliament has acted scrupulously in full awareness of its great responsibility in taking its decision. With its decision the Turkish Parliament has defended the constitution and democracy. It has at the same time cleared the path of independent judiciary for the protection of the State against terror, separatism and religious fundamentalism, by preventing certain MP's abusing their parliamentary immunities as a shield.
All these facts also make it clear that the decision to lift the immunities is taken by the TGNA and the military is not involved.

3. The argument that seven of these members of Parliament have campaigned for greater autonomy for Kurds in Turkey and the eighth has criticised the secular nature of the modern Turkish State ignores the fact that the accusations made by the TGNA against the deputies involve offences related to territorial integrity and the basic principles of the Sate, such as secularism as well as offences in the form of expression with the potential to acquire the form of actions such as to incite to commit crime through propaganda or give encouragement for crime. No freedom is unlimited. The European Convention on Human Rights foresees the limitation by law of the freedom of thought and expression for the sake of national security, territorial integrity and public safety.

A parliamentarian cannot be expected to fulfil his/her duties under serious accusations. For this reason, the parliamentarians in question have been given an opportunity to prove themselves innocent through judiciary means. This was, in fact, necessary to enable the said parliamentarians as well as the Grand National Assembly to carry out their tasks effectively. This was also necessary for the people not to lose their belief in democracy and in the Grand National Assembly of Turkey.

4. The argument that these parliamentarians will be charged under article 125 of the anti-terror law: First of all, the article in question is not an article of the anti-terror law. It is an article of the Turkish Penal Code which deals with actions against the indivisibility of the State and nation. Article 125 of the Turkish Penal Code itself is based on article 14 of the Turkish Constitution which stipulates that the basic rights and freedoms as indicated in the Constitution cannot be used against the integrity of the state and endanger its very existence.

In fact, article 14 of the Turkish Constitution, like the constitutions of all civilised countries, reflect the universal principles included in the European Convention as explained above. The same Convention states that nothing in the said Convention may be interpreted as implying a freedom to engage in any activity or perform any act aimed at the destruction of any of the rights and freedoms stated. The Constitution of Federal Germany, for example, contains similar provision and the German Penal Code, in its articles 81 and 82, sanctions imprisonment ranging between 10 years and life for such crimes under the heading "Treason against the federal state." Furthermore the European Convention of Human Rights also makes clear distinction between the freedom of thought and freedom of expression, codifying that states may take necessary measures to prevent the abuse of the freedom of thought, as well as to protect the state against separatism.

5. The argument that the death penalty will be requested is an oversimplification of the legal proceedings stated in the laws and the Constitution of Turkey. Indeed the violation of the State's territorial integrity involves the death penalty as the maximum penalty for those who are charged with this crime. Penalties, however, will be considerably reduced if no act within the meaning of article 125 is accomplished and if this act remains in the form of provocation or incitement. On the other hand, all acts and actions of the administration are subject to judicial appeal and review.

6. The argument that the 7 Kurdish Parliamentarians represent a large minority 10 million people is wrong. The deputies in question elected from the south eastern provinces of Turkey do not represent the Kurdish origin people but the whole of the nation. In fact, article 80 of the Turkish Constitution stipulates that the MP's do not represent their constituency or their electors but the whole of the Turkish nation. Moreover, large number of the Turkish citizens of Kurdish origin live in the western provinces of Turkey. In fact Istanbul today is the province with the largest number of Kurdish origin people living in Turkey. In addition, in the parliament almost 150 MP's are of Kurdish origin. Many Turkish citizens of Kurdish origin occupy prominent positions in all areas of public life. We have had even ministers and prime ministers of Kurdish origins.

7. The argument that since 1984 many of those died in the conflict between the Turkish military and Kurdish separatist have been civilians—neglects to mention that the main targets of the terrorist organisation Kurdistan Workers Party-PKK are the civilians. The civilians who have died in the conflicts, in fact, are the victims of the PKK. The aim of the PKK is to intimidate the local population through employing terrorist tactics and thereby gain some degree of ostensible support. As a result of PKK's terrorist attacks since 1984 more than 3000 civilians have lost their lives and the majority of these are of Kurdish origin. The PKK also in an effort to deter the Turkish Government from bringing social and economic services to the region, attacks hospitals, trains, buses, touristic installations, development projects. In fact, the PKK is the greatest perpetrator of human rights. It is, therefore, basic duty of the government to guarantee the protection of its citizens lives and property against the PKK terror organisation.

The combat of the Turkish State with the terror organisation, however, is presented by certain groups or interests as the terror of the security forces with the aim of misleading the international public opinion to achieve their goals.

The arguments of Senator Childs are ill-informed to say the least. The Embassy of the Republic of Turkey calls on all the honourable members of the Parliament not to be misled by the terrorist propaganda and support the rule of law and constitutional democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: 16 March 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —In Queensland, local council elections will be held on Saturday, 26 March 1994. In Townsville, where I have one of my offices, the Liberal Party has an excellent mayoral candidate in Barbara Hymus—a 40-year-old business woman and mother of five—and a complete Liberal team. This team includes the three incumbent Liberal councillors, Peter Lindsay, Jim Cathcart and John Francis, and seven motivated, community minded citizens who are running as candidates for the balance of the 10 wards.

PARA.TAB: While Barbara Hymus and her Liberal team have been dealing with the issues that affect the people of Townsville, the Labor Party, running true to form, has been resorting to its normal dirty tricks campaign. It started a couple of weeks ago with the Labor mayor spending a whole day peddling the false beat up that the Liberals would be running as Independents. Legal advice from a leading Queensland QC has confirmed that what Mooney was saying is wrong, misleading, and probably defamatory.

Here we have the Labor mayor who is willing to run around in his council-supplied V8 Statesman all day spreading vicious lies, and still having the gall to put out his hand for his $1,500 weekly pay cheque. In fact, the Townsville ratepayers are subsidising Mayor Mooney's lies. No wonder there have been so many raw sewage spills in Townsville recently—the mayor is too busy dreaming up a new lie to help stop his inevitable election loss rather than having time to actually maintain basic ratepayers' services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I know we are used to this sort of tirade of abuse, but is the language that Senator Macdonald is using in conformity with the standing orders?
—Senator Sherry, I was not conscious of any offensive word, but was there anything in particular which struck you?
—The reference to `lies'.
—I will listen to what Senator Macdonald says carefully. `Lies' is not a word that I am personally attracted to, but in some contexts it has been accepted in the past by Presiding Officers.

—The Labor Party, of course, is always anxious to save its members from the truth being known about them. As I was saying, as if what he has been doing is not enough, his latest invention is to use blatant untruths and misleading statements in television advertising. He makes absolutely false claims—and if that is not lying, Senator Sherry can correct me—in his advertisements, saying, `The Liberals want you to pay more and more', and that water rates will rise by 70 per cent. They are absolute and unmitigated lies. The Labor council would probably raise rates, if Mayor Mooney's federal mate's—that is, Mr Keating's—track record on tax hikes is anything to go by. The Labor Mayor of Townsville could certainly relate to sports rorts, whiteboard accounting and the sandwich shop fiasco, as it has recently been revealed that his previous campaign received a substantial donation from a company doing developmental work in Townsville to which favours could be given, and the donation was conveniently not accounted for. Mayor Mooney and Mrs Kelly obviously went to the same corrupt accounting school. It is evident that Labor, at all levels of government, cannot be trusted with money. What other sly and underhanded deals has he done that we do not know about?

PARA.TAB: The Barbara Hymus Liberal team will keep rates at or below inflation and provide better services and management. It is high time that Mayor Mooney started being accountable and honourable to the Townsville ratepayers. This seems to be a concept that is not understood. For 15 years, the Labor City Council has broken promise after promise in Townsville, just like its federal colleague Paul Keating.

Year after year, we have heard the Labor Party say that Magnetic Quays would be completed, yet there is still a huge hole in the ground on Magnetic Island, almost as big as one of Tony Mooney's exaggerations and untruths. Now—surprise, surprise, just before the election—they are promising that they can almost guarantee that they think that maybe they have a developer lined up to complete Magnetic Quays.

The Townsville people are not stupid, although Mayor Mooney treats them as such. They are sick and tired of Labor's negative campaign of distortion and sick and tired of Labor's lies. Mayor Mooney has ignored and neglected the basic services people need. As such, there is now a major sewerage problem in Townsville. Raw sewage is flowing into Ross Creek, onto the Strand and into the ocean. The beach has been closed and people have been instructed not to swim in the ocean. Crime has sky-rocketed, with a wave of burglaries, bashings and vandalism. It is so bad in Townsville at the moment that army personnel have been advised not to walk in the mall at night. If diggers cannot walk down the street in safety, what type of place is it? This man Mooney is clearly out of touch with crime in Townsville, as he dismisses it and says it is not true.

Mayor Mooney has taken the people of Townsville for granted and will soon pay for his disregard. The simple fact is that Tony Mooney cannot tell the truth and is not fit to be a mayor. The Liberals are cleaning up the mess Labor has caused in five states. Soon, Barbara Hymus and her Liberal team will be doing the same in Townsville, North Queensland.

PARA.TAB: With reference to an article which appeared in the Melbourne Herald-Sun of 7 September 1993, regarding the sale of residential homes to staff at a discount in the Northern Territory:

(1) & (2) With the establishment of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), the former Department of Transport and Communications retained the ownership of a number of "off airport" houses occupied by FAC staff. The ongoing transfer of aerodromes to local authorities under the Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan (ALOP) also left the former Department with further "off airport" residences occupied by its own employees. In consultation with the FAC and the unions the former Department adopted the following principles in respect to disposal of excess "off airport" housing:
(a) The existing tenant would be given the opportunity to purchase
(b) A valuation of the property would be obtained
(c) Offers to tenants were based on valuations prepared within the three months preceding the date of offer

(d) An adjustment to the valuation was made to take account of the fact that minimal costs would be incurred by the former Department for advertising, inspections, commissions etc. In the case of properties sold to former Departmental staff tenants, the purchaser received a $3000 discount plus the inclusion of departmental whitegoods or furnishings allocated to the dwelling. FAC staff who purchased a former Departmental dwelling received the $3000 plus an FAC incentive discount of $4000.
(e) A further adjustment to the valuation would be made to account for tenant provided improvements e.g. garage, garden shed, etc.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 2 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is Austrade promoting Australia as a provider of high quality education for visiting Asian students.
(2) Does Austrade promote this education export in particular countries and are some countries favoured over others.

(3) Are all Austrade promotions consistent with Australia's immigration policies and are systematic measures undertaken to ensure that the actions of Austrade are consistent with actions and policy decisions made by other government departments, that is, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: if so, how regularly are these measures applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Austrade promotes Australian education services widely, including established markets in Asia and emerging markets in Europe, the Middle East, and the Pacific. Austrade does not favour some countries over others.

(3) Yes. There is regular contact with the Departments of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Employment, Education and Training. Austrade is represented on NACCIETS (The National Consultative Committee on International Education and Training Services) which meets quarterly, and also participates in Interdepartmental reviews of policies governing the export of Australian education services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice on 23 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has Australia been offered a partner country role at this technology exhibition and what are the ramifications of this offer.
(2) How does CeBIT rank among world exhibitions.

(3) What will be the estimated cost of Australia's participation in CeBIT and have individual State governments and commercial firms offered to contribute to Austrade's staging of the Australian section of the exhibition.
(4) What short and long-term benefits are expected to flow from Australia's participation in CeBIT.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia has been offered and accepted the role of Partner Country at CeBIT'95, to be held in Hannover, Germany, 8-15 March 1995. Austrade sees the Partner Country status as a uniquely valuable opportunity to promote Australian Information Technology and Telecommunications capability on a global stage.

(2) CeBIT is one of the world's largest trade fairs, and is by far the largest trade event for the Information Technology or the Telecommunications industries, as well as the most comprehensive in terms of the range of products covered. CeBIT'95 is expected to attract over 600,000 visitors from 100 countries, some 6,000 exhibitors from 50 countries, and 7,000 journalists. CeBIT has grown every year since it was started in 1986, and has become a global event with 100,000 visitors from outside Germany and 35,000 from the Asia Pacific region.

(3) The cost of participation in CeBIT'95 is currently estimated at $A2.2 million. The Austrade Board has allocated $1,050,000 to Austrade's "InTelligent Australia" promotion at CeBIT. Austrade expects to receive financial contributions from the governments of NSW, VIC, QLD, SA, WA, ACT together with space rental contributions from individual company exhibitors, and sponsorships.

(4) In the short term, Austrade forecasts—conservatively—that Australian exhibitors will realise at least $150 million in orders resulting from CeBIT'94 and `95 (based on reports from exhibitors from 1986 to 1993). More importantly, CeBIT'95 should result in at least 50 leading-edge Australian IT companies being permanently established in overseas markets, through subsidiaries, joint ventures, distributors, or strategic partners. In the longer term, CeBIT'95 and the promotions, market research, planning and export activities that precede and follow it, will help energise the Australian IT industry and help focus it on the international markets where it is competitive. Austrade's ultimate objective is to dramatically and permanently raise world-wide awareness of Australia as a source of technological excellence and a business and investment destination.
